Headline: Rallis India share price falls 8% after Q3 results. Should you sell or hold?Shares of Rallis India were down 8% in early trade and were down 6.82% to Rs 269.85 at around 1:56 pm.
Content: Rallis India share price fell sharply on Monday after it reported a decline of over 54% in year-on-year (YoY) net profit in Q3FY25. Shares of Rallis India were down 8% in early trade and were down 6.82% to Rs 269.85 at around 1:56 pm. The agri-inputs company’s profit fell to Rs 11 crore in the third quarter, compared to Rs 24 crore in the same quarter of the previous year. It’s revenue from operations fell 12.7% YoY to Rs 522 crore. Meanwhile, its operating income or EBITDA fell 27.9% YoY to Rs 44 crore. Moreover, the EBITDA margin contracted to 8.4% from 10.2% in the corresponding period last year. On a quarter-on-quarter (QoQ) basis, the company’s net profit slumped nearly 89% and revenue fell 43.8%. Shares of Rallis India have been on a declining path for a long period now. In a month, the stock has declined 9%, over 20% in 6 months and nearly 10% in a year. It may be noted that Rallis India, a subsidiary of Tata Chemicals, is a leading agro-science company, offering a diverse portfolio of products for Indian farmers.Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Jan 20, 2025

Headline: Ian Bremmer calls Elon Musk the most powerful man after Donald Trump in USIan Bremmer responded with a yes when asked if Musk is right now the most powerful man in the US after Donald Trump.
Content: Ian Bremmer, the founder and president of Eurasia Group, a political risk research and consulting firm, agreed that Elon Musk, Tesla founder, is right now the most powerful man in the US after president-elect Donald Trump.   In an exclusive interview with Rahul Kawal, News Director, India Today & Aaj Tak, Bremmer responded with a yes when asked if Musk is right now the most powerful man in the US after Donald Trump.  "He is clearly the most powerful non-president in the United States and, in some ways, it was true even before Trump was elected given his role in the public square," Bremmer told Rahul Kanwal.  "I think now that Trump has been elected and than Elon has spent more time with him than anybody else, without question. And has even inserted himself into legislation directly, even though he has no official election," he added.  Bremmer further said that it is being reported that Elon Musk will have his own office at the White House.  He also talked about Donald Trump setting up cryptocurrency for himself and his wife, calling it a 'conflict of interest'.  "Lots of conflict of interest with Trump setting himself and his wife cryptocurrencies that people are putting billions of dollars into. None of this is normal. None of this is leading by example," said Bremmer.  "If Narendra Modi would have meetings with a head of state or a company's CEO and bring in Gautam Adani, I promise you in Davos they would be calling India a 'banana republic'. But when the most powerful country in the world does it, it's a new order," he added. Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Jan 20, 2025Tune InMust Watch

Headline: Faster PF transfers, direct online claims: Check benefits of new EPFO rulesThe newly introduced measures are expected to minimise the turnaround time, thereby benefiting about 94% of the 13 million claims filed during FY 2024-25.
Content: In a landmark move, set to benefit over 65 million subscribers, the Employees’ Provident Fund Organisation (EPFO) has introduced significant reforms to fast-track provident fund (PF) transfers. Further, it has also announced streamlining of personal detail corrections. Both these measures aim at reducing delays and grievances, thereby providing relief to both employees and employers. Let’s see how these changes work.advertisementSIMPLIFICATION OF PROCESS  Earlier, PF transfer requests needed employer verification, adding delays that could stretch to 14 days or more. Now, members with fully compliant e-KYC (Electronic Know Your Customer) can now self-correct errors online without requiring employer intervention, approval of EPFO or additional documents. Subscribers can file transfer claims directly through the EPFO portal using an Aadhaar one-time password (OTP). The newly introduced measures are expected to minimise the turnaround time, thereby benefiting about 94% of the 13 million claims filed during FY 2024-25, which would now instantly reach the EPFO. This change also addresses the backlog of nearly 20 lakh transfer claims that have been pending for over two weeks in the previous nine months alone.MINIMISING GRIEVANCES AND TURNAROUND TIME  With the employer’s role being reduced to a great extent, the turnaround time for processing transfer claims will drop significantly. As of now, 17%  of them relate to transfer-related grievances.  The newly-introduced reforms not only reduce these grievances but also ensure faster resolution, benefiting both the employees and employers.SEAMLESS CORRECTION OF PERSONAL DETAILS  The EPFO has also announced streamlining of personal detail corrections. Subscribers with a Universal Account Number (UAN) issued on or after October 1, 2017can now self-correct errors online without requiring employer intervention, approval of EPFO or additional documents. But, for the UAN issued before the said date, employers make corrections through a simplified documentation process and without the need for EPFO approval.  In other words, the above measures are a step towards empowering the Indian workforce, thus ensuring that their hard-earned savings are efficiently managed.Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Jan 20, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Budget 2025: New income tax bill likely to be introduced for simpler taxationThe bill will be introduced directly in Parliament, wherein stakeholder inputs including taxpayers and experts, would be incorporated, before being finalised.
Content: Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman is likely to introduce a new income tax bill during the upcoming Budget session, which aims to simplify taxation laws and sync them with the prevailing economic scenario. In fact, the government aims to cut down the size of the legislation by about 60%, thereby making it clearer and concise. This initiative comes as part of the government’s commitment to create a more taxpayer-friendly and efficient framework.advertisementCALL FOR A SIMPLER TAX STRUCTURE  As per a PTI report, a committee in charge of revising the law is contemplating replacing the 63-year-old Income Tax Act, 1961, instead of amending the existing law. The committee intends to divide the Income Tax Act into two or even three parts, for greater clarity and efficiency. The bill will be introduced directly in Parliament, wherein stakeholder inputs including those of taxpayers and experts would be incorporated, before being finalised. As per sources, the draft law is almost ready and is likely to be presented during the latter part of the Budget session, which is scheduled from January 31 to April 4.FORMATION OF SPECIALISED SUB-COMMITTES In fact, an internal committee has been formed by The Central Board of Direct Taxes (CBDT), which would supervise the review process. Also, 22 specialised sub-committees have been formed to study the various aspects of the Act. In order to ensure that the new bill addresses current economic challenges, public feedback has been sought in areas including language simplification, litigation reduction, simplified compliance and identifying obsolete provisions. Around 6,500 suggestions have been received from stakeholders by the Income Tax Department. In other words, the new law is expected to minimise disputes and litigation, and be easily understandable, thereby creating a more transparent system for taxpayers.Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Jan 20, 2025Tune InMust Watch

Headline: Sensex, Nifty rally as banking stocks power markets higher; Zomato falls 7%Share Market Today: The S&P BSE Sensex gained 454.11 points to close at 77,073.44, while the NSE Nifty50 added 141.55 points to end at 23,344.75.
Content: Benchmark stock market indices started the week on a positive note after they closed higher on Monday driven by a rise in banking sector stocks.  The S&P BSE Sensex gained 454.11 points to close at 77,073.44, while the NSE Nifty50 added 141.55 points to end at 23,344.75.  Ajit Mishra – SVP, Research, Religare Broking Ltd, said, "The markets began the week on a positive note, gaining over half a percent amid mixed signals. After a flat opening, strength in heavyweight stocks, particularly in the banking sector, propelled the index higher during the first half, followed by a range-bound movement for the rest of the session." Kotak Mahindra Bank shares, which surged nearly 10% in early trade, ended the day with a gain of 9%. Wipro was also among the stocks that saw good gains as it ended the day with a climb of 6.58%.   "After a volatile start, the market saw a strong upward move, ending the session with a 141.55-point gain to close at 23,344.75. Most sectors, except Auto and FMCG, ended in the green, with Banking and Metal indices leading the gains. The Broader Markets outperformed the Frontline Index, as Mid and Smallcaps rose over 0.90%," said Aditya Gaggar Director of Progressive Shares.  Banking indices showed strong positive momentum, with Nifty Private Bank leading the gains with a rise of 2.38%, while Nifty PSU Bank advanced by 1.99%. Shares of Zomato fell as much as 7% after the company reported a 57.24% decline in year-on-year (YoY) consolidated net profit in the third quarter of FY25. "Markets appear to be consolidating following the recent decline, with the ongoing earnings season keeping participants engaged. Additionally, budget-related themes are attracting selective buying interest. While there has been limited alignment with global markets lately, developments following Trump’s inauguration will be closely monitored for potential cues," said Mishra.  "We could see Nifty gain support between 23,300 and 23,260 and face resistance between 23,430 and 24,620 in the next session," said VLA Ambala, Co-Founder of Stock Market Today. Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Jan 20, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Zomato shares decline 7% as Q3 profit tumbles over 57%Zomato Stock Price: Soon after the Q3 results were released, Zomato shares sharply declined over 7%, hitting a day's low of Rs 228.80. At market closing, the food delivery giant's shares fell 3.14% to Rs 240.95.
Content: Shares of Zomato fell as much as 7% on Monday after the company reported a 57.24% decline in year-on-year (YoY) consolidated net profit in the third quarter of FY25. Soon after the Q3 results were released, Zomato shares sharply declined over 7%, hitting a day’s low of Rs 228.80. At market closing, the food delivery giant’s shares fell 3.14% to Rs 240.95. In Q3 FY25, the company’s net profit declined to Rs 59 crore from Rs 138 crore in the corresponding period a year ago. Revenue from operations, however, surged 64.39% to Rs 5,405 crore in the quarter, compared to Rs 3,288 crore in the year-ago period. The company also said that its adjusted EBITDA grew 128% YoY. However, on a quarter-on-quarter (QoQ) basis, the adjusted EBITDA fell 14% due to accelerated investments towards new store openings and customer acquisition in the quick commerce business.  Zomato also said that its Blinkit store count crossed the 1,000 store mark, one quarter ahead of plan. It aims to get to 2,000 stores by December 2025, one year ahead of earlier guidance of Dec 2026. "Muted 2% QoQ (17% YoY) GOV growth in food delivery this quarter, driven by broad-based demand slowdown. Sharp rise in Adjusted EBITDA margins from 3.5% in Q2FY25 to 4.3% in Q3FY25," Zomato added.  Zomato CEO Deepinder Goyal said, "The losses in our quick commerce business this quarter are largely on account of pulling forward the growth investments in the business that we would have otherwise made in a staggered manner over the next few quarters." "As of now, it seems like we will get to our target of 2,000 stores by Dec 2025, much earlier than our previous guidance of December 2026," he added.  The company's CFO Akshant Goyal also said that losses may continue in the near term as the focus remains on expansion. "As we continue to bring forward store expansion, our networks may have to carry a greater load of underutilized stores which will impact near-term profits in the next one or two quarters," he said. "These investments will however also likely result in GOV growth remaining meaningfully above 100%, at least for FY25 and FY26. Once we come out from this period of expansion, the business is likely to turn sharply from being loss making to becoming meaningfully profitable as a larger part of our business starts comprising mature stores compared to newly added ones. We remain confident of navigating the short term (expansion/ competition) with focus and discipline," he added. Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Jan 20, 2025

Headline: Global elites' wealth grew 3x faster in 2024; 4 new billionaires weekly: OxfamOxfam International, in its latest assessment of global inequality timed to the opening of the World Economic Forum meeting, also predicts at least five trillionaires will crop up over the next decade. A year ago, the group forecast that only one trillionaire would appear during that time.
Content: Billionaires’ wealth grew three times faster in 2024 than the year before, a top anti-poverty group reported on Monday as some of the world’s political and financial elite prepared for an annual gathering in Davos, Switzerland. Oxfam International, in its latest assessment of global inequality timed to the opening of the World Economic Forum meeting, also predicts at least five trillionaires will crop up over the next decade. A year ago, the group forecast that only one trillionaire would appear during that time. Oxfam’s research adds weight to a warning by outgoing President Joe Biden last week of a “dangerous concentration of power in the hands of very few ultra-wealthy people.” The group’s sharp-edged report, titled “Takers Not Makers,” also says the number of people in poverty has barely budged since 1990. The World Economic Forum expects to host some 3,000 attendees, including business executives, academics, government officials, and civic group leaders at its annual meeting in the Alpine village of Davos.WHAT’S THE WORRY ABOUT? ... THE ‘NEW ARISTOCRACY’ President-elect Donald Trump, who visited Davos twice during his first term and was set to take the oath of office on Monday, is expected to take part in the forum’s event by video on Thursday. He has long championed wealth accumulation — including his own — and counts multibillionaire Elon Musk as a top adviser. “What you’re seeing at the moment is a billionaire president taking oaths today, backed by the richest man. So this is pretty much the jewel in the crown of the global oligarchies,” Amitabh Behar, executive director of Oxfam International, said in an interview, referring to Trump and Musk. “It’s not about one specific individual. It’s the economic system that we have created where the billionaires are now pretty much being able to shape economic policies, social policies, which eventually gives them more and more profit,” he added. Like Biden’s call for making billionaires “begin to pay their fair share” through the U.S. tax code, Oxfam — a global advocacy group — called on governments to tax the richest to reduce inequality and extreme wealth, and to “dismantle the new aristocracy.” The group called for steps like the break-up of monopolies, capping CEO pay, and regulation of corporations to ensure they pay “living wages” to workers.HOW ARE THE POOREST FARING? Many investors racked up strong gains in 2024, with strong performances for top tech companies and stock-market indexes like the S&P 500, as well as the price of gold and cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin. Oxfam said billionaire wealth grew by $2 trillion last year, or roughly $5.7 billion a day, three-times faster than in 2023. The number of billionaires rose by 204 to 2,769, and the 10 richest men saw their wealth rise nearly $100 million a day on average, it said. Citing World Bank data, the group pointed to lingering poverty, saying the number of people living on less than $6.85 per day has “barely changed” since 1990. Oxfam used Forbes’ Real-Time Billionaire List” as of end-November for data on the ultra-rich. By contrast, at least four new billionaires were “minted” every week in 2024, and three-fifths of billionaire wealth comes from inheritance, monopoly power or “crony connections,” it said. On average, Oxfam said, low- and middle-income countries are spending nearly half their national budgets on debt repayments. It also noted that life expectancy in Africa is just under 64 years of age, compared to over 79 years in Europe.WILL IT BE BUSINESS AS USUAL AT DAVOS AGAIN THIS YEAR? Despite the growing gap between the super rich and the poor, the annual Davos confab, which formally begins on Tuesday, will likely focus this year again on making money and doing deals, with strongman leaders on the rise in some Western countries and progressive causes like diversity and climate change waning in the business world. The continued rise of artificial intelligence as a tool for business to reap greater efficiencies will also again be a central theme in Davos, despite worries in many sectors that AI could upend many white-collar jobs and displace workers in an array of industries. Trump’s return for a second term will likely be on many lips in Davos, as will lingering conflicts, including wars in Ukraine and Sudan, along with hopes for a continuation of a cease-fire that began on Sunday between Hamas and Israel, pausing their devastating 15-month war in Gaza. Forum organizers last week issued a survey conducted among 900 experts for “Global Risks Report,” which found that conflicts between countries was the top concern, followed by extreme weather, economic confrontation, misinformation and disinformation, and “societal polarization” — a nod to the gap between rich and poor. As in past years, protesters calling for more economic equality, taxing the rich and pressing other demands took to the streets. Some blocked roads to Davos, snarling traffic in places and delaying trips for some attendees to the event, which runs through Friday.Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Jan 20, 2025Trending Reel

Headline: Budget 2025: How can government make healthcare more affordableThe healthcare sector expects lowered costs on medical equipment in Budget 2025, thereby boosting affordability and accessibility.
Content: All eyes are set on February 1, as the Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman is scheduled to unveil the Budget 2025. India's healthcare sector anticipates the introduction of policies that promote prevention, innovation, and affordable care. Here's a look at some of the key expectations of the healthcare sector from Budget 2025.FOCUS ON PREVENTIVE HEALTHCARE  With an increase in ailments related to the heart and a rise in lifestyle diseases, people are urging a keen focus towards preventive healthcare. Rajneesh Chopra, Managing Director, Amway India, “Although awareness around wellness is growing, significant barriers to access the same and affordability remain a concern, particularly when it comes to nutrition and dietary supplements. These challenges hinder the full realisation of a healthier, more resilient population.” He added, “A key step in this direction would be rationalising the GST from the current 18% on health and wellness products, including dietary supplements.”EXPANDING GST EXEMPTIONS  Healthcare experts are urging enhancing GST exemptions and input tax credits on dietary health and wellness products, which would go a long way in promoting holistic wellness across the country. “A key step in this direction would be rationalising the GST from the current 18% on health and wellness products, including dietary supplements,” states Rajneesh Chopra. In the words of Dr. Sharmila Tulpule, Founder & Director, Orthobiologix Biotech Pvt. Ltd., “A reduction of GST and Customs Duty on medical devices and surgical inputs could help lower treatment costs, making advanced procedures and life-saving interventions more affordable for patients.”REDUCING TAXES ON MEDICAL EQUIPMENTS  The healthcare sector expects lowered costs on medical equipment in Budget 2025, thereby boosting affordability and accessibility. Moreover, reducing import duties and promoting domestic manufacturing can significantly lower the cost of treatment, benefitting both the patients and the healthcare providers.   Dr. Jay Goyal, Senior Eye Surgeon and Director, Surya Eye Hospital, says, “The upcoming budget must focus on lowering taxes on medical equipment and increasing subsidies for advanced procedures for diseases like diabetic retinopathy and glaucoma.”BOOSTING R&D  The healthcare sector expects a higher budgetary allocation, particularly to promoting research and development. Mr Masaharu Morita, Founder and Program Director at NURA, “With the help of the government’s industry-friendly policies, AI-enabled healthcare companies can channelise more investments in the healthcare sector, particularly in the adoption of AI and advanced technologies.” Dr. Sharmila Tulpule, added, “Encouraging emerging fields like regenerative medicine, robotics, and advanced diagnostics will drive innovation and position India as a leader in medical advancements." If taken into consideration, these measures would align with the government’s Swasth Bharat mission and place the country as a global leader in holistic wellness.Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Jan 20, 2025Tune InMust Watch

Headline: Want to avoid paying credit card annual fees? Here are 3 easy tipsSometimes banks may waive your annual fees as a goodwill gesture, if you are a loyal customer with a good credit history.
Content: In today’s time, credit cards have emerged as a key financial tool. Apart from paying EMIs, they also offer rewards, special deals and cashback, etc. But, at times, some lenders charge high annual fees which increase your financial burden. This article talks about easy and practical tips to lower the annual fees and make your credit card more cost-effective.advertisementCHOOSING THE RIGHT CARDNot all credit cards come with annual fees. Nowadays, several lenders offer lifetime free cards, while many others waive off fees if you spend a specific amount yearly. Not all credit cards come with annual fees. Nowadays, several lenders offer lifetime free cards, while many others waive off fees if you spend a specific amount yearly. Hence, it is advised to access your spending habits and opt for those credit cards with benefits which you actually use.NEGOTIATING AND REWARD REDEMPTION At times, banks may waive your annual fees as a goodwill gesture, if you are a loyal customer with a good credit history.  In order to negotiate a waiver, contact your bank, tell them about your regular payments and responsible usage. Moreover, some credit cards allow their customers to use the accumulated rewards points to waive off the annual fees. Hence, check your card’s reward program and plan your spending to accumulate these reward points.SPENDING SPECIFIC AMOUNT  Several credit cards waive the annual fees if a customer reaches a particular spending limit. Hence, it is advisable to switch to a credit card which offers more benefits or rewards and has lower annual fees, if your existing credit card does not align with your current needs. In other words, lowering or waiving off credit card annual fees is easier than you think, if you negotiate with your bank wisely and are well-informed. However, it is advised not to fall into the trap of overspending while trying to maximise its benefits.Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Jan 20, 2025Trending Reel

Headline: Donald Trump is a dealmaker: WEF President Børge Brende on potential US trade tariffsWorld Economic Forum President Børge Brende said while some tariffs may be introduced by the US administration, Donald Trump's ultimate goal will likely be to negotiate favourable deals.
Content: World Economic Forum President Borge Brende shared crucial insights on the impact of potential US trade tariffs as Donald Trump returns to the White House for a second term as president. In an exclusive conversation with Rahul Kanwal, News Director, India Today and Aajtak, on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum (WEF) 2025 in Davos, Brende acknowledged that incoming trade tariffs under the Trump administration could impact the global economy but added that there will be a growth in global trade.  “Donald Trump is a dealmaker,” Brende said, acknowledging Trump's strategy of using tariffs as leverage in negotiations. Reflecting on Trump’s first term, he said, “Look at Trump 1.0—trade grew globally when he was president the last time, and economic growth was strong.” Brende said while some tariffs may be introduced, especially targeting nations with significant trade deficits with the US, Trump’s aim will likely be to negotiate favourable deals. “Sometimes they (US) put tariffs out there and see what happens down the road,” he added, pointing to Trump’s transactional approach.COLLABORATION IN A 'MULTIPOLAR' WORLD During the interview, Brende also spoke about the current geopolitical landscape, which according to him is "fragmented," with rising competition between the US and China shaping the global agenda. “The geopolitical backdrop for Davos this year is the most complicated in generations,” he said. The competition, along with increasing conflicts and less international cooperation, has created what Brende described as a “geopolitical recession.” Brende also spoke about a "new world order" where nations are competing for influence. "It is definitely going to be a more multipolarised world with more players. We also see more emerging economies taking more room and also playing a bigger role in the world economy—be it Indonesia, Malaysia, Africa, and definitely India," he said.  He said the multipolar world will continue to have "key actors" like the US, given the fact that it comprises almost 30% of the global economy. According to him, the focus this year at Davos will be on collaboration in specific areas, which will benefit all the stakeholders in some way or another.  "We still need to collaborate on mitigating greenhouse gases. We need to collaborate even in a competitive world for future preparedness," Brende added.WHAT TO EXPECT FROM WEF 2025? Brende also highlighted the need to revive global growth amid this challenging environment. “There is a lot of realism related to the economic outlook,” he said, adding that participants in Davos are focusing on ways to achieve trend growth of 4% in the coming years. He indicated that the focus at the WEF 2025 will be achieving greater cooperation and boosting global growth, even in an era of growing protectionism. As far has Trump 2.0 is concerned, Brende remains optimistic that there will be a balance between competition and cooperation. Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Jan 20, 2025Tune InMust Watch

Headline: Stallion India IPO: Check allotment status, latest GMP and listing dateStallion India IPO allotment status: Investors who have subscribed to Stallion India IPO can check their allotment status on the online portals of the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) and Bigshare Services Pvt Ltd.
Content: The allotment of shares for the initial public offering (IPO) of Stallion India Fluorochemicals Limited will be finalised on Tuesday after having seen massive interest from investors. Stallion India IPO received bids of close to 200 times.  Stallion India IPO opened for subscription on January 16 and closed for bidding on January 20 and aimed to raise Rs 199.45 crore.  The IPO got an overall subscription of 188.32 times. The bidding was led by the NII category, which subscribed the IPO 422.35 times.  QIB category saw bids of 172.93 times while the retails section was booked 96.81 times for Stallion India IPO.  Investors who have subscribed to Stallion India IPO can check their allotment status on the online portals of the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) and Bigshare Services Pvt Ltd, the registrar for the IPO.HOW TO CHECK ALLOTMENT FOR STALLION INDIA IPO Investors who have subscribed to Stallion India IPO can check their allotment status on the online portals of the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) and Bigshare Services Pvt Ltd, the registrar for the IPO. Steps to check allotment through the BSE website Go to the BSE website by clicking here. Click on 'Equity'. Choose ''Enviro Infra Engineers Limited" from the list. Put in your application number and PAN card ID. Confirm that you're not a robot and submit. Steps to check allotment through Bigshare Services Limited Visit the Bigshare Services Pvt Ltd website. Select the IPO from the dropdown menu (available once allotment is finalised). Choose one of three modes: Application number/CAF No., Beneficiary ID, or PAN ID. Enter the details based on your selected mode. Complete the captcha verification. Click "Search" to view your allotment statusLATEST GMP FOR STALLION INDIA IPO The grey market premium (GMP) for the IPO has gone up in the past few days, reflecting the strong investor interest.  Stallion India IPO commands a GMP of Rs 48 in the unofficial market as of the latest update, which translates to an expected listing gains of over 53%.  With its IPO price band of Rs 90, the expected listing price for Stallion India IPO is Rs 138 as of January 21, 07:29 AM.  The shares of Stallion India IPO are set to debut on the BSE and NSE, with the expected listing date scheduled for Thursday, January 23, 2025. Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Jan 21, 2025

Headline: Will Donald Trump's second term spark volatility on Dalal Street?US President Donald Trump on Monday said he would impose tariffs and taxes on "foreign countries" "to enrich" Americans.
Content: Donald Trump was sworn in as the 47th US President on January 20, and in his inauguration speech he made it very clear that he was going to follow the 'America first' policy which he has long advocated for.  US President Donald Trump on Monday said he would impose tariffs and taxes on "foreign countries" "to enrich" Americans and said he will create an "external revenue service" to collect "massive amounts" of duties and other revenues from foreign sources. Speaking at his inauguration, Trump said he would immediately begin overhauling the US's trade system to protect Americans. While he did not mention specific tariff plans in his inaugural address, experts believe that the beginning of Trump's second term may bring market volatility.  Vishnu Kant Upadhyay, AVP - Research & Advisory, Master Capital Services, said, "The market traded with a positive bias on Monday, ahead of Donald Trump’s inauguration ceremony on January 20th. Traders appear to be engaging in short-covering as significant volatility is anticipated on Tuesday." The Sensex and Nifty both gained to close higher in the last trading session, but Upadhyay expects the new US President to begin his term with multiple executive orders, inducing uncertainty in the stock markets.  "The newly elected US President is expected to sign multiple executive orders, which could introduce heightened volatility in the markets, prompting traders to adjust their positions," he said.  Upadhyay expects the market sentiment to remain cautious in the near future.  "Despite the positive undertone, overall sentiment remains cautious as the market continues to trade well below its crucial 200-day EMA, indicating underlying weakness. Any initial gains are likely to face resistance around the 23,500–23,550 zone. On the downside, the immediate support is placed at 23,050–23,000. A decisive move above 23,550 would provide some clarity and open the door for a potential rally toward the 24,000 mark," he added.  (Disclaimer: The views, opinions, recommendations, and suggestions expressed by experts/brokerages in this article are their own and do not reflect the views of the India Today Group. It is advisable to consult a qualified broker or financial advisor before making any actual investment or trading choices.)Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Jan 21, 2025Tune InMust Watch

Headline: Sensex, Nifty open higher as IT and FMCG stocks drive early tradeThe S&P BSE Sensex was up 98.36 points to 77,171.80, while the NSE Nifty50 added 69.20 points to 23,413.95 as of 9:30 AM.
Content: Benchmark stock market indices opened marginally higher on Tuesday, helped by a rise in information technology (IT), consumer goods (FMCG), and auto stocks in early trade.  The S&P BSE Sensex was up 98.36 points to 77,171.80, while the NSE Nifty50 added 69.20 points to 23,413.95 as of 9:30 AM.  Dr. V K Vijayakumar, Chief Investment Strategist, Geojit Financial Services said that Trump 2.0 has kicked off without much clarity on Trump’s likely economic decisions. "In his inaugural address he was clear on immigration but sounded vague on tariffs. The indication of a likely 25% tariffs on Canada and Mexico suggests that the tariff hike policy will be implemented gradually. The currency market has reacted with a cut in the dollar index to 108.43 and the 10-year bond yield has declined to 4.54%. This is the classic case of ‘buy on rumours and sell on news'," he added.  Bharat Petroleum Corporation Limited (BPCL) took the lead among gainers on Nifty50, jumping 3.37%, while Apollo Hospitals Enterprise followed with a rise of 2.86%. Tata Consumer Products climbed 1.71%, with JSW Steel adding 1.37%. UltraTech Cement completed the list of top gainers with a 1.22% increase. On the downside, Trent Limited saw the biggest drop, as it fell 1.61%, followed by Adani Enterprises which fell 1.51%. Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone dropped 1.32%, while Kotak Mahindra Bank dipped 0.91%. Reliance Industries rounded out the losers with a decline of 0.87% "It is likely that further delays in tariff hikes will weaken the dollar and bring down the bond yields. If this happens, it will be good for emerging markets like India. But if the FII flows to India are to turn positive consistently, we will have to see a pick -up in India’s GDP growth and corporate earnings. That’s the crucial macro data to watch," said Vijayakumar.  Most of the sectoral indices remained in red with only a handful managing to stay in the green with cautious sentiment. Nifty Healthcare Index led the positive momentum with a gain of 0.57%, while Nifty FMCG rose 0.42%. Nifty Midsmall Healthcare moved up by 0.29%, followed by Nifty IT which added 0.23%. Nifty Metal gained 0.16%, Nifty Auto increased by 0.15%, and Nifty Pharma ticked up 0.20%. Nifty Oil & Gas showed a marginal uptick of 0.08%. However, the decliners were led by Nifty Consumer Durables, which dropped significantly by 2.27%, while Nifty Realty fell 1.72%. Nifty Midsmall Services declined 1.18%, and Nifty PSU Bank decreased by 0.61%. The banking sector faced pressure with Nifty Bank falling 0.52%, Nifty Private Bank dropping 0.50%, and Nifty Financial Services sliding 0.47%. Nifty Midsmall IT & Telecom slipped 0.46%, while Nifty Media remained unchanged at 0.00%.Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Jan 21, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Sensex tumbles over 800 points. Is Trump 2.0 behind stock market bloodbath?Stock market crash: The S&P BSE Sensex was trading 800.18 points lower at 76,281 at 11:12 am, while the NSE Nifty50 dipped 200 points to 23,144.75.
Content:
Benchmark stock market indices fell sharply during Tuesday’s trading session after rising in early trade. The S&P BSE Sensex was trading 800.18 points lower at 76,281 at 11:12 am, while the NSE Nifty50 dipped 200 points to 23,144.75. All other broader market indices also declined sharply during the session, impacting smallcap and midcap stocks. Volatility also registered a sharp increase during the trading session.advertisementTRUMP TARIFFS DRIVE MARKET UNCERTAINTYDonald Trump has returned to the White House for his second term as US President. He signed a bunch of executive orders, but it was his remark on tariffs that seemed to have rattled global stock markets, including Dalal Street. Donald Trump has returned to the White House for his second term as US President. He signed a bunch of executive orders, but it was his remark on tariffs that seemed to have rattled global stock markets, including Dalal Street. He announced plans to announce trade tariffs on neighbouring countries just hours after taking office. Prashanth Tapse, Senior VP (Research), Mehta Equities Ltd, said Trump’s tariff decisions remain a wildcard despite no immediate announcement.  Dr. VK Vijayakumar, Chief Investment Strategist, Geojit Financial Services, added that Trump 2.0 has kicked off without much clarity on his likely economic decisions. "In his inaugural address, he was clear on immigration but sounded vague on tariffs. The indication of a likely 25% tariffs on Canada and Mexico suggests that the tariff hike policy will be implemented gradually," Vijayakumar said. "It is likely that further delays in tariff hikes will weaken the dollar and bring down the bond yields. If this happens, it will be good for emerging markets like India. But if the FII flows to India are to turn positive consistently, we will have to see a pickup in India’s GDP growth and corporate earnings," he explained. "That’s the crucial macro data to watch," he added.

Headline: Explained: Why Zomato shares are down 10% and what investors should doZomato shares were trading 9.42% lower at Rs 218.25 at 10:22 am. Shares of the food delivery giant had also declined in the previous session.
Content: Food delivery giant Zomato’s share price fell nearly 10% in early trade on Tuesday after reporting a sharp decline in net profit during the third quarter of FY25. Zomato shares were trading 9.42% lower at Rs 218.25 at 10:22 am. Shares of the food delivery giant had also declined in the previous session. The company’s net profit in Q3 FY25 declined to Rs 59 crore from Rs 138 crore in the same period a year ago. This marked a staggering 57.25% drop in net profit. While revenue from operations rose to Rs 5,405 crore, the overall growth was muted in the third quarter.WHAT SHOULD INVESTORS DO? Despite today’s sharp decline in Zomato’s share price, most brokerages remain optimistic about the company’s future performance. For instance, brokerage firm Nomura noted that Zomato faces a more challenging landscape but added that its quick-commerce division, Blinkit, is poised to secure a top-two spot in the immensely popular market. Jefferies, too, remains optimistic about Blinkit’s performance and is confident about the management’s goal to double Blinkit’s store count by 2,000 by December 2025. Despite this, the brokerage cut its target price on the stock to Rs 255, albeit retaining a ‘HOLD’ rating on the stock. Brokerage firm Bernstein retained an ‘OUTPERFORM’ rating on the Zomato stock, with a target price of Rs 310. It also highlighted that the recent correction in the stocks was due to rising competition in the quick commerce space. Nuvama Institutional Equities also stated that Blinkit’s dark store additions are outpacing expectations, leading to faster growth. "We believe this bunching up of cost for dark store addition shall hurt profitability in the short-term, but shall ultimately lead to bunching up of profitability in future quarters as these stores mature," Nuvama said. Nuvama has cut its target price on the stock to Rs 300, but it has retained its ‘BUY’ call. Among other brokerages, CLSA has a target price of Rs 400 on Zomato stock, while BofA Securities has kept it at Rs 375 and Nomura India has set it at Rs 290. Headline: Stocks to watch today: Tata Technologies, Waaree Renewable, Reliance PowerAmid all the news regarding Donald Trump's tariff threat, several stocks such as Tata Technologies, Waaree Renewable, L&T Finance, Reliance Power, Vedanta will be in the spotlight today.
Content: The stock markets started the week on a positive note with the Sensex ending Monday's session with a gain of over 400 points. However, experts have indicated that the market may see volatility with Donald Trump's return to the White House.  "The market traded with a positive bias on Monday, ahead of Donald Trump’s inauguration ceremony. Traders appear to be engaging in short-covering as significant volatility is anticipated on Tuesday. The newly elected US President is expected to sign multiple executive orders, which could introduce heightened volatility in the markets, prompting traders to adjust their positions," said Vishnu Kant Upadhyay, AVP - Research & Advisory, Master Capital Services.  Amid all the news regarding Donald Trump's tariff threat, several stocks such as Tata Technologies, Waaree Energies, L&T Finance, Reliance Power, Vedanta will be in the spotlight today.  In the earnings corner, investors will be keeping an eye on Tata Technologies, ICICI Prudential Life, and Indiamart as they get ready to share their Q3 FY25 financial results later in the day.  Vedanta - Fitch has upgraded their parent company's credit ratings, saying they're looking much better on the debt front. Waaree Renewable has landed a pretty substantial deal worth Rs 277.20 crore. They'll be building a huge ground-mounted solar project - we're talking about 105 MWp capacity. L&T Finance announced their Q3 results, making Rs 626 crore in net profits. Their net interest income hit Rs 2,041 crore, which shows they're doing well in their lending business. MCX has really turned things around, they've gone from losing Rs 5.4 crore last year to making Rs 160 crore this quarter, with revenue touching Rs 301 crore. Landmark's expanding their MG presence. They've got the green light to open new MG Select showrooms in Ahmedabad and Kolkata. Cipla's Goa unit (Medispray) got a Form 483 from the FDA with one observation. Over at Venus Remedies, they've managed to keep their European GMP certification, which is pretty crucial for their business. Dixon Technologies has posted good numbers with Rs 216 crore in profits and Rs 10,454 crore in revenue for Q3. In the telecom space, Vodafone Idea clarified they haven't heard anything official about those AGR dues waiver rumours that have been going around. Reliance Power's got a new boss. Neeraj Parakh is taking over as CEO for the next three years, starting January 20.Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Jan 21, 2025

Headline: 'Nobody can say...': Narayana Murthy on why 70-hour workweek isn't up for debateNarayana Murthy shared the time which he used to spend at his office and said, "I used to get to the office at 6:20 am and leave at 8:30 pm. I've done it for 40-odd years. That's a fact. So nobody can say that's wrong."
Content: Infosys co-founder Narayana Murthy cleared the air about his 70-hour workweek remark on Monday, saying that no one can forcefully implement it on others.  After stirring up a fierce debate on social media by suggesting young Indians should work 70 hours a week earlier last year, Narayana Murthy shared his take on the matter while speaking at IMC's Kilachand Memorial Lecture. "There's nobody who can say you should do this, you should not do it," the Infosys co-founder said.  He shared the time which he used to spend at his office during his years building Infosys and said, "I used to get to the office at 6:20 am and leave at 8:30 pm. I’ve done it for 40 odd years. That’s a fact. So nobody can say that's wrong."  He mentioned that these choices are personal and aren't really up for public debate. "These are not issues that should be discussed and debated. These are issues that one can introspect on, one can ingest, and one can come to some conclusion on and do whatever they want," said Murthy.  His clarification on the long working hours that have been a topic of national debate comes after Larsen & Toubro (L&T) Chairman SN Subrahmanyan sparked outrage with his comments in support of a 90-hour workweek. The comments from the L&T Chairman sparked reactions from India Inc's top leaders, with most criticising the comment.  Rajiv Bajaj, Managing Director of Bajaj Auto, said, “Let it start from the top, and if [it works] as a Proof of Concept, then implement it further down.” He called the practice of measuring work hours “archaic and regressive.” The second-richest man in India, billionaire industrialist Gautam Adani, also shared his views on work-life balance. In an interview, Adani said, “Your idea of work-life balance should not be imposed on me, and my work-life balance shouldn’t be imposed on you.”Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Jan 21, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Adar Poonawalla on 70-hour workweek: Humans can't be productive beyond 8-9 hoursThe CEO of Serum Institute mentioned that there's no substitute for hard work but the quality of work, and working strategically is of importance.
Content: Adar Poonawalla, the CEO of the Serum Institute of India said that human beings can not be productive after continuously working for 8-9 hours, sharing his views on the ongoing debate about the 70-hour workweek.  "A human being can't be productive beyond 8 or 9 hours. Sometimes you have to put in those hours. It's fine. I do it. My staff do it, but you can't do that every day," Poonawalla told Rahul Kanwal, News Director, India Today and Aajtak, on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum (WEF) 2025 in Davos.  He talked about the number of hours he works in a day and said, "I would say I work at least 8 hours a day, sometimes on weekends if it's needed, but there may be some days when, you know, I may be just on the slope skiing or doing something else. But, it all depends on the day." Sharing his thoughts on the need to work long hours in the office, he suggested that it is necessary to put in the hard yards when the situation demands it.   "I could have a 16-hour day. During covid, I was coming home at 11 PM at night. So it all depends on the journey and the stage that you're at. If you're an entrepreneur building your business, you absolutely should work hard, and do whatever it takes," Poonawalla said.  The CEO of Serum Institute mentioned that there's no substitute for hard work but the quality of work, and working strategically is of importance.  His recent comments come amid the ongoing debate over the work-life balance and 70-hour workweek talks.  Infosys co-founder Narayana Murthy cleared the air about his 70-hour workweek remark on Monday, saying that no one can forcefully implement it on others. After stirring up a fierce debate on social media by suggesting young Indians should work 70 hours a week earlier last year, Narayana Murthy issued a clarification while speaking at IMC's Kilachand Memorial Lecture. "There's nobody who can say you should do this, you should not do it," the Infosys co-founder said.Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Jan 21, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Explained: Why Paytm share price fell 7% today and what's nextThe drop in Paytm's share price came after the company reported its Q3FY25 results. Read to find out how brokerages rated Paytm's Q3 results and how the company's stock will perform in future.
Content: Shares of One97 Communication Limited (OCL), the parent firm of digital payments firm Paytm, fell as much as 7% on Tuesday. The drop in Paytm's share price came after the company reported its Q3FY25 results, following which analysts have said the company missed its Q3 contribution margin due to higher loan guarantee (DLG) costs. Analysts, however, acknowledged that the fintech company has seen an improvement in its business metrics in the third quarter, citing steady increase in gross merchandise value (GMV) and loan disbursements. In a note, JM Financial said it expects the impact of DLG cost to normalise with the contribution margin reverting back to 55% (excluding UPI incentives) and the company reporting PAT profitability next quarter, thanks to UPI incentives worth Rs 350 crore. “We reiterate our BUY rating with March 2026 target price of Rs 1,250, valuing Paytm at 70x FY27E PER,” said the note. Motilal Oswal Financial Services maintained its contribution profit estimates for FY25/FY26 and estimate it to turn EBITDA positive by FY27. “We value Paytm at Rs 950, based on 18 times FY30 Ebitda discounted to FY26E, which corresponds to 6.1 times FY26E sales," said the brokerage firm, while maintaining its ‘NEUTRAL’ rating on the stock. Analysts at Yes Securities also exuded confidence about Paytm’s EBITDA breakeven plans. It has kept its ‘ADD’ rating on the stock with a revised target price of Rs 1,050. Emkay Global, which recently upgraded that Paytm stock to ‘BUY’ with a target price of Rs 1,050, also shared optimistic views about future growth. It said factors like strong merchant payment/lending business, improving MTU and other factors “should put” Paytm on an early path to profitability in FY26E. At 1:15 pm, Paytm shares were trading 4.30% lower at Rs 859.20 on the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE). Headline: Donald Trump's uncertain tariff plan keeps Dalal Street on edge. 3 key takeawaysUS President Donald Trump has decided not to immediately implement tariffs, leading to uncertainty among market investors around the world, including Dalal Street.
Content: Benchmark stock market indices have been buzzing since early morning, with volatility sending the Sensex and Nifty50 swinging between gains and losses. One moment, the Sensex was up nearly 200 points, and the next instance, it was down 800 points.  At the time of writing this article, the 30-share Sensex was down nearly 500 points and the 50-share Nifty was trading 100 points lower. The India VIX or volatility index, which is a measure of the market's expectation of volatility over the near term, was up 4%, reflecting the edgy mood on Dalal Street. This comes after Donald Trump returned to the White House for his second term as US President. While Trump did sign several executive orders, he did not implement any immediate tariffs, keeping global markets guessing about his next move. Here are three things investors should know:UNCLEAR TARIFF PLANS Donald Trump had earlier hinted at imposing tariffs of up to 25% on goods from Canada and Mexico and 10% on Chinese imports. However, no immediate action was taken, leaving markets guessing. The lack of specifics has created uncertainty for global trade and investors, suggested Justin Khoo, Senior Market Analyst - APAC, VT Markets.ASIAN MARKETS FEEL THE HEAT Khoo said as a result of this inconclusive policy stance, Asian markets were mixed, with China, South Korea and India witnessing declines. “This lack of definitive action on tariffs spurred caution among investors, who remain vigilant for further announcements that might reshape global trade,” he added.FUTURE TARIFF SCARE While Khoo suggested that broad-based, day-one tariffs appeared unlikely from the outset, the possibility of more selective, near-term import levies remains open. And this seems to have spooked investors around the globe. Moreover, Khoo added that the US President could even go forward and impose a global tariff early in his administration. This could significantly shake up global trade. “Historically, similar tariff threats have triggered volatility in Asian markets. In 2018, for instance, US tariffs on steel and aluminum prompted a wave of uncertainty, leading to short-term declines before gradual recoveries as investors adjusted to the new environment,” Khoo said. “Consequently, while current fluctuations may persist, Asian markets have historically demonstrated resilience, and the ultimate impact will hinge on the scope and timing of any upcoming US trade measures,” he added. Headline: Sensex crashes as Trump 2.0 spooks D-Street investors. 3 things to knowStock market crash: The Sensex tumbled 1,300 points to 75,773 at around 2:45 pm, while the Nifty50 fell below 23,000. All other broader market indices also collapsed during the trading session.
Content: A volatile session on Dalal Street turned into a nightmare for stock market investors as the benchmark indices crashed after swinging between gains and losses for most of the session. The Sensex tumbled 1,300 points to 75,773 at around 2:45 pm, while the Nifty50 fell below 23,000. All other broader market indices also collapsed during the trading session. The main reason behind the stock market crash was uncertainty over US President Donald Trump's tariff plan after he returned to the White House for his second term.  Here are all the factors that led to today's bloodbath on Dalal Street: TRUMP TARIFF UNCERTAINTY As mentioned earlier, the uncertainty over Donald Trump's tariff plan triggered panic among investors. In an earlier article, we explained how the unprdictability of tariff plans has led to higher volatility on Dalal Street. HEAVYWEIGHT STOCKS DECLINE Major stocks across several sectors fell sharply during the trading session, leading to today's downturn. Zomato was on course to register an 11% decline and was the top loser on the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE). Other heavyweight stocks such as ICICI Bank, HDFC Bank, Reliance and SBI also tumbled sharply during the session, leading to the stock market slump. Q3 RESULTS FAILS TO IMPRESS A majority of companies that have reported their Q3 results have either failed to meet expectations or barely scraped through. Only a handful of companies have managed to defy expectations. And a Bloomberg consensus estimate has indicated that the earnings per share (EPS) of Nifty50 companies may grow by just 3% year-on-year in the third quarter. Only the capital goods, healthcare and telecom sectors are likely to register double-digit profit growth. VOLATILITY SKYROCKETS Volatility also spiked during the session due to the prevailing sentiments among Dalal Street investors. Investors remain worried about the impact of Trump's delayed tariff announcements, which could lead to a prolonged period of uncertainty for them. Had Trump executed his tariff plans, it could have provided clarity to investors on which sectors will be hit. However, experts said that the ambiguity surrounding Trump's tariff plan will force investors to "wait and watch" for a longer period and this could lead to a longer period of volatility on Dalal Street. FII SELLING CONTINUES The above factors have just made the situation worse on Dalal Street, given that it is already facing an exodus of foreign institutional investors (FIIs). As of January 20, FIIs have pulled out equity holdings worth over Rs 48,000 crore. In an uncertain market, FII selling could intensify and hit domestic stock market investors harder. It is advisable to consult a qualified broker or financial advisor before making any actual investment or trading choices.)Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Jan 21, 2025Must Watch

Headline: India could afford to cut back...: IMF's Gita Gopinath on Trump tariff threatGita Gopinath said that India's focus should be on domestic reforms rather than tariff battles as it looks to become a global hub for manufacturing.
Content: International Monetary Fund's (IMF) first deputy Managing Director (MD) Gita Gopinath suggested that India should consider reducing its tariffs not just to address the tariff threat by US President Donald Trump, but also for its own economic benefits.  "India could afford to cut back on some of its tariffs just for its own sake because this is an important opportunity for India to plug itself into global supply chains," Gopinath told Rahul Kanwal, News Director, India Today and Aajtak, on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum (WEF) 2025 in Davos She also said that India remains an attractive destination for businesses but needs to address the tariff issue.  "The US is going to have bilateral negotiations with all their trading partners, to address what they feel are unfair trade practices," she said. She said that India's focus should be on domestic reforms rather than tariff battles as it looks to become a global hub for manufacturing.  "In terms of what prevents people from going into India, it is about still the ease of doing business, the infrastructure, the ability to buy land or sell land, contract enforcement," she said. On India's growth outlook, Gopinath maintained an optimistic view despite recent slowdowns. The IMF projects India's growth at 6.5% for the fiscal year, which she believes represents the country's current potential growth rate. "For the fiscal year as a whole, our growth number is 6.5%. So we do expect to see a recovery. But first, potential growth is also at 6.5%. So again, this comes back to if you want to be able to raise potential growth by a lot more, you're going to have to do the soft reforms," she said. Gopinath called the slowdown in growth "temporary," attributed largely to delays in public infrastructure project implementation. She mentioned the importance of continuing public infrastructure investment, particularly at the state level, while maintaining macro stability.Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Jan 21, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Sensex, Nifty crash: Bears dominate amid Trump's tariff threat; Zomato down 11%The S&P BSE Sensex plunged 1235.08 points to close at 75,838.36, while the NSE Nifty50 was down 320.10 points to end at 23,024.65.
Content: Benchmark stock market indices tanked in a see-saw day of trading with 'Trump's tariff threat' making for high volatility as uncertainty prevailed in the market.  The S&P BSE Sensex plunged 1235.08 points to close at 75,838.36, while the NSE Nifty50 was down 320.10 points to end at 23,024.65.  The major trigger behind the stock market crash was uncertainty over US President Donald Trump's tariff plan after he was sworn in as the 47th US President for his second term. Aditya Gaggar, Director of Progressive Shares, said that the market experienced significant volatility today, with bears taking control of the trade. "The Mid and Smallcap sectors saw a sharp decline, pulling the Index lower, though a brief V-shaped recovery occurred. All sectors closed in the red, with Realty and Energy being the primary underperformers. The Mid and Smallcap indices fell more than 2%, underperforming the benchmark," he added.  Selling pressure was broad-based, with sectors like realty, energy, and auto leading the losses. The broader indices also came under pressure, each shedding over 2%. "Persistent selling by FIIs and a lackluster start to the earnings season are key factors dampening market sentiment. Additionally, the recent uptick in the volatility index, India VIX, is contributing to the prevailing cautious outlook," said Ajit Mishra – SVP, Research, Religare Broking Ltd.  The Nifty Mid Select Index closed the latest session at 12,062.20, with a decline of 2.38%, whereas the Nifty Private Bank Index ended at 23,680.05 after declining by 1.49%. Nifty PSU Bank Index nosedived by 1.57%, suggesting a sense of caution in the broader market. "Unless the Nifty index jumps past 23,472, the bearish sentiment is likely to prevail, especially as we approach the budget session. On the daily technical charts, Nifty reflected a cautious temperament, underscoring the bearish sentiment. In this situation, a sell-on-rise approach could be more favourable as this volatile market is not ripe for a buy-on-dip strategy. Considering these aspects, Nifty could gain support between 23,090 and 23,000 and meet resistance between 23,310 and 23,380 in the next market session," said VLA Ambala, Co-Founder of Stock Market Today. Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Jan 21, 2025Must Watch

Headline: IMF's Gita Gopinath on Trump tariffs, impact on global growth, AI and moreDuring the interview, Gita Gopinath discussed the potential impact of US President Donald Trump's plan to impose new trade tariffs, global growth, bilateral trade between India and America, cryptocurrency and more.
Content:
International Monetary Fund's (IMF) First Deputy Managing Director Gita Gopinath shared exclusive insights about a diverse range of topics while speaking to India Today and Aajtak News Director Rahul Kanwal on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. During the interview, Gopinath discussed the potential impact of US President Donald Trump’s plan to impose trade tariffs on some countries, global growth, bilateral trade between India and America, cryptocurrency and more. Below is the full text of her interview with Rahul Kanwal:IMPACT OF DONALD TRUMP’S PLANNED TRADE TARIFFS Rahul Kanwal: I want to start by asking you about what you're making of American President Donald Trump's determination to impose new trade tariffs. From the IMF's lens and from your own personal point of view, how do you see that pan out in actuality, belligerence versus reality? Gita Gopinath: You know, President Trump said he would hit the ground running, and he has done that, and he's announced a lot of measures. He's been more concrete on immigration and on energy, on tariffs on trade policy more generally. He has, you know, pointed to intent, but we have yet to see what exactly he will do. The reason I'm saying that is because if you look at the tariffs that were done in 2018-19, The details didn't matter in terms of what products you put your tariffs on. That's going to determine how much of an inflationary effect it will have. How countries retaliate, that was absolutely critical for what the consequences were going to be. But, you know, in general, what we have seen based on historical evidence is that if we end up in a place where there are lots of tit-for-tat tariffs that happen, then that's a net negative for the world as a whole.IMPACT OF POTENTIAL TARIFFS ON GLOBAL GROWTH Rahul Kanwal: So how much of an impact do you think this could have on global growth? It will of course determine, as you say, it will be determined by what tariffs he imposes, what countermeasures the other countries employ. But how do you see this impact global growth? Because the latest IMF forecast seems to suggest global growth slowing down on its own even before these tariffs have come into place. Gita Gopinath: So, in addition to knowing what the details are on the tariffs, there are lots of other policies that are being announced by the US government. So, for example, which they plan to do, which is to make the tax cuts permanent to have more financial deregulation. There is a lot of positive sentiment. Foreign direct investment into the US is very strong at this point. So, all of that can have an offsetting effect. So, in fact, our near-term assessment is that there are more upside risks to the US economy. Now, what that usually means is that if there's more growth in the US economy, it does have spillovers to the rest of the world, and that can be positive, too. While many of the other policies on the trade front and so on will be more of a downside risk for the rest of the world. What I'm trying to say is that it's not just about trade and tariff policy, but there's a lot that's happening on taxes, a lot that's happening on immigration, on energy, and so on. We have to look at the sum total to be able to say what will happen to global growth.SHOULD INDIA CUT BACK ON TARIFFS? Rahul Kanwal: President Trump has called India a tariff king and threatened taxes, tariffs against India as well. How do you see that impact the India-America bilateral trade and India's growth and India's desire to build its own economy at this time? Gita Gopinath: This is going to be an environment where the US is going to have bilateral negotiations with all their trading partners to address what they feel are unfair trade practices that the fact that they get, their products get imposed higher tariffs than what the US imposes on products coming out of other countries. And so, you know, there is a valid point of whether this is a level playing field or not and, therefore, I think countries will have to negotiate this. As you know, and I've said this before to you too, I mean, our view at the IMF is that India could afford to cut back on some of its tariffs just for its own sake because this is an opportunity for India to plug itself into global supply chains. Everybody is looking to diversify and I hear from almost everyone that India is a very attractive destination. But to be able to go in, you will need somewhat lower tariffs in India too. So that will help India directly. Again, but like I said, every country is going to be negotiating this.HOW CAN INDIA ATTRACT MORE INVESTMENTS? Rahul Kanwal: There are two trends playing out simultaneously. One, India trying to attract some of the China plus one investment into the 'Make in India' story. The other, Donald Trump determined to get companies to invest and manufacture in the United States. To what extent could that mar India's chances? You're saying reduce tariffs, plug into global supply chains, but you've also got America determined to pull manufacturing into mainland United States. Gita Gopinath: Well, the US is actually quite successful now in being able to attract investment into the US. So, if you look at foreign direct investment around the world, the US is an incredibly attractive destination. It's taking a bigger and bigger share of foreign direct investment flows. I think the best thing for India to do to offset some of that is actually to focus on the domestic reforms. In terms of what prevents people from going into India, it is still about ease of doing business, the infrastructure, the ability to buy land or sell land, contract enforcement. Those are the kinds of aspects that are more of a constraining factor. So, the more India can do in terms of structural reforms at home, and it's done a lot, not to deny that, it's done quite a bit, especially in terms of public infrastructure, it's done a lot, and to keep that momentum going, that will be what will change the story for India.advertisementWHAT SHOULD BUDGET 2025 FOCUS ON? Rahul Kanwal: You're talking about the need for the Indian government to usher in a new range of reforms. You've got a big budget coming up and this is one year when there are just two elections in the states and they're very far spread out. So it's an actual opportunity to push some reform through. On economic policy, what are the key reforms you and the IMF are looking out for from India?Gita Gopinath: So, I think firstly, it is important to continue on the path of public infrastructure investment. And implementation needs to be timely.This is just at the central government level, but I'm talking at the state government level. There is still a big need for that, and so pushing more on that front is going to be important.It's also important to keep India's macro stability. And it's done very well in terms of inflation and what the RBI has done in terms of managing inflation. It's done a really great job. On the fiscal front, of course, India's debt levels are high.It's not an imminent concern. But that's something in terms of the budget to determine what you can do, because you need to be able to raise some revenues too while you undertake the spending. You know, making sure that it's done in a growth-friendly manner is going to be important.WHAT’S BEHIND INDIA’S GROWTH SLOWDOWN? Rahul Kanwal: India has seen a slowdown in economic growth in the second quarter of this financial year, with growth slowing to 5.2%. Overall, annual growth forecasts are down as well. Now there's a big debate raging over whether this is a temporary slowdown caused by the elections, by the pullback in capex by the government, or is this more cyclical? How do you come out of this debate?Gita Gopinath: So, the 5.2% we see as a temporary thing. That reflects the fact that there have been some delays in implementing some of the public infrastructure projects.But we see that picking up. And we do continuously see strength in rural consumption. I remember last time we talked about that. For the fiscal year as a whole, our growth number is 6.5%. We do expect to see a recovery. But for us, potential growth is also at 6.5%. Again, this comes back to if you want to be able to raise potential growth by a lot more, you're going to have to do this over the fall.Rahul Kanwal: So you've reduced what you think is India's potential growth in the medium term to about the mid-6%, right?Gita Gopinath: 6.5%. Yeah, but I mean, I don't think we've been that far off from 6.5%.NEED FOR GLOBAL CRYTO FRAMEWORKRahul Kanwal: Talking about cryptocurrency, I remember speaking with you last time, and you generally weren't very bullish on cryptocurrency. Now you've got the President of the United States who's highly bullish himself. Does that change your perspective on how you're viewing cryptocurrencies and the stability and the future of this asset?Gita Gopinath: The way we've always viewed it is that crypto has both risks and opportunities. There is a technology that's underlying it in terms of distributed ledger technology that many companies are actually using for other purposes, like for their payment platforms, for having more security in their contracts.That is all extremely welcome. And that's why innovation is good. There are many faces of innovation, and this is all fine.But at the same time, there are risks. And therefore, we do think countries around the world need a solid crypto-policy framework that protects consumers, that prevents your financial stability risks from building up. You can have both, and you have to hit the sweet spot there.IS THERE A NEED TO REGULATE AI? Rahul Kanwal: Speaking of regulation, there's a need for regulation on artificial intelligence as well. Do you see anything at all which leads the world towards having some kind of a common governance architecture? Or will it just be the case of development and use cases running far faster than any governance around?Gita Gopinath: First of all, for AI, it's much more than just regulation. There are issues about what governments do in case AI ends up with a lot of people losing their jobs.How do you also get innovation going? What kinds of policies will encourage innovation? So it's not just about the regulation aspect, but there are multiple aspects.Rahul Kanwal: So let's break it down one by one. You spoke about the potential impact of artificial intelligence on jobs. I was just in a conversation at the World Economic Forum on Industries in the Intelligent Age. And the argument being made by chief executives is that the impact on jobs isn't as severe as was being made out initially. How do you view this? How bad or how much of an impact will artificial intelligence have on jobs, particularly in India?Gita Gopinath: I think we haven't seen the first of it at this point. It's still early days. So we're still in the realm of the hypothetical and the theoretical at this point based on some estimates that one can do.Rahul Kanwal: What are your estimates?Gita Gopinath: Our estimate is for the world as a whole, 40% of jobs are exposed to AI. But at about half of that, 20% will benefit from AI and 20% will be displaced. But there's a wide variation. So advanced economies are at 60% exposure. India is at 26% exposure. So there's a lot of variation over here. We'll see what happens in terms of the labour market.I think a good thing to remember from past history is that when you actually see the impact of automation on the job market is the first year of a recession. So, you don't see it in normal times. You don't see it in good times.When you have a recession...and then in that first year, that's when 90% of automation-related job losses happen. So, I don't think we should be sanguine at this point. We should be careful what may come in the future.What governments can do for us is to make sure that they're only benefiting from AI side. That requires digital public infrastructure, scaling, making sure your population can actually use AI. Otherwise, they will be on the losing end.Rahul Kanwal: So, let's spend some time talking about that because India seems to have taken on the mantle of being the use case capital of the world. Instead of focusing on building large language models of its own, it is attempting to do that, but really trying to implement artificial intelligence and its capabilities. Do you think that's the right approach? How would you, because you're also of Indian origin, how would you think a country and an economy like India should really be approaching artificial intelligence?Gita Gopinath: I think that's a good place for India to be. It does not necessarily have to be in the foundational models producing side. There are a ton that can be done in terms of application and especially for a country like India, even in education and healthcare space, these applications can be very helpful and they have to be tailored to country circumstances, which is why the industry has an advantage in doing that.But I mean the bottom line is as long as you have the right environment for companies to innovate, venture capital is going to be very important, the right level of skilled labor is going to be very important, education is going to be very important, creating that ecosystem.INDIA-CHINA EQUATIONRahul Kanwal: How strong a pushback do you see from China on some of the trade measures that the United States may implement and how should India be navigating its dealing with the Chinese economy just at this moment because after a lot of deadlock along the line of actual control, there's ultimately now a bit of a thaw and the question is at what speed do you accelerate that?Gita Gopinath: Countries for their own selfish interests benefit from cooperating, and therefore, I expect all countries are going to sit across the table and negotiate what they think is good for their countries and by the way, cooperation as I said has been good for the world and for everybody individually.So we'll see how this plays out. I mean the last time China did retaliate was the US.We'll see what happens. It's too early to speculate.Rahul Kanwal: But do you see the fragmentation of the global economy, the division into two camps, that trend accentuate or do you think they're more likely to find ways of being able to navigate these divisions?Gita Gopinath: We are already seeing signs of...what we call geoeconomic fragmentation, which is when you look at trade, it is much more stronger between countries that are more geopolitically aligned. Geopolitical alliance is becoming a bigger factor in explaining who trades with whom, who invests in which country.So we're already seeing the seeds of that. And I expect that's going to continue.Now, unlike, you know, 50 years ago, when so-called non-aligned countries were a very small share of world GDP, they're much stronger now, India, Mexico, all of them are much bigger economies, and they can play a much bigger role in terms of being a bigger part of the global supply chain and seeing how trade gets rerouted.Rahul Kanwal: So do you see a fragmentation in the medium term of the world into two trading blocks?Gita Gopinath: I don't think I would point to a very stark break in terms of completely fragmented world, but we certainly have drifted away from the strong rules-based multilateral trading system that we've been used to for a couple of decades.WHAT SKILLS SHOULD YOUNGSTERS DEVELOP?Rahul Kanwal: Before I end, I want you to speak to young people who are watching you at this moment and wondering what kind of skills should they be developing to be able to navigate, succeed, and survive in a world dominated by artificial intelligence where machines are much smarter than men. How should they be preparing for the job market given the realities that face them?Gita Gopinath: Well, I mean, firstly, I still believe that STEM will be important. I don't think machines are going to completely take over all aspects of STEM. So, STEM will remain important.But also, just in terms of investing in creativity, in terms of investing in teamwork, in terms of, you know, thinking at a much higher level as opposed to in terms of the minutiae. I think all of that, building those skills is going to be important.SHOULD US REVISIT IMMIGRATION POLICY?Rahul Kanwal: There's a big debate raging over immigration. You know, ultimately it seemed that Donald Trump came out on the side of Elon Musk on the issue of H-1B visas. But do you see this argument impacting skilled labor wanting to move to a country like the United States or not really? That the pull is just too much and it won't impact who comes and who doesn't?Gita Gopinath: For many countries, including the US, there is certainly a need to revisit immigration policy. It has created a lot of stress in the US. And so it's not unusual to see that they are thinking of how to change the system. And, you know, we remain of the view that skilled labour is critical for economies in the world. And if you can get the best talent from other parts of the world, you should attract that into your economy.Rahul Kanwal: The American president talks about taking over Greenland. Canada is becoming the 51st state and talking about taking over the Panama Canal. How do you see that potentially play out in the months to come?Gita Gopinath: Well, that's not something I can talk about. I think we stay out of those kinds of issues. We'll see what, if any, economic impact that could have.Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Jan 21, 2025Must Watch
