Headline: A decade of budget evolution under ModiCoalition dynamics could influence future budgetary decisions, particularly in the welfare sector. Will the government maintain its current priorities?
Content: The Union Budget for 2025-26 will be an interesting exercise for the ruling BJP. The saffron party now has to contend with influential coalition partners trying to push their agendas — a problem it has not faced in the last decade. Will this affect the Centre’s fiscal priorities? To get a clearer picture, India Today’s Data Intelligence Unit analysed ministry-wise budget allocations over the last decade.  As per the budget allocation for 2024-25, the Finance Ministry continues to dominate the budget, with a 38.6 per cent share in FY25, a slight increase from 37.3 per cent in FY20 and 36.7 per cent in FY15. The Defence Ministry secured the second spot, but its budget share declined from 17.1 per cent in FY15 to 12.9 per cent in FY25. However, in absolute terms, its allocation more than doubled, rising from Rs 2.8 lakh crore in FY15 to Rs 6.2 lakh crore in FY25. Infrastructure ministries saw the most remarkable growth in budget allocations, reflecting the government’s emphasis on development and connectivity. Road Transport and Highways climbed from rank nine in FY15 to rank three in FY25 in terms of money allocation. Its budget share rose from two to six per cent, but allocations increased from Rs 0.3 lakh crore to Rs 2.8 lakh crore over the same period. Railways experienced extraordinary growth, moving from rank 11 in FY15 to rank four in FY25. Its share rose from 1.8 to 5.3 per cent, while its allocation skyrocketed by 748 per cent, from Rs 0.3 lakh crore in FY15 to Rs 2.5 lakh crore in FY25. The Ministry of Consumer Affairs, Food, and Public Distribution dropped from rank three in FY15 to rank five in FY25. Its share declined from 7.11 per cent in FY15 to 4.63 per cent in FY25, but allocations grew significantly from Rs 1.2 lakh crore to Rs 2.2 lakh crore.   Similarly, the Ministry of Rural Development slipped from rank five in FY15 to rank sixth in FY25, its budget share falling from 4.2 per cent to 3.7 per cent. However, its allocation nearly doubled, from Rs 0.6 lakh crore in FY15 to Rs 1.8 lakh crore in FY25, indicating sustained rural investment. The Agriculture Ministry saw a major boost, with allocations increasing from Rs 0.2 lakh crore in FY15 to Rs 1.3 lakh crore in FY25, a 450 per cent jump. The Communications Ministry emerged as a rising star, climbing from rank 15 in FY15 to rank ninth in FY25. Its share grew from one per cent to 2.8 per cent, as allocations increased from Rs 0.2 lakh crore to Rs 1.2 lakh crore. On the other hand, some ministries saw slower growth, like the Ministry of Chemicals and Fertilisers dropped from four per cent in FY15 to three per cent in FY25, though its allocation rose modestly from Rs 0.7 lakh crore to Rs 1.6 lakh crore.  These are the ministries where the Narendra Modi government spent more than 80 per cent of the budget in FY25 and the analysis shows a clear shift in the government’s priorities over the decade, with an increased focus on infrastructure, digital connectivity, and national security. Welfare sectors like consumer affairs and rural development still receive significant funding but are no longer at the forefront. Coalition dynamics could influence future budgetary decisions, particularly in the welfare sector. Will the government maintain its current priorities, or will it realign to accommodate partners? Only time will tell.Published By: Pathikrit SanyalPublished On: Jan 21, 2025Tune InREAD |  What to expect from Budget 2025: Growth, taxes, and fiscal realities in numbersMust Watch

Headline: What to expect from Budget 2025: Growth, taxes, and fiscal realities in numbersFY25's deficit is projected at 4.9 per cent of the GDP, or Rs 16.1 trillion. Despite slower economic growth, the government is expected to stick to its fiscal discipline plan.
Content: India’s Finance Minister, Nirmala Sitharaman, faces a challenging task as she delivers her eighth Budget speech on February 1. Amid slowing economic growth, sticky inflation, and tepid private investment, the government must boost consumption and infrastructure spending while keeping the fiscal deficit in check. The balancing act hinges on the state of public finances.A NEW CHAPTER FOR INCOME TAX Simplifying India’s six-decade-old income tax law will likely be a headline measure. Weak consumption and inflation have dampened demand, with private investment stuck in wait-and-watch mode. Tax relief may help break this stalemate. The government set a January 2025 deadline to overhaul the Income Tax Act 1961, aiming to reduce disputes and litigation while improving clarity. It was announced by Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman in her July 2024 budget speech: “I am now announcing a comprehensive review of the Income-tax Act,1961. The purpose is to make the act concise, lucid, and easy to read and understand. This will reduce disputes and litigation, thereby providing tax certainty to taxpayers. It will also bring down the demand embroiled in litigation. It is proposed to be completed in six months.” FISCAL DEFICIT: A RIGHTROPE Fiscal deficits occur when government spending exceeds income. While necessary during crises, sustained high deficits pose economic stability risks, especially with elevated debt levels. The fiscal consolidation roadmap, announced in the FY22 budget, aims to reduce the fiscal deficit to 4.5 per cent of the GDP by FY27. FY25's deficit is projected at 4.9 per cent of the GDP, or Rs 16.1 trillion. Despite slower economic growth, the government is expected to stick to its fiscal discipline plan. “Notwithstanding the growth slowdown in FY25 and the likely minor growth improvement in FY26, the government will adhere to its fiscal consolidation roadmap provided in the medium-term fiscal policy-cum-fiscal strategy statement with the FY25 budget and peg the FY26 fiscal deficit at 4.5 per cent,” says Devendra Kumar Pant, chief economist and head of public finance at Ind-Ra, a rating agency. DIRECT TAXES LEAD Direct taxes have outpaced indirect taxes since FY22, reflecting a shift in revenue sources. In FY25, direct taxes accounted for 57.5 per cent of gross tax revenue, up from 52 per cent in FY22. However, indirect taxes, primarily governed by the GST Council, no longer see significant changes in the Union Budget, except for import duties. SPENDING AND REVENUE India’s revenue-to-GDP ratio has fluctuated modestly over 30 years, peaking at 12.5 per cent in 2004 before falling to 8.5 per cent in 2021 during the pandemic. Spending, meanwhile, has shown more variability, averaging 14-16 per cent of the GDP. The fiscal gap has narrowed, with FY25 revenue projected at 9.8 per cent of the GDP and spending at 14.8 per cent. CAPITAL SPENDING Capital spending is critical for growth but faces hurdles. It is projected at 23.05 per cent of the total budget or 3.4 per cent of the GDP in FY25, with Railways, Road Transport, and Defence accounting for almost two-thirds of the total. Election-related spending slowed investment early in FY25, causing a 12.3 per cent drop in project spending over the first eight months. Meeting the year’s target will require a staggering 64.7 per cent growth in spending over the next four months. CLOSING GAPS This year’s budget must address weak growth, inflation, and external developments such as Donald Trump’s return as president of the US — a country that consumes a fifth of India’s exports and is a major source of fund inflows. With GDP growth expected to slow to 6.4 per cent, the weakest since the pandemic, fiscal consolidation limits the government’s flexibility to bolster social and economic priorities. Sitharaman’s ability to navigate these challenges will define Budget 2025 and set the tone for India’s economic trajectory.Published By: Pathikrit SanyalPublished On: Jan 21, 2025Tune InREAD |  2024's climate chaos: Why Budget 2025 must prioritise climate actionMust Watch

Headline: Concern for world, won't benefit US much: Ex-RBI Governor on Trump tariff threatSpeaking to India Today TV, former RBI Governor Raghuram Rajan warned that US President Donald Trump's tariff plans could harm global economic stability, increase costs, and deter foreign investment.
Content:
Former Reserve Bank of India (RBI) Governor Raghuram Rajan on Tuesday expressed strong concerns over newly-appointed US President Donald Trump's proposed tariff hikes. Rajan described the tariff hike plans as a "big source of uncertainty" that could disrupt global economic stability. "I think Trump's tariff hike threats are a big source of uncertainty and a potential source of disruption for the rest of the world. For the US, I don't think they will be as beneficial as the administration believes. Partly because goods are made outside the US for a reason — it is cheaper to make them outside," Raghuram Rajan said while speaking to Rahul Kanwal, News Director, India Today, on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum (WEF) 2025 in Davos. 

What could be the real impact of Donald Trump's tariff measures? Former RBI Governor Raghuram Rajan explains#EXCLUSIVE #ITVideo #Davos #IndiaTodayAtDavos #Newstrack #DonaldTrump | @rahulkanwal pic.twitter.com/b3AIhBL1XB
— IndiaToday (@IndiaToday) January 21, 2025
 What could be the real impact of Donald Trump's tariff measures? Former RBI Governor Raghuram Rajan explains#EXCLUSIVE #ITVideo #Davos #IndiaTodayAtDavos #Newstrack #DonaldTrump | @rahulkanwal pic.twitter.com/b3AIhBL1XB
— IndiaToday (@IndiaToday) January 21, 2025 "Trying to bring them back into the US by putting up tariffs typically doesn't work," the former RBI Governor asserted.  Explaining the impact of the tariff hike on the US, Raghuram Rajan cited examples of bigger economies like China and how they import goods from small countries like Vietnam to reduce manufacturing costs.  "Trying to bring those goods back into the US by imposing tariffs usually doesn’t work as intended. If possible, production will simply move to another location. For example, what was being manufactured in China is now shifted to Vietnam," Rajan said.  "If universal tariffs are implemented, they may prevent imports from other countries, but that would force production to occur in the US at a much higher cost. There's a reason why China is doing it — it's cost-effective," he added.  Further in his conversation, Rajan also pointed out the uncertainty in foreign investments if tariffs will change overnight.  "There would be great uncertainty about where to invest if tariffs could change overnight. Not just the US, remember there would be retaliatory tariffs as well. I believe that the President has in mind three benefits — it will even the playing field, it will be a source of revenue and a source of jobs," he added.  Soon after taking the oath of office, Trump, the 47th President of the United States, reiterated that he would impose 100 per cent import tariffs on the Brics nations, which also includes India, in case they took any steps towards cutting the use of the dollar in global trade.Published By: Sahil SinhaPublished On: Jan 21, 2025

Headline: Ex-RBI Governor Raghuram Rajan speaks on Trump's tariffs, job creation and othersFormer RBI Governor Raghuram Rajan highlighted his views on issues like US President Donald Trump's plans to impose tariffs on some countries, including India, and how the economy and job creation is progressing under the Narendra Modi-led central government.
Content:
Former RBI Governor Raghuram Rajan sat down with India Today News Director Rahul Kanwal on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum in Switzerland's Davos and touched upon various issues including US President Donald Trump's tariff threats, creation of jobs and the current investment climate in India. During the interview, Rajan highlighted his views on Trump's plans to impose tariffs on some countries, including India, how the economy and job creation is progressing under the Narendra Modi-led central government and the rupee vs dollar situation. Here are the full excerpts of the interview:ON TRUMP'S TARIFF IMPACT ON INDIA Rahul Kanwal: What is the real impact you think Donald Trump's tariff measures could have on the global economy and most importantly, on India's growth? Raghuram Rajan: Well, I think they are a big source of uncertainty and a potential source of disruption for the rest of the world. For the US, I don't think they'll be as beneficial as the administration thinks, partly because, you know, goods are made outside the US for a reason. It's cheaper to make it outside. Trying to bring them back into the US by putting up tariffs, typically if they could, they'd go somewhere else. You know, what was being made in China will go to Vietnam. If you're going to put universal tariffs, maybe you could stop them from coming in from elsewhere, but they have to be made in the US at a much higher cost, because there's a reason China made it. I think the higher costs, the fact that the rest of the world is disrupted, and their economies, which are already weaker than the US for the most part, weakened even further.Of course, the great uncertainty about where you invest when tariffs could change overnight, not just from the US, because remember, there'll also be retaliatory tariffs. I think there's a big source of potential disruption in the world. I do think that the president has three benefits in mind. One, he believes it will even the playing field. The US is running deficits because everyone else cheats. The second is that this could be a source of revenue. The third is this could be a source of jobs. We could question each one of these, especially the source of revenue, because it's actually small in relative to the US's economy size. In terms of whether they'll create jobs, a lot of manufacturing is already automated, even in a country like India. Bring it back to the US, it gets even more automated. So I'm not sure if this is going to create a lot of jobs, especially at the high school education level where there's a lot of anxiety. Rahul Kanwal: So there is the question of competitiveness, which you say the US doesn't have, which is why these jobs moved outside. But then there is also the aspect of economic coercion. We're already seeing how corporate America is trying to kiss the ring as it were. Therefore, does that then impact India's opportunity to be China plus one gateway, whereas a lot of companies think, hey, Donald Trump is calling us, cajoling us or coercing us? So is it better to set up manufacturing in the US than to look at countries like India? Raghuram Rajan: I think it creates uncertainty because one of the things that President Trump respects is the market. If the market starts tanking on the basis of some preliminary set of tariffs, clearly there will be a revisit to the tariffs. Rahul Kanwal: How are the markets likely to react? Raghuram Rajan: I think if you said, you know, suddenly after the markets had, had been expecting no or moderate tariffs, 60 per cent tariffs on, on China, 25 per cent on the rest of the world, it would be seriously adverse for the markets. I think that is partly why the decision has been postponed some by because we heard it would come on February 1 for Canada and Mexico. Also, the other concern is there's a lot of other stuff wrapped up in these tariffs, right? Remember, when the BRICS countries were talking about an alternative payment system, there was a threat of tariffs. If you do that, the threat of tariffs, if you have too many drugs being produced in your country and sent across, if you have immigrants. I mean, at some point, the world is also going to get a little jaded. But of course, this is the most powerful country in the world. So you don't want to upset the president. You want to be on the right side, but how much can you do? So at some point, countries are also going to say the only thing they will listen to is the same kind of medicine, so you will have tariffs imposed from the other side. Canada apparently has already prepared some. This is not going to end well if it continues along this path. Rahul Kanwal: What kind of inflation pressures could it create on consumers in the US and the spiral effect on consumers in India if these new tariffs are actually imposed? Raghuram Rajan: Well, I think from the Indian perspective, it would be more limited because we don't import that much from the US and even if we impose tariffs on the US, that's not going to be a huge problem. I think the concern for India will be more if Chinese goods get stopped at the US border, will they try and find a home elsewhere and similarly for Mexican goods and so on. I think in the US itself, tariffs will increase the price in the market. Some of it will be absorbed by the producer, but some of it will be passed on. If it is a one-time thing, I think the Fed will look through it because it's a one-time increase in prices. But if it's steady, if it creates more inefficiencies that create more inflation, if workers start demanding higher wages because they're protected from competition from the rest of the world, those could be sources of more steady higher inflation. So yes, it's inflationary, but maybe one-off and the Fed will look through it. But there could be a steady ramp up in inflation, in which case the Fed has to even more sort of stay with higher interest rates for longer.advertisementON ECONOMIC GROWTH IN INDIARahul Kanwal: There's a big debate in India about whether the dip that we've seen in economic growth in the second quarter of this fiscal. Is it a short-term phenomenon caused by the elections or caused by the pullback in capex because of the general elections or is this more cyclical? Where do you come out on this deeply contentious debate - short-term with an immediate recovery or more cyclical?Raghuram Rajan: Well, in one quarter, it's very hard to be assured that you have the right answer. But for some time, I have been worried about the strength of consumption, which has been less than normal over the last year, year-and-a-half and two years. What has instead compensated is infrastructure spending, which undoubtedly the government has been very successful in elevating growth rates.But of course, what was missing last quarter was infrastructure spending. So you could see that when that's taken off, the economy is weaker than we thought it was. The other component that's important to focus on is the weakness were earlier in the lower middle-class consumption and the consumption of the poor. Now you are seeing that the upper middle-class consumption has slowed down somewhat.So my sense is, broadly speaking, what is the reason for consumption slowing, especially when the stock market till recently was quite buoyant? It has to be concerns about the economic future, which means things like jobs. Do we have reasonable jobs? Are our children getting well employed? Do we feel confident enough about the future to spend?You can see a lot of spending was being supported by borrowing, the unsecured borrowing that the RBI cracked down on. So these are all signs that at the edges, all is not well. Now that doesn't mean we will plummet in terms of growth. I still think our baseline is about six, but six is not enough because we're not creating the jobs for those young people coming in.Rahul Kanwal: India's growth numbers demonstrate the dependence on government capital expenditure. We've been waiting for private investment to kickstart. Capacity utilisation has been in the mid-seventies, which is typically when you see a fresh investment cycle kickstart. It hasn't happened fully so far, even though the likes of Neelkanth Mishra and others say they can see some green shoes. What's your reading? Will we see a full-fledged investment cycle? Why is it being delayed? When does it start?Raghuram Rajan: It's been delayed for a long time, right? I mean when I was the governor eight years ago I used to worry about why investment isn't coming back on. There too, we were flirting with the 70s and 75. We said when it hits 75, it's going to come in, but it didn't quite come in. That's I think, is the big puzzle.Why is private industry not investing? Partly I mean, partly the answer is positive. It's because they've become more productive. They're using their capital better. But partly the answer is negative, that they're not sure of strong demand going forward and not preparing in time because you would think if they see demand down the line, they should be preparing well in advance and they don't seem to be.It's a big source of worry. It would be nice if that came on board. Maybe a part of the worry is also with Indian exports along with the tariff situation. But of course, the tariff situation is more like a post-US election. But, I do think this is a huge concern and a puzzle. I don't have a quick answer to why they are not doing it.ON INVESTMENT CLIMATE IN INDIARahul Kanwal: The Finance Ministry or RBI has been dealing with this situation where capacity utilisation has been in the mid 70s, despite the reduction in corporate taxes. Private investment hasn't really kick-started in a big way except for some green shoots in some sectors. What are your policy recommendations? How can we change that?Raghuram Rajan: As you know, investment is a lot about animal spirits. It's about the sense of edulience, the confidence that private industry has about the future and also involves a certain amount of risk-taking. I don't quite know if demand will be there, but let me invest.In fact, what happens is you get a virtuous circle because they invest, because they create jobs, there is a sense of confidence that permeates the economy and they invest. I would say in the early 2000s, in the previous government, you saw that confidence building up. When you talk to private industry, it was, "We can beat the world." I don't sense the same kind of confidence any more.It's no longer, "We can beat the world, but we need protection against all those people who have support from the government." We're talking again of industrial policy. We've talked about the PLI scheme before, but we need crutches. That wasn't the case in the early 2000s. So it seems to me that part of the answer is that private industry itself hasn't got that confidence to go out and invest which it needs.Now, I don't know if it is tax cuts. We've already cut the tax rate on private corporations quite a bit. I don't know if it's investment incentives, but it has to be more a sense that we can be world beaters. And that's disappeared for some reason.ON SKILL TAPPING IN INDIARahul Kanwal: Is there any way that can be changed? Because a lot of it is just spirits, right? You said animal spirits. Can any policy or nudge impact that?Raghuram Rajan: I think you can talk a good game as a politician and say we're going to grow. These are hard-bitten business people. Unless they see the underpinnings or they have these animal spirits from somewhere, it's going to be very hard to get them to put their money in the ground. So I mean, I think the government was doing what it could on the physical capital side, that is infrastructure spending. I wonder, and I've been saying this again and again, whether we can do more on the human capital side.Take the fact that right now I was meeting an NGO here. He was saying we've got all these bright poor children. We identified them. They're really smart. But they can't get into the IITs. They can't get into tech colleges. So we have a thin layer of very good schools and very good universities. Can we expand that?Because that's where we are getting our longer term sort of, the people who are going to these GCCs, the people who are going to create new jobs. So maybe it's to shift the focus of government spending. We talked about skilling in the last budget. I'd love to see how we are doing there, but we need to do far more.ON PLANS OF GOVERNMENT REDUCING INCOME TAXESRahul Kanwal: Some analysts have spoken about the possibility of bringing in a reduction in income tax rates as a means of creating more consumption, that this is the right opportune time. Would you recommend to Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman that on February 1, one of the things she should do to spur demand is to reduce income tax?Raghuram Rajan: It's not so much the tax rate I would worry about. I think our fiscal situation, though the government has spent a lot of time trying to keep it on track, is not that sound. I mean, fiscal situations have deteriorated all over the world. But when our nominal growth is where it is. Our debt starts becoming an issue with the kind of combined government and state and central fiscal deficit.Right now, those numbers are very comparable. How much growth do we have in the economy and how much our fiscal deficit is? This means that we don't have much room to expand spending without seeing debt grow much faster than we want.So I would say at this point, it's not so much on cutting taxes, as on spending in a more effective way. When we spend on a more effective way, I would say that focusing on increasing the quality of our human capital at every level. Whether it's the health of our children, reducing malnutrition, or improving the quality of primary schools, improving the quality of our universities.I think across the board, if we invest, we have a chance in the new economy of the future. If we don't invest, I think we're going to reach the point where we want to be a developed country without the human capital to do it. We may have reasonable infrastructure, but we need human capital, people of high caliber. With 1.4 billion people, that has to be our most important asset.ON JOB CREATION IN INDIARahul Kanwal: When we spoke last, the biggest concern was around rural consumption. Now, there's a lot of talk about urban distress.
In fact, some analysts have spoken about the middle-class shrinking. Some FMCG CEOs have spoken about it. We've got fund houses speaking about the great Indian middle-class shrinking. Your reading of the data around the spirits of the middle-class and whether middle class numbers and their consumption actually coming down?Raghuram Rajan: Again, a good time in the Indian economy was the early 2000s, when we saw a lot of reforms, but we also saw strong growth, but also spirits were strong. If you look at applications to the IAS, to the civil services, they were falling at that time.More recently, you see it going up significantly. Then you hear these horror stories about how many people apply for low-level railway jobs with PhDs and with MBAs and so on. I think that what we really are seeing is a lot of angst about job creation, good jobs, not any false job, but good jobs. It can't be all of the government (jobs).The government only has a limited number of jobs on its own. But even facilitating private sector jobs, what it can do is create the backbone for more jobs to be created. Take tourism, for example. It is very employment intensive. Can we do more to facilitate tourism? Just visas. I mean, my friend from China is an academic from Stanford. Why doesn't he get a visa to come in? Let's look at these nitty-gritty things.We want people to come from across the world to spend money in India, but you can take sector after sector. For instance, in plumbing, it's hard to find a good plumber in a city in India. Can we train more people in that? I think we can grow jobs. We have to accept that they aren't all going to be IAS, but they can be pretty good jobs.ON PRODUCTION-LINKED INCENTIVES Rahul Kanwal: One of the government's big ideas has been production-linked incentives, and we spoke about it the last time we had a conversation. It's been a mixed track record. In some sectors, for example, like mobile manufacturing and solar panels. We've seen some positives because of the PLI schemes, but on balance, what's your reading of the efficacy of PLIs when it comes to job creation?Raghuram Rajan: Well, I think what has happened is in a bunch of industries which are very capital-intensive. We haven't seen much job creation and where we've put enormous subsidies at play, for example, chips. I would say there's more of a concern that this is about national security than about creating a flourishing chip industry and creating jobs. I mean, chips are very capital intensive but it is not going to create many jobs.Rahul Kanwal: Do you think that's a bad idea?Raghuram Rajan: I think the kind of investment we're doing in manufacturing chips is that we're already designing chips. Should we put more money into creating more chip designers where there is a lot of added value? NVIDIA is worth over 3 trillion. TSMC, which makes the highest-value added chips, is about USD 750 billion on a good day. These are comparisons, but broadly speaking, manufacturing is not where the value added is. It's in the design, the intellectual property.That's where we have people who can actually, if trained up, make a difference. I saw a number that we have 3 lakh chip designers. We don't have a single chip manufacturing unit as yet. Should we be putting more value into chip design and maybe create our own version of NVIDIA? Hopefully, eventually.Rahul Kanwal: I spoke to Ashwini Vaishnav about this. The minister's argument is it's about building a full ecosystem. Also the fact that there is so much global uncertainty. We've seen the kind of norms the US has come out with recently under former President Joe Biden. We're seeing how China is pushing against Taiwan.And the dependence on companies like NVIDIA, dependence on companies like TSMC. So you have to start somewhere in the government's argument and build an ecosystem. Even if the chips being produced are far bigger and more outdated technologically, then you can't get to the cutting edge right away.Raghuram Rajan: So the issue is time and place to make that kind of investment, right? Right now, I think the real issue is do we have enough capability to train our people to the levels that are needed? We're building these chip factories. We can't get the engineers to actually construct them.We've got to get them from outside. But broadly, I would even disagree with the idea that we need the entire ecosystem in India. You know, ASML makes machines for chips in the Netherlands. There's no big chip manufacturer in the Netherlands. That's the kind of specialisation that is required in the world economy to be at the frontier.You can be the best machine maker in the world without having a chip industry. You can be the best foundry, as in Taiwan, but you don't have to have a chip designing this framework. Chip designers are all in the US.Can we build a chip design industry because our human capital is available? Let's invest more in our human capital. That would be my argument to something like we need the ecosystem. That said, I'm saying don't prevent any manufacturing. But, you know, think carefully when you're putting so much money in terms of subsidies because we're competing with the US.We're competing with Taiwan. Those guys are going to create a glut in chips sooner rather than later. Why not buy the chips when they create the glut? Yes, I understand there's a security rationale. By all means, to the extent that we need some of those chips for our military, let us buy them, create inventories and create surpluses. That'll be far cheaper than trying to make them.ON EMPLOYMENT-LINKED INCENTIVESRahul Kanwal: In the last budget, the government came out with employment-linked incentives. One year down, how do you see that play out? Should Nirmala Sitharaman double down on ELIs or is that not working out the way the government would have wanted?Raghuram Rajan: I think the broader issue of bringing people into work and training them on the job is extremely important, given we need jobs in any way we can get. I think that was a good idea. I think the skilling announcements that were made then are also good ideas. What I would love to see is careful monitoring of where we are and how it's working.This is not the Press Information Bureau giving us some numbers, which God only knows where they came from. But put out the numbers, let people do research on it, say, 'here is where we're doing well, here's where we're not doing so well'.A modern economy needs to run on the basis of careful data analysis. We're not even getting the data, let alone the analysis. I think if we are to do these things well, I mean, remember, we had a Skill India programme, which didn't really take off because a lot of people apparently were funded to actually do it, but the outcomes weren't that great.Rahul Kanwal: We have our own internship scheme with the big NSE listed companies. Do you think that's a good idea?Raghuram Rajan: I think all ideas are good until they've proven bad. Let's try it out. As I said, we need all the jobs we can. Let's try it out. But measure what happens just because you went into Hindustan Lever or L&T doesn't necessarily mean that you're employable. If the course you've got was terrible.On the other hand, you can go to a small entity and get a variety of experiences which make you very employable. So can we just measure? Are you employed for two years? We have the data, we can find the data. You know, do you pay income taxes two years from when you were trained? What is your job? What are you doing? You know, just track it.ON RUPEE VS DOLLAR SITUATIONRahul Kanwal: There is a new governor at the RBI. The Indian rupee has been depreciating. The last governor's thinking seems to have been to hold off on the depreciation. The new governor seems to have a slightly different thinking. What do you see as being the medium-term outlook for the rupee? To what extent should the rupee be allowed to depreciate, especially given the potential for a political backlash against the central government?Raghuram Rajan: So I think we have to be a lot more mature about the rupee-dollar exchange rate than public dialogue sometimes. 
First, if the dollar is appreciating vis-a-vis the euro, to hold it from appreciating vis-a-vis the rupee means that then we become uncompetitive in our exports to the euro or to anywhere else which is depreciating.So what you need to look at is across the basket of currencies is how we're doing. My sense is that pretty much every country has depreciated against the dollar. We haven't appreciated or depreciated against other currencies, but we have against the dollar. Since everybody's looking at the dollar, we look like we're doing badly. But if you look at the euro, it's closing on parity with respect to the dollar, which means quite a bit of decline over the last year. I won't worry too much.The exchange rate is a means for the economy to adjust to things like tariffs, things like the fact that capital is flowing into the US. So don't overreact to the rupee vs dollar.Rahul Kanwal: So what would be the natural exchange rate for the Indian rupee versus the dollar at this moment?Raghuram Rajan: I don't want to put a number out there. I don't think we should hold the rupee at a level which is unsustainable.That just means wasting our foreign exchange reserves and we will need it at some point if things become more difficult in the global economy. I don't know exactly what is. What I would look at is, which I haven't done, look at the weighted exchange rate against other currencies as well as our inflation and make sure the real effective exchange rate hasn't crept up. That would make us uncomparative.It coming down too much would make it more comparative but would create the potential for some kind of volatility down the line. That, to my sense, is household confidence, which the way to repair it is to do much more on the job front, which is why I think the skilling, the apprenticeship, the trying to get incentives for job creation. All those are good.ON PLANS TO TAX ULTRA-RICH IN INDIARahul Kanwal: Thomas Piketty has spoken about the need for a wealth tax of 2 per cent on the ultra-rich in India. But again and again, you hear horror stories of a tiny business easy to open.Once it's a big business, then I attract all the inspector raj, the tax authorities. Everybody's intent on making my life miserable. It's hard running a business in India even today despite the government's sort of focus on ease of doing business.Can we make it easier so that you say, 'oh look, there's all that demand that needs to be satisfied'. Let me invest and let me create more job opportunities for people. So I do think we need to create an environment which attracts investment, whether it be domestic or foreign.Published By: Prateek ChakrabortyPublished On: Jan 22, 2025ALSO READ |  IMF's Gita Gopinath on Trump tariffs, impact on global growth, AI and moreMust Watch

Raghuram Rajan: It's not so much the tax rate I would worry about. I think our fiscal situation, though the government has spent a lot of time trying to keep it on track, is not that sound. I mean, fiscal situations have deteriorated all over the world. But when our nominal growth is where it is. Our debt starts becoming an issue with the kind of combined government and state and central fiscal deficit. Right now, those numbers are very comparable. How much growth do we have in the economy and how much our fiscal deficit is? This means that we don't have much room to expand spending without seeing debt grow much faster than we want. So I would say at this point, it's not so much on cutting taxes, as on spending in a more effective way. When we spend on a more effective way, I would say that focusing on increasing the quality of our human capital at every level. Whether it's the health of our children, reducing malnutrition, or improving the quality of primary schools, improving the quality of our universities. I think across the board, if we invest, we have a chance in the new economy of the future. If we don't invest, I think we're going to reach the point where we want to be a developed country without the human capital to do it. We may have reasonable infrastructure, but we need human capital, people of high caliber. With 1.4 billion people, that has to be our most important asset.ON JOB CREATION IN INDIA Rahul Kanwal: When we spoke last, the biggest concern was around rural consumption. Now, there's a lot of talk about urban distress.
In fact, some analysts have spoken about the middle-class shrinking. Some FMCG CEOs have spoken about it. We've got fund houses speaking about the great Indian middle-class shrinking. Your reading of the data around the spirits of the middle-class and whether middle class numbers and their consumption actually coming down? Raghuram Rajan: Again, a good time in the Indian economy was the early 2000s, when we saw a lot of reforms, but we also saw strong growth, but also spirits were strong. If you look at applications to the IAS, to the civil services, they were falling at that time. More recently, you see it going up significantly. Then you hear these horror stories about how many people apply for low-level railway jobs with PhDs and with MBAs and so on. I think that what we really are seeing is a lot of angst about job creation, good jobs, not any false job, but good jobs. It can't be all of the government (jobs). The government only has a limited number of jobs on its own. But even facilitating private sector jobs, what it can do is create the backbone for more jobs to be created. Take tourism, for example. It is very employment intensive. Can we do more to facilitate tourism? Just visas. I mean, my friend from China is an academic from Stanford. Why doesn't he get a visa to come in? Let's look at these nitty-gritty things. We want people to come from across the world to spend money in India, but you can take sector after sector. For instance, in plumbing, it's hard to find a good plumber in a city in India. Can we train more people in that? I think we can grow jobs. We have to accept that they aren't all going to be IAS, but they can be pretty good jobs.ON PRODUCTION-LINKED INCENTIVES  Rahul Kanwal: One of the government's big ideas has been production-linked incentives, and we spoke about it the last time we had a conversation. It's been a mixed track record. In some sectors, for example, like mobile manufacturing and solar panels. We've seen some positives because of the PLI schemes, but on balance, what's your reading of the efficacy of PLIs when it comes to job creation? Raghuram Rajan: Well, I think what has happened is in a bunch of industries which are very capital-intensive. We haven't seen much job creation and where we've put enormous subsidies at play, for example, chips. I would say there's more of a concern that this is about national security than about creating a flourishing chip industry and creating jobs. I mean, chips are very capital intensive but it is not going to create many jobs. Rahul Kanwal: Do you think that's a bad idea? Raghuram Rajan: I think the kind of investment we're doing in manufacturing chips is that we're already designing chips. Should we put more money into creating more chip designers where there is a lot of added value? NVIDIA is worth over 3 trillion. TSMC, which makes the highest-value added chips, is about USD 750 billion on a good day. These are comparisons, but broadly speaking, manufacturing is not where the value added is. It's in the design, the intellectual property. That's where we have people who can actually, if trained up, make a difference. I saw a number that we have 3 lakh chip designers. We don't have a single chip manufacturing unit as yet. Should we be putting more value into chip design and maybe create our own version of NVIDIA? Hopefully, eventually. Rahul Kanwal: I spoke to Ashwini Vaishnav about this. The minister's argument is it's about building a full ecosystem. Also the fact that there is so much global uncertainty. We've seen the kind of norms the US has come out with recently under former President Joe Biden. We're seeing how China is pushing against Taiwan. And the dependence on companies like NVIDIA, dependence on companies like TSMC. So you have to start somewhere in the government's argument and build an ecosystem. Even if the chips being produced are far bigger and more outdated technologically, then you can't get to the cutting edge right away. Raghuram Rajan: So the issue is time and place to make that kind of investment, right? Right now, I think the real issue is do we have enough capability to train our people to the levels that are needed? We're building these chip factories. We can't get the engineers to actually construct them. We've got to get them from outside. But broadly, I would even disagree with the idea that we need the entire ecosystem in India. You know, ASML makes machines for chips in the Netherlands. There's no big chip manufacturer in the Netherlands. That's the kind of specialisation that is required in the world economy to be at the frontier. You can be the best machine maker in the world without having a chip industry. You can be the best foundry, as in Taiwan, but you don't have to have a chip designing this framework. Chip designers are all in the US. Can we build a chip design industry because our human capital is available? Let's invest more in our human capital. That would be my argument to something like we need the ecosystem. That said, I'm saying don't prevent any manufacturing. But, you know, think carefully when you're putting so much money in terms of subsidies because we're competing with the US. We're competing with Taiwan. Those guys are going to create a glut in chips sooner rather than later. Why not buy the chips when they create the glut? Yes, I understand there's a security rationale. By all means, to the extent that we need some of those chips for our military, let us buy them, create inventories and create surpluses. That'll be far cheaper than trying to make them.ON EMPLOYMENT-LINKED INCENTIVES Rahul Kanwal: In the last budget, the government came out with employment-linked incentives. One year down, how do you see that play out? Should Nirmala Sitharaman double down on ELIs or is that not working out the way the government would have wanted? Raghuram Rajan: I think the broader issue of bringing people into work and training them on the job is extremely important, given we need jobs in any way we can get. I think that was a good idea. I think the skilling announcements that were made then are also good ideas. What I would love to see is careful monitoring of where we are and how it's working. This is not the Press Information Bureau giving us some numbers, which God only knows where they came from. But put out the numbers, let people do research on it, say, 'here is where we're doing well, here's where we're not doing so well'. A modern economy needs to run on the basis of careful data analysis. We're not even getting the data, let alone the analysis. I think if we are to do these things well, I mean, remember, we had a Skill India programme, which didn't really take off because a lot of people apparently were funded to actually do it, but the outcomes weren't that great. Rahul Kanwal: We have our own internship scheme with the big NSE listed companies. Do you think that's a good idea? Raghuram Rajan: I think all ideas are good until they've proven bad. Let's try it out. As I said, we need all the jobs we can. Let's try it out. But measure what happens just because you went into Hindustan Lever or L&T doesn't necessarily mean that you're employable. If the course you've got was terrible. On the other hand, you can go to a small entity and get a variety of experiences which make you very employable. So can we just measure? Are you employed for two years? We have the data, we can find the data. You know, do you pay income taxes two years from when you were trained? What is your job? What are you doing? You know, just track it.ON RUPEE VS DOLLAR SITUATION Rahul Kanwal: There is a new governor at the RBI. The Indian rupee has been depreciating. The last governor's thinking seems to have been to hold off on the depreciation. The new governor seems to have a slightly different thinking. What do you see as being the medium-term outlook for the rupee? To what extent should the rupee be allowed to depreciate, especially given the potential for a political backlash against the central government? Raghuram Rajan: So I think we have to be a lot more mature about the rupee-dollar exchange rate than public dialogue sometimes. 
First, if the dollar is appreciating vis-a-vis the euro, to hold it from appreciating vis-a-vis the rupee means that then we become uncompetitive in our exports to the euro or to anywhere else which is depreciating. So what you need to look at is across the basket of currencies is how we're doing. My sense is that pretty much every country has depreciated against the dollar. We haven't appreciated or depreciated against other currencies, but we have against the dollar. Since everybody's looking at the dollar, we look like we're doing badly. But if you look at the euro, it's closing on parity with respect to the dollar, which means quite a bit of decline over the last year. I won't worry too much. The exchange rate is a means for the economy to adjust to things like tariffs, things like the fact that capital is flowing into the US. So don't overreact to the rupee vs dollar. Rahul Kanwal: So what would be the natural exchange rate for the Indian rupee versus the dollar at this moment? Raghuram Rajan: I don't want to put a number out there. I think the RBI does these calculations, but others can also do it. What is the real effective exchange rate that we feel comfortable with? Which means taking down both the depreciation but also the inflation rate in India versus the rest of the world. I don't think we should hold the rupee at a level which is unsustainable. That just means wasting our foreign exchange reserves and we will need it at some point if things become more difficult in the global economy. So I would say, do what the RBI has always been doing, which is focus on reducing volatility, but don't try and determine what the level is. Let it move towards whatever level it has to move to keep the economy in balance. Rahul Kanwal: There has been some commentary about letting the rupee slide to a hundred rupees to a dollar, that being a more natural exchange rate at this moment given what is happening globally. Raghuram Rajan: I would not think that from what I know, I don't think 100 is the right place. I don't know exactly what is. What I would look at is, which I haven't done, look at the weighted exchange rate against other currencies as well as our inflation and make sure the real effective exchange rate hasn't crept up. That would make us uncomparative. It coming down too much would make it more comparative but would create the potential for some kind of volatility down the line. So I would say reasonable balance is to keep it fairly reasonable until tariffs hit. When tariffs start being imposed, if they are imposed against India, one of the answers is to let the rupee depreciate some.ON INFLATION IN INDIA Rahul Kanwal: The other question is about interest rates and the RBI's position on whether there should be a reduction or should it be held off. How would you view this question? Raghuram Rajan: I have never commented on RBI's monetary policy. I just commented peripherally on exchange rates. Look, I think the RBI has an inflation targeting regime. It has to feel comfortable that inflation is coming down and then it can cut rates. I think the problem in the economy to some extent is not supply. We seem to have a reasonable supply. You can see that in the core inflation numbers. They have been going at very moderate rates. The issue seems to be more demand. Now, of course, inflation has been high because of food, especially vegetables. I understand that's coming down. That may give the RBI more room. But, clearly what it has to do is keeping in mind the state of the economy and adjust monetary policy rates accordingly. Rahul Kanwal: What can be done to spur demand? There's a big budget. There's a monetary policy review as well. How should policymakers be spurring demand? Raghuram Rajan: Again, this goes back to something short term or is it something longer term? I think it's this confidence, not just in the industrialists, which we talked about earlier. It's also in people, in their futures. Yeah, politicians can make you feel that things are great. But if their daily lives aren't matching that, then they're going to cut back. I think you need to give them a greater sense that they will have better jobs. They will have better incomes. Then you will see the consumption pick up. That's why I'm saying this is not a temporary thing. I think we're seeing it exposed because infrastructure came down this time, and we focused on the growth numbers. But consumption has been more tepid relative to the past in recent times. I would say even post-pandemic. That would suggest something has broken. That, to my sense, is household confidence, which the way to repair it is to do much more on the job front, which is why I think the skilling, the apprenticeship, the trying to get incentives for job creation. All those are good.ON PLANS TO TAX ULTRA-RICH IN INDIA Rahul Kanwal: Thomas Piketty has spoken about the need for a wealth tax of 2 per cent on the ultra-rich in India. Do you think at this stage in India's economic journey that's a good idea? A lot of people are pushing back saying this wealth tax haven't worked elsewhere and that Piketty is completely wrong. Raghuram Rajan: Well, I think Piketty has been right about growing inequality across the world. Whether that's fixed through a huge or even a wealth tax. Part of the problem is the very rich also know how to get around taxes. I mean, it's very hard to see any place where wealth taxes get you a lot. There's a wealth tax in the US, 40-45 per cent of your wealth, you know, once it's beyond 20 million. Why aren't these billionaires unhappy? Why aren't they trying to change it? Because nobody is really going to be hit by it. They put it into various trusts and there's a whole lot of lawyerings that goes on, which ensures that the ultimate wealth tax that will be collected will be tiny. I think it may be a reasonable idea to collect more in taxes from wealthier people to try and generate more growth by the various spending that has to take place. But I am not sure that wealth taxes will do it for you. As far as other income taxes are, we are pretty high already.ON EASE OF DOING BUSINESS IN INDIA Rahul Kanwal: There's been a trend of high net worth individuals leaving India to go to Dubai, the UK and elsewhere. What would you recommend be done to try and change that? Why do you think that's happening? Can the government do something to try and change that? Raghuram Rajan: That's another issue that I should study more. What you hear is people are trying to establish multiple areas of residence and wealth so that they're more diversified against policy change wherever it happens. I don't know how big this is as a factor driving them. But I would try and create more incentives to bring money into India. So one of the big issues I hear from business people is the ease of doing business. We've talked a lot about it in India. But again and again, you hear horror stories of a tiny business easy to open. Once it's a big business, then I attract all the inspector raj, the tax authorities. Everybody's intent on making my life miserable. It's hard running a business in India even today despite the government's sort of focus on ease of doing business. Can we make it easier so that you say, 'oh look, there's all that demand that needs to be satisfied'. Let me invest and let me create more job opportunities for people. So I do think we need to create an environment which attracts investment, whether it be domestic or foreign.Published By: Prateek ChakrabortyPublished On: Jan 22, 2025ALSO READ |  IMF's Gita Gopinath on Trump tariffs, impact on global growth, AI and moreMust Watch

Headline: Stocks to watch today: HCLTech, HDFC Bank, HUL, Tata Communication, ZomatoHDFC Bank, Hindustan Unilever (HUL), and Tata Communication will be announcing their Q3 FY25 results today, hence their stocks will likely see some action.
Content: The stock market had a rough day as Dalal Street saw a see-saw trading session before crashing in the final hours. After swinging up and down all day, the benchmark indices ended up dropping by about 1.5% affected by uncertain policies that Donald Trump might implement.  Ravi Singh, SVP - Retail Research, Religare Broking, said, "India's benchmark equity index, the Sensex, saw a slight decline on Tuesday due to a combination of disappointing earnings reports and concerns over global economic growth. Market sentiment turned cautious after US President Donald Trump’s announcement of trade tariffs on neighbouring countries, creating uncertainty around global trade dynamics. This move fuelled concerns over potential disruptions in international trade, leading to a pullback in domestic equities." HDFC Bank, Hindustan Unilever (HUL), and Tata Communication will be announcing their Q3 FY25 results today, hence their stocks will likely see some action. Jio Financial Services - The Jio-BlackRock partnership is moving forward, with both companies putting in another Rs 117 crore for about 5.85 crore shares in their joint venture. HCLTech is expanding its presence down south, opening up a massive new centre in Hyderabad that'll house 5,000 people. Zomato - Zomato is having a bit of a tough time as its shares dropped for the second day running, taking an 11% hit yesterday. Their latest results showed profits falling from Rs 138 crore to Rs 59 crore compared to last year - that's a pretty steep 57% drop. ICICI Prudential Life Insurance saw their profits jump by 43%, reaching Rs 325 crore this quarter. Tata Technologies had a slight dip though, with profits edging down from Rs 170 crore to Rs 169 crore. JSW Steel signed a deal with Maharashtra for a massive Rs 3-lakh crore investment. PNB Housing Finance posted solid numbers with Rs 471 crore in profits and Rs 764 crore in net interest income. Dalmia Bharat reported Rs 66 crore in profits with revenue hitting Rs 3,181 crore. And IndiaMart Intermesh had positive news too, with profits up 36% to Rs 125 crore.Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Jan 22, 2025

Headline: Sensex, Nifty open higher driven by a rally in IT sector stocks; Infosys gains 2%The S&P BSE Sensex was up 246.41 points to 76,084.77, while the NSE Nifty50 added 62.15 points to 23,086.80 as of 9:26 AM.
Content: Benchmark stock market indices gained in early trade to open higher on Wednesday after witnessing a crash in the last session. The market was driven by gains in information technology (IT) stocks.  The S&P BSE Sensex was up 246.41 points to 76,084.77, while the NSE Nifty50 added 62.15 points to 23,086.80 as of 9:26 AM.  Dr. V K Vijayakumar, Chief Investment Strategist, Geojit Financial Services said, ""President Trump’s orders and announcements, so far, have been disruptive. He is doing tough talking initially to send the message that more stern measures are in the offing. Trump’s threat to impose 100% tariffs on BRICS if they attempt dedollarisation is a repeat of his election campaign rhetoric. It appears that the markets took this threat too seriously." Nifty is down around 12% from September highs. The correction provides a good opportunity for long-term investors to buy quality stocks, which are now available at fair valuations. The key to success will be patience.Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Jan 22, 2025

Headline: HDFC Bank to announce Q3 results today: Here's what to expectHDFC Bank Q3 FY25: Investors will be keeping a keen eye on the results as the stock of HDFC Bank has fallen 8.62% in the last month.
Content: HDFC Bank is set to announce its financial results for the December quarter (Q3 FY25) on Wednesday. Investors will be keeping a keen eye on the results as the stock of HDFC Bank has fallen 8.62% in the last month.  HDFC Bank shares closed marginally below, falling 0.33% at Rs 1,645.75 in the last trading session.  India's largest private sector lender is expected to report muted profit growth in its December quarter results, according to market analysts and brokerages. HDFC Bank might see net profit grow between 0-3%, with net interest income (NII) increasing by 6-8% year-on-year. Financial solutions and broking services firm Axis Securities projects HDFC Bank to report a 2.2% year-on-year (YoY) rise in net profit at Rs 16,737 crore for the December quarter compared with Rs 16,373 crore in the same quarter last year. Net interest income (NII) is expected to increase by 8.1% year-on-year, reaching Rs 30,778 crore compared to Rs 28,471 crore in the same period last year. Provisions are anticipated to rise 18.6% sequentially to Rs 3,203 crore from Rs 2,700 crore in the previous quarter, although this marks a 24% decline from Rs 4,217 crore in the corresponding period a year ago. The pre-provision operating profit is projected to stand at Rs 25,098 crore. "Deposit growth was better than credit growth, LDR improved marginally; credit growth was significantly below the industry growth. Margins are likely to remain stable QoQ with a slight positive bias. Opex ratios are expected to remain steady. Slippages may remain under control. The management commentary on deposit accretion and resultant credit growth and Margin improvement trajectory will be watched," it said.  Sharekhan, another leading brokerage, points out that while deposit growth has been encouraging, lending hasn't kept pace with market trends. They forecast a slight dip in profits to Rs 16,264 crore. The bank's provision for bad loans might rise to Rs 3,203 crore, up 18.6% from the September quarter but significantly lower than last year's figure of Rs 4,217 crore, according to market estimates. Investors will closely monitor management comments on several key aspects during today's earnings announcement. Motilal Oswal Financial Services (MOFSL) projects HDFC Bank's net profit to reach Rs 16,644 crore, marking a 1.7% year-on-year growth. The brokerage anticipates a 6.5% YoY increase in net interest income (NII) to Rs 30,335 crore. It also expects cost ratios to be well-managed and margins to remain largely steady. Nuvama's research suggests a marginal decline in net interest margins to 3.43% from last quarter's 3.46%. However, they remain more optimistic about profit growth, projecting a 3.2% increase to Rs 16,900 crore. (Disclaimer: The views, opinions, recommendations, and suggestions expressed by experts/brokerages in this article are their own and do not reflect the views of the India Today Group. It is advisable to consult a qualified broker or financial advisor before making any actual investment or trading choices.)Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Jan 22, 2025

Headline: Focus on effective spending, not tax cuts: Raghuram Rajan ahead of Budget 2025Former RBI Governor Raghuram Rajan said that he is not worried about the reduction in tax rates but instead about the need for more effective government spending, particularly in human capital development.
Content: The Budget is just a week away and salaried taxpayers are hoping for some income tax relief to cope with high inflation and the cost of living.  However, Former RBI Governor Raghuram Rajan said that he is not worried about the reduction in tax rates but instead about the need for more effective government spending, particularly in human capital development. Speaking to India Today News Director Rahul Kanwal on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Rajan expressed concerns about India's fiscal situation. "It's not so much the tax rate I would worry about. I think our fiscal situation, though the government has spent a lot of time trying to keep it on track, is not that sound," the former RBI governor said, while highlighting that fiscal situations have worsened globally. Rajan said that with current nominal growth rates, debt becomes a concern when considering the combined state and central fiscal deficits. "Our debt starts becoming an issue with the kind of combined government and state and central fiscal deficit. Right now, those numbers are very comparable. We don't have much room to expand spending without seeing debt grow much faster than we want. So I would say at this point, it's not so much on cutting taxes, as on spending in a more effective way," he said.  Instead of tax cuts, Raghuram Rajan advocated for more targeted and effective government spending, particularly in developing human capital. "When we spend in a more effective way, I would say that focusing on increasing the quality of our human capital at every level - whether it's the health of our children, reducing malnutrition, or improving the quality of primary schools, improving the quality of our universities," he said. The former RBI chief highlighted the importance of human capital in India's development journey.   "If we invest, we have a chance in the new economy of the future. If we don't invest, I think we're going to reach the point where we want to be a developed country without the human capital to do it," he added.  Former Reserve Bank of India (RBI) Governor Raghuram Rajan on Tuesday expressed strong concerns over newly-appointed US President Donald Trump's proposed tariff hikes. Rajan described the tariff hike plans as a "big source of uncertainty" that could disrupt global economic stability. These comments come ahead of the upcoming Union Budget, where experts have suggested the possibility of income tax rate cuts to boost consumption, which will induce growth. Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Jan 22, 2025

Headline: Denta Water IPO opens for bidding: Should you subscribe? Check latest GMPThe price band for the IPO of Denta Water has been set at Rs 279-294 per share with retail investors required to invest a minimum of Rs 14,700. The minimum lot size for an application is 50.
Content: The initial public offering of Denta Water and Infra Solutions Limited opened for bidding on Wednesday aiming to raise Rs 220.50 crore through a fresh issue of 75 lakh shares.  Denta Water and Infra Solutions Ltd. (DWISL) specialises in the design, installation, and commissioning of water management projects, with a primary focus on groundwater recharge solutions. Established in 2016 and based in Bangalore, Karnataka, DWISL also undertakes construction projects within the railway and highway sectors, leveraging its expertise to deliver high-quality infrastructure solutions.advertisementDENTA WATER IPO REVIEW The price band for the IPO of Denta Water has been set at Rs 279-294 per share with retail investors required to invest a minimum of Rs 14,700. The minimum lot size for an application is 50. For sNII, the minimum investment requires 14 lots, which equals 700 shares and amounts to Rs 2,05,800. On the other hand, bNII investors need to invest in at least 69 lots, or 3,450 shares, which comes to Rs 10,14,300. The 3-day bidding process for the IPO will close on January 24, 2024.  The public listing of Denta Water IPO has already raised Rs 66.15 crore from anchor investors.SHOULD YOU SUBSCRIBE?  The Indian water and wastewater treatment market is expected to grow at a CAGR of 6.20% in terms of value to reach $24 billion in 2033 from USD $billion in 2023. "At the upper price band of Rs 294, Denta is available at a P/E of 16.2 (FY25 Annualised), which is at a discount compared to its listed peers. The company’s focus on water management projects and growing market opportunities present prospects for the company's future growth. With a robust order pipeline and consistent financial performance featuring industry-leading margins, the company is set for future success. We recommend subscribing to this issue for short- to medium-term investment," said an IPO report from Geojit.  Proceeds from the IPO will be used by the company for general corporate purposes and to manage working capital. LATEST GMP OF DENTA WATER IPO The grey market premium (GMP) for the IPO of Denta Water has gone up in the last couple of days in the unofficial/unregulated grey market.  As of the latest update on January 22, 2024, the public listing commands a GMP of Rs 165 which translates to an expected listing gain of over 56%. The expected listing price as per the GMP is Rs 459 for the IPO.  Allotment of shares for the IPO will be finalised on January 27, 2025. Denta Water IPO is expected to make its market debut on Wednesday, January 29, 2025.
