Content: Benchmark stock market indices opened flat on Saturday as stock market investors awaited key announcements of Union Budget 2025. The markets opened with marginal gains but quickly shed the early rise.  The S&P BSE Sensex was down by 31.61 points to 77,468.96, while the NSE Nifty50 declined by 19.30 points to 23,489.10 as of 9:20 AM.  Dr. V K Vijayakumar, Chief Investment Strategist, Geojit Financial Services said that on the Budget day the market reactions will be quick in response to Budget announcements. "A major expectation from the Budget is a cut in personal income tax to provide relief to the middle class and boost consumption, thereby facilitating growth recovery. The extent of the tax relief remains to be seen. The fact is that there is no fiscal space for big relief. The market will be looking for growth stimulating measures; not market-related taxation reliefs like changes in the capital gains taxation. The market response to the Budget will not last more than a few days. Trends in growth and earnings recovery will dictate the medium to long-term market direction," he added. Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 1, 2025

Headline: Budget 2025: Use this income tax calculator to check your tax outgoCalculate income tax online: Experts suggest that 'Modi 3.0' may introduce measures to make the new income tax regime more appealing to taxpayers.
Content:
Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman is set to announce the Union Budget 2025 in Parliament, with major focus on potential income tax changes to boost consumption amid a slowdown in GDP growth. Experts suggest that the Modi 3.0 government may introduce measures to make the new income tax regime more appealing to taxpayers. There is speculation that the Modi 3.0 government may make the new tax regime more attractive by offering higher rebates or additional deductions. Many taxpayers still prefer the old tax regime due to the available exemptions and deductions. However, experts suggest that a simpler tax system could increase the number of people filing tax returns. Dipesh Jain, Partner at Economic Laws Practice, said, "Choosing between the old and new tax regime is difficult for some taxpayers as they struggle to optimise their tax savings. A simpler tax system with clear incentives and fewer compliances can make tax filing easier and boost participation. The government's focus is to encourage more people to file taxes, and a simpler regime can help achieve this goal."How to Calculate Your Income Tax? While the government has not yet announced any changes, taxpayers can still estimate their tax liability for the financial year 2024-25 using an income tax calculator. Click here to check our income tax calculator The India Today Income Tax Calculator can help you calculate how much tax you need to pay. By entering details such as:

 The calculator will show your estimated tax outgo after considering applicable exemptions, deductions, and rebates.What to Include in Your Tax Calculation? To get an accurate estimate of your income tax, you must include all sources of income:

 By considering all these factors, you can get a clear picture of your tax liability and plan your finances accordingly. If the Budget 2025 introduces any new tax benefits, knowing your current tax outgo will help you compare and decide whether to switch to the new tax regime or stick to the old one.Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 1, 2025

Headline: Will stock market investors get tax relief from this budget?Capital gains tax and stock market investors: Experts anticipate that Budget 2025 should not announce new taxes, instead, provide tax rebates to boost the consumption levels and revive market sentiment.
Content: Stock market investors anticipate tax relief from Union Budget 2025 that could boost market sentiment. They expect doing away with security transaction tax (STT) and a rise in tax exemption to long term capital gains tax (LTCG) from the existing Rs 1.25 to Rs 2 lakh, but no change in short term capital gains tax (STCG). Devam Sardana, Business Head, Lemonn mentioned that in the previous budget an increase in both STT and LTCG on the listed shares impacted the investors. “In the last budget, there was a dual impact of STT increase and LTCG increase (on listed shares) on the users with an increase in trading costs as well as impact on profitability of the users. Given that the revenue generation would have significantly increased with STT, this can potentially be used to revert the LTCG to 10% in order to ensure even higher market participation and incentivise long-term investment which is critical for the users and the capital market stability,” he said. “This can also address reduction in the flight of capital from India towards global markets and potentially contribute to rupee appreciation as well,” added Sardana. Experts quoted in a Business Today report that frequent changes give rise to uncertainty. Hence it is important to maintain stability amid an economic slowdown. Dr. V K Vijayakumar, Chief Investment Strategist, Geojit Financial Services, said, "A major expectation from the Budget is a cut in personal income tax to provide relief to the middle class and boost consumption, thereby facilitating growth recovery. The extent of the tax relief remains to be seen. The fact is that there is no fiscal space for big relief. The market will be looking for growth stimulating measures; not market-related taxation reliefs like changes in the capital gains taxation." They hope that Budget 2025 should not announce new taxes, instead, provide tax rebates to boost the consumption levels.Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Feb 1, 2025

Headline: Budget 2025: Government to strengthen MSME sectorThe Indian government would strengthen the country's MSME sector.
Content: Finance Minsister Nirmala Sitharaman, while presenting Union Budget 2025 mentioned the government would prioritise the MSME sector of the country. The government said that the investment limit for MSME classification to be made 2.5 times. Also, the turnover limit for MSME classification would be doubled. This would not only pace up the country's manufacturing sector but would also provide employment opportunities to countless youth across the country On MSME as second engine of growth, Sandeep Chilana, Managing Partner CCLaw said, “Union Budget 2025 pays specific attention to MSME by enhancing threshold for qualification as MSME as well as improving  credit facilities of MSMEs including specialised credit cards to be used for SMEs and setting up of new fund for investments in startups.” The country has more than one crore registered MSMEs, which gives employment to nearly 7.5 crore people.Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Feb 1, 2025

Headline: Rising middle class, growth top focus of Budget 2025; Bihar big beneficiaryFinance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman said the top priorities of Budget 2025 will be to boost growth and enhance the spending power of the middle class, farmers, women and youth.
Content: Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman started presenting the Union Budget 2024 on Saturday, with measures focused on boosting the spending power of the "rising middle class." She said Budget 2025 prioritises reforms in six key areas such as taxation, power, urban development, mining, the financial sector, and regulatory policies. "Honourable Speaker, I present the Union Budget for 2025-26, continuing our efforts to drive growth," Sitharaman said. "Together, we aim to unlock India's potential under the visionary leadership of Prime Minister Modi," Sitharaman said as she began her address. "This budget is dedicated to accelerating growth, fuelled by our vision for a 'Viksit Bharat.' Our economy remains the fastest-growing among major nations," she added, Below are the latest developments from her budget speech: 'GAREEB, YOUTH, ANNADATA AND NARI' IN FOCUS Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman said the top focus of the budget would be on uplifting the poor, youth, farmers, and women. "In this Budget, the proposed development measures span 10 broad areas, focusing on poor, youth, annadata (farmer) and nari (women), spurring agricultural growth and productivity, building rural prosperity and resilience, and taking everyone together on an inclusive," she added. VISION FOR 'VIKSIT BHARAT' The Finance Minister outlined a vision for Viksit Bharat, focusing on zero poverty, access to quality education, and high-quality, affordable, and comprehensive healthcare for all. "Viksit Bharat encompasses zero poverty, 100% quality education, comprehensive healthcare," she added.BIG BOOST FOR FARMERS  Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced the PM Dhan Dhanya Krishi Yojana, targeting 100 districts with low yields, moderate crop intensity, and below-average credit access. The scheme is expected to benefit 1.7 crore farmers by improving agricultural productivity through crop diversification, better irrigation, and enhanced storage facilities. The government has also introduced a 6-year Atmanirbharta Mission in pulses, focusing on tur, urad, and masoor, with procurement support from central agencies. Additionally, a national mission on high-yielding seeds will be launched to enhance crop output. To support horticulture, a comprehensive programme for vegetable and fruit production will be introduced, ensuring farmers get remunerative prices. In Bihar, a Makhana Board will be established to boost fox nut production and processing. The Dhan Dhanya Krishi initiative, inspired by the Aspirational Districts Programme, aims to develop agricultural districts through state partnerships, ensuring long-term growth in the sector.ENHANCED CREDIT Guarantee COVER FOR MSMEs  The government will introduce measures to enhance productivity in labour-intensive sectors, Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced. The MSME credit guarantee cover will be doubled from Rs 5 crore to Rs 10 crore for micro-enterprises, enabling an additional Rs 1.5 lakh crore in credit over the next five years. Additionally, investment and turnover limits for MSME classification will be raised by 2.5 times and 2 times, respectively. A Manufacturing Mission under Make in India will provide policy support and a structured framework for small, medium, and large industries.Published By: sharangee Published On: Feb 1, 2025

Headline: Budget for common man, says PM Modi at Cabinet meet: SourcesBudget 2025-2026 is likely to provide a much-needed boost to the middle class amid high inflation with the nation's GDP growth projected to slow down to a four-year low of 6.4 per cent.
Content:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi said the Union Budget 2025-2026 is "for the common man", with the main focus on farmers, women and the young individuals of the nation. He made the remarks at a Cabinet meeting today ahead of Union Minister Nirmala Sitharaman presenting the Budget in Parliament, sources said. "This is the budget of 'GYAN' (garib, yuva, annadaata, rani)," the Prime Minister added. As Sitharaman presented the Budget today, she said it was "aimed at enhancing the spending power of the "rising middle class" population. Also echoing the PM's remark, she said the top focus would also be on uplifting the poor, youth, farmers, and women. "The focus of the Budget is taking everyone together on an inclusive path," she added. "We embark on a journey to unlock our country's immense potential. Our economy is the fastest growing among all the major economies. Confidence in India's potential has only grown."

This is Sitharaman's eighth Budget, while it is the first of the Modi 3.0 government. According to the Finance Minister, the focus areas of Budget 2025-2026 are to accelerate growth, secure inclusive development, invigorate private sector investment, uplift household spending, and enhance the spending power of India's rising middle class. She further outlined a vision for Viksit Bharat, focusing on zero poverty, access to 100 per cent quality education, and high-quality, affordable, and comprehensive healthcare for all.Published By: sharangee Published On: Feb 1, 2025Must Watch

Headline: No tax payable up to Rs 12 lakh income: Budget bonanza for middle classFinance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced that taxpayers with salaries up to Rs 12 lakh would not be required to pay tax in the new tax regime.
Content:
Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced in her budget speech that taxpayers with salaries up to Rs 12 lakh would not be required to pay tax in the new tax regime. 

 



Change in tax slabs
 The Union Minister also announced changes in the tax slabs.  The new tax regime offers zero income tax for earnings up to Rs 12 lakh (Rs 12.75 lakh for salaried taxpayers with standard deduction of Rs 75,000). What this effectively means is that people earning a salary of up to Rs 12,75,000 will not have to pay tax.  Manmeet Kaur, Partner at Karanjawala & Co, said, "The Government aims at Democracy, demography and demand recognising the middle class. Minimum tax slab raised to Rs 12 lakhs from Rs 7 lakhs in new regime + Rs 75000 standard deduction. Aims to boost both consumption and savings/investments." The government has introduced new tax slabs that aim to substantially reduce taxes for the middle class and are designed to leave more money in their hands, boosting household consumption, savings, and investment. The tax slabs and rates are as follows:
0-4 lakh rupees: Nil
4-8 lakh rupees: 5%
8-12 lakh rupees: 10%
12-16 lakh rupees: 15%
16-20 lakh rupees: 20%
20-24 lakh rupees: 25%
Above 24 lakh rupees: 30%
Published By: sharangee Published On: Feb 1, 2025

Headline: New Income Tax Bill next week, will focus on easing taxpayer convenience: Finance MinisterFinance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman to unveil new Income Tax Bill next week.
Content: Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman said that a new income tax bill will be announced next week. The bill would reflect the government’s decade-long efforts focused on enhancing taxpayer convenience. She mentioned the tax department’s approach of “trust first, scrutinise later," assuring the government’s continued commitment to ease compliance. "It will be simple to understand for taxpayers and reduce litigation," said Nirmala Sitharaman. Sandeep Chilana, Managing Partner, CCLaw, said, “A complete overhaul of the Income Tax Act is a bold step, but the real question is whether it will truly simplify compliance or just reorganise complexities.” “If the new law can bring predictability, reduce disputes, and ease tax administration, it will be a game-changer. However, businesses and professionals will be watching closely to see how it handles legacy issues like retrospective taxation, complex exemptions, and litigation-heavy provisions. The success of this reform will depend on how effectively it balances revenue needs with a taxpayer-friendly approach,” Chilana added. Manmeet Kaur, Partner at Karanjawala & Co. said, "In tax reform, the focus is on faceless assessment, faster return processing, and taxpayer convenience. With 90 lacs taxpayers revising their returns voluntarily, the government has increased the maximum time limit for filing revised returns from 2 years to 4 years to promote self assessment."advertisementPublished By: sharangee Published On: Feb 1, 2025

Headline: TDS reforms announced, limit for senior citizens doubledFinance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced an increase in the TDS threshold in the Union Budget 2025.
Content: Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman, while tabling the Union Budget 2025 announced reforms related to tax deductions at source (TDS), and focused on senior citizens easing their financial woes. Nirmala Sitharaman raised the annual limit for TDS on rent from Rs 2.40 lakh to Rs 6 lakh. She also announced rationalising the TDS for senior citizens and increasing the threshold from Rs 50,000 to Rs 1,00,000. Sandeep Chilana, Managing Partner, CCLaw, said, “The increase in the TDS threshold for various payments is a welcome move to ease the compliance burden on smaller businesses and individuals.” “By raising the threshold for TDS on rental income, professional fees, and other such payments, the government aims to simplify tax filing for taxpayers with smaller incomes or fewer transactions. At the same time, the planned rationalisation of TDS rates—by streamlining various categories into fewer, more uniform slabs—will significantly reduce confusion and compliance complexity across different sectors,” Chilana added.Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Feb 1, 2025

Headline: Everyone's praising you, Budget is very good: PM praises Nirmala SitharamanAccording to sources, the Prime Minister walked up to the bench where Nirmala Sitharaman was seated and expressed his gratitude for presenting her eighth and the Modi 3.0 government's first Budget today.
Content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Saturday congratulated Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman in Parliament after the latter presented the Union Budget 2025-26. "Everybody is praising you, the Budget is very good," he reportedly told Sitharaman. According to sources, the Prime Minister walked up to the bench where Sitharaman was seated and expressed his gratitude for presenting her eighth and the Modi 3.0 government's first Budget today. As she presented the Budget for this fiscal, Sitharaman said the top priorities will be to boost growth and enhance the spending power of the middle class, farmers, women and young people. She said it prioritises reforms in six key areas such as taxation, power, urban development, mining, the financial sector, and regulatory policies. In one of the biggest reliefs for the middle class, the Finance Minister announced that taxpayers with salaries up to Rs 12 lakh would not be required to pay tax in the new tax regime. Earlier in the day, the Prime Minister said the latest Budget is "for the common man", with the main focus on farmers, women and the young individuals of the nation. "This is the budget of 'GYAN' (garib, yuva, annadaata, rani)," he said while addressing a Cabinet meeting. While presenting the Budget, the Finance Minister echoed the PM's remark, saying the top focus would also be on uplifting the poor, youth, farmers, and women. "The focus of the Budget is taking everyone together on an inclusive path. We embark on a journey to unlock our country's immense potential. Our economy is the fastest growing among all the major economies. Confidence in India's potential has only grown," she stressed.Published By: sharangee Published On: Feb 1, 2025Tune InMust Watch

Headline: Will boost savings, investment, consumption, growth: PM Modi on 'force multiplier' BudgetWill boost savings, investment, consumption, growth: PM Modi on 'force multiplier' Budget
Content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi, applauding the Union Budget 2025, said that it will spike "savings, investment, consumption and growth" rapidly.  This is a developing story. It will be updated.Published By: sharangee Published On: Feb 1, 2025

Headline: Increased TDS limit, exemption for NSS: Big relief for senior citizens Budget 2025 announced major tax reforms for senior citizens, reducing their tax burden and giving a boost to their savings.
Content: Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman while presenting the Union Budget 2025 announced key tax reforms for senior citizens. She announced a raise in the limit of tax deduction on interest for senior citizens from Rs 50,000 to Rs 1,00,000. This announcement is seen as a welcome move for senior citizens as it aims to provide enhanced financial relief, reduce their tax burden and boost their savings. Sitharaman said that since very old National Savings Scheme accounts are no longer earning interest, individuals will now be able to withdraw their savings with no taxes being levied on them. She stated, “A number of senior and very senior citizens have very old National Savings Scheme accounts. As interest is no longer payable on such accounts, I propose to exempt withdrawals made from NSS by individuals on or after August 29, 2024. I am also proposing to allow similar treatment to NPS Vatsalya accounts as is available to normal NPS accounts, subject to overall limits.” Meghna Mishra, Senior Partner at Karanjawala & Co. said, “Overall, this budget is highly beneficial for the middle class and senior citizens, with key measures aimed at increasing savings and boosting consumption. The increase in the TCS threshold limit from â‚¹7 lakh to â‚¹10 lakh and the doubling of the TDS threshold for senior citizens provide significant relief.” In other words, by reducing the tax liabilities for senior citizens, the new framework aims to provide greater financial relief to the retirees and the elderly.Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Feb 1, 2025Tune InMust Watch

Headline: Harley-Davidson to get cheaper in India as Centre cuts tariff on premium bikesDonald Trump has consistently pushed for reducing trade barriers, especially on products that the US manufactures, and the high tariff on Harley-Davidson has been a point of contention in the past.
Content: Imported bikes, including American brands like Harley-Davidson, are set to become cheaper in India as the Union Budget 2025 has lowered import duties on high-capacity motorcycles. The Harley-Davidson tariff has been a point of contention for several years between India and the US, and the US President Donald Trump has been batting for its reduction. The Budget announcements are anticipated to alleviate these strains. The import duty on motorcycles with engine capacities up to 1,600 cc, which are imported as completely built-up (CBU) units, has been slashed from 50 per cent to 40 per cent. For motorcycles with engine capacities exceeding 1,600 cc, the reductions are even more substantial with a drop to 30 per cent from 50 per cent. Additionally, the import duty on semi-knocked down (SKD) kits has been reduced from 25 per cent to 20 per cent, and completely knocked down (CKD) units will now be taxed at 10 per cent, down from 15 per cent, according to the Union Budget presented on Saturday. This reduction in tariffs is expected to significantly lower the prices of Harley-Davidson motorcycles in India and will likely make these bikes more accessible to a broader range of customers, potentially increasing sales and market penetration for the brand. The decision to slash tariffs for imported bikes comes as Donald Trump threatened reciprocal taxes on countries that levy high tariffs on US goods. In December last year, asserting his tit-for-tat approach to taxation, Trump said that India’s taxes are excessive and stated, "If they tax us, we tax them the same amount". "The word reciprocal is important because if somebody charges us - India, we don't have to talk about our own - if India charges us 100 per cent, do we charge them nothing for the same? You know, they send in a bicycle, and we send them a bicycle. They charge us 100 and 200. India charges a lot," he said. According to data by the Ministry of Commerce, India was the US's largest trading partner last financial year. Published By: Ajmal Published On: Feb 2, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Gone bananas! Most Kerala tea-time snacks come under 18% GST From 'pazhampori' to 'ada' and 'undam pori,' beloved Malayali tea-time snacks find themselves caught in the bewildering GST maze. These humble delicacies come with an 18 per cent GST tag, all because they do not have the required 'classification' to be put elsewhere.
Content: Any Malayali would know what a ‘pazhampori’ is. Anyone who’s ever set foot in Kerala or befriended a Malayali, has also likely encountered the beloved pazhampori.  For those unfamiliar with it, it’s a banana pakora or bhajji—banana fritter—made with the ripe plantain banana, native to Kerala.  And this tax season, let’s bring another lesser known fact to light: it comes under the 18 per cent GST bracket. For comparison, peanut chikki (peanut candy) comes under the 5 per cent GST bracket.  The reason? This quintessential tea-time companion, lacks an HSN (Harmonised System of Nomenclature) code, and in the labyrinthine world of GST, products without specific classifications often default to the highest tax bracket. This isn’t just the tale of one Malayali snack. According to Kiran S Palakkal, president of Bakers Association of Kerala (BAKE), numerous Malayali delicacies, which barely last 6-8 hours on the shelf, face the same highest tax rate, all because of the complexity of how goods are classified under the Goods and Services Tax (GST) system.  Biju Prem Shankar, owner and COO of Fresh Products, a Kochi-based traditional snack company, shed light on the complex battle for tax clarity.  “For the past seven years, since GST was implemented, we have been asking for clarifications. Whatever clarification we have got so far is because we sat with chartered accountants, tax specialists and made a table of categories to classify each item and list them to be presented to the Authority for Advance Ruling (AAR),” he explained. Then why has BAKE not pushed for pazhampori, or for that matter ‘ada’, ‘unda’, ‘undam pori’, ‘manda kottiyappam’—all Malayali snacks that have a shelf life of less than 24 hours—to be brought under a lesser tax rate?  Because only GST-paying companies can petition for clarification, not associations, Kiran S Palakkal stated. “Fresh Products manufactures unniyappam, and banana, potato, tapioca, jackfruit chips, so we applied for tax clarification on these items. They were not assigned any HSN code prior to this, and we got the ruling only in 2019,” Biju clarified. An unniyappam is a sweet made of rice flour and jaggery fried in oil; it comes under the category of ‘sweet meat’ and thus charged 5 per cent GST. Chips items come under the ‘fried namkeen snacks’ made out of fruits or vegetables classification, hence charged 12 per cent GST. Biju got the GST sorted out for the products his company manufactured so that “during audits the GST Council wouldn’t come back and make us pay the differential taxes, in case we charged it less,” he said. “Almost all Malayali snacks are taxed at 18 per cent GST. And it is not a recent issue or confined to pazhampori or who can apply for clarification to the AAR,” Kiran explained, saying it is much more complex than just categorisation. “The minute difference exists because there are thousands of products without an HSN code. And to be honest, all of them cannot be assigned one,” Biju said. As Biju pointed out, “Even region to region, a simple item will have its recipe tweaked. For example, ingredients used to make unniyappam in Kerala are used to prepare adhirasam in Tamil Nadu, and they both would come under ‘sweet meat’ category.” Adding another layer of complexity is the point of sale. “These same items if sold at a restaurant or a hotel will only be charged 5 per cent GST, all because these come under service goods,” Kiran explained. A completely different impediment for manufacturers lay in trying to charge GST on their products. “Kerala bakeries are different from the bakeries in the North,” Biju said. “In the North, they are actual bakeries selling baked confectionery. For other items like Indian sweets, savoury snacks, they have sweet shops. Then there are coffee shops and cafes.” “But in Kerala, a bakery is a generic term for a coffee shop selling Indian sweets, confectionery, namkeen (savoury fried snacks) items all in one place,” he explained. That makes it even more complicated to assign GST, as product to product, it varies, Kiran said. “These bakeries in Kerala they buy our Malayali snacks from MSMEs, small housewives preparing these items in their kitchens, or cooperatives like Kudumbashree selling snacks and bakery items,” Biju revealed, “unlike in a supermarket where packaged food needs to have specified information on it.” “The complexity of varying GST on different food items was brought up last year, too, by the owner of Coimbatore-based restaurant chain Sree Annapoorna’s D Srinivasan,” Biju recollected. Biju was talking about the incident in September 2024 during an interaction between Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman and representatives of MSMEs and Chamber of Commerce in Coimbatore. Srinivasan had quipped: “The problem is that GST is applied differently to each item. For example, there is no GST on a bun, but if you add cream, GST becomes 18 per cent. Customers are asking to be given the bun and cream separately to save money.” “We are not trying to make a political statement. We, and I mean all food item manufacturers, especially the MSMEs, want a more uniform and simpler GST regulations to make our lives easier. This will benefit customers as well,” Kiran said. In the end, the pazhampori stands as a symbol of a larger issue: traditional culinary heritage clashing with modern tax complexity, where both makers and consumers hope for a simpler, more palatable solution. Until then, this beloved banana fritter carries not just the weight of its golden-brown crust, but also the burden of an 18 per cent GST tag. Published By: Deepthi Published On: Feb 2, 2025

Headline: Rupee not falling against any currency other than US dollar: Nirmala SitharamanFinance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman rejected criticism of the rupee's decline, stating it remains stable against most currencies despite a stronger US dollar. She attributed volatility to global factors and highlighted India's strong macroeconomic fundamentals.
Content: Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Sunday rejected criticism over the slide of the Indian rupee, saying it has depreciated only against a strengthening US dollar but remained stable against all other currencies because of the strong macroeconomic fundamentals. In an interview with PTI, she said a 3 per cent depreciation in the rupee against the US dollar in past few months is a matter of concern as it makes imports costlier, but she rejected criticism that the local currency has seen all-round weakness. "I am concerned but I will not accept the criticism that 'Oh Rupee is weakening!' Our macroeconomic fundamentals are strong. Rupee wouldn't be stable against all the currencies if the fundamentals were weak," she said. The Indian rupee has been under pressure in the last few months but it continues to be the least volatile currency against the US dollar among its Asian and global peers. The reasons for the rupee hitting record lows almost on a daily basis against the US dollar range from widening trade deficit to a surge in the dollar index after the US Federal Reserve hinted at fewer rate cuts in 2025. The Reserve Bank has reportedly spent USD 77 billion from its foreign exchange reserves to defend the rupee from falling sharply in the spot market, taking India's foreign exchange reserves down to USD USD 629.557 billion as on January 30, 2024, from USD 701.176 billion on October 4, 2024. "Rupee's volatility is against the dollar. Rupee has behaved in a far more stable fashion than any other currency," Sitharaman said. Rupee volatility is noticeable as the dollar is strengthening. "RBI also has been looking at ways in which it will interfere in the market only to stabilise the need for avoiding huge volatility based reasons. So we are all closely watching the situation," she said. She termed critics pointing to rupee volatility and depreciation as "a very quick argument". "But in today's dollar strengthening environment and in the new US administration, the rupee will have to be understood in its relationship with the dollar (and) the fluctuations which come as a result of that. Criticisms can come, but those criticisms will also have to go with a response with a bit more study," she added.Published By: Akhilesh NagariPublished On: Feb 2, 2025Tune InMust Watch

Headline: Markets in red: Sensex drops 500 points, rupee hits record lowThe S&P BSE Sensex plunged 516.30 points to 76,989.66, while the NSE Nifty50 fell by 230.90 points to 23,251.25 as of 9:25 AM.
Content:
Benchmark stock market indices tanked in early trade on Monday, falling nearly 1%, reacting to Budget 2025 and global cues, led by a decline in IT, metal, and energy stocks.  The S&P BSE Sensex plunged 516.30 points to 76,989.66, while the NSE Nifty50 fell by 230.90 points to 23,251.25 as of 9:25 AM.  Rupee also hit an all-time low, breaching 87 per US dollar for the first time. It fell 54 paise as US President Donald Trump's tariffs threat shook Asian currencies.  Dr. V K Vijayakumar, Chief Investment Strategist, Geojit Financial Services said that despite an excellent Budget the market will be under pressure from the Trump tariffs and the heightened global uncertainty these ‘initial round of tariffs’ has triggered. "It is important to understand that the 25% tariffs imposed on Mexico and Canada are to punish them for issues like immigration and illicit trade in fentanyl. Trump may use tariffs again against other countries on non-trade issues. China’s response to the 10% tariffs has been more responsible. For now, they have not reacted like Mexico and Canada by imposing tariffs on imports from the US. Instead, they are moving the WTO against the US action.

Now we don’t know how this will pan out. For now, India is not affected. Therefore, the impact on the Indian market will be less. But the spike in the dollar index to above 109.6 will trigger more selling by FIIs putting the market under pressure. Domestic consumption stocks will be relatively resilient since they stand to benefit from the income tax cuts announced in the Budget.advertisementPublished By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 3, 2025

Headline: Stock market today: Will Sensex, Nifty rally after Budget 2025? Stocks to buyMarket experts believe that while the budget had some positive aspects, certain key areas did not meet expectations.
Content: The stock market had a volatile session following the announcement of the Union Budget 2025. Despite some major announcements by Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman, the benchmark indices closed almost flat. The S&P BSE Sensex ended 5.39 points higher at 77,505.96, while the NSE Nifty50 declined by 26.25 points to settle at 23,482.15. Market experts believe that while the budget had some positive aspects, certain key areas did not meet expectations. Vinod Nair, Head of Research at Geojit Financial Services, said, "The market had mixed reactions due to the 10% year-on-year rise in capital expenditure (capex) for FY26, which was lower than expected. Sectors like railways, defence, and infrastructure, which the market relies on for performance, saw limited benefits, leading to cautious sentiment." He added that consumption-driven sectors, which should benefit the most from higher disposable income, did not have a major impact on the broad market due to their market position. However, in the coming months, the market will likely factor in the overall benefits of the tax cuts and business-friendly measures.Budget 2025: Key announcements impacting the market One of the biggest highlights of the budget was the income tax relief for individuals earning up to Rs 12 lakh. Sitharaman announced that people earning up to Rs 12 lakh per year under the new tax regime will not have to pay any income tax. “I am happy to announce that there will be no income tax payable on income up to Rs 12 lakh under the new regime,” the finance minister said in Parliament.Market outlook: What lies ahead? Kranthi Bathini, Director of Equity Strategy at WealthMills Securities, believes that while the budget is positive overall, the focus has been more on consumption than capex spending. "Markets had anticipated a stronger push towards capital expenditure, but the government has chosen a balanced approach. Defence spending has increased by 10%, which is still a positive sign for the markets," he said. He also pointed out that the next major trigger for the stock market will be the Reserve Bank of India's (RBI) monetary policy announcement in February. "If the RBI announces a rate cut of 25 basis points, it will boost liquidity in the market and improve sentiment for banking and financial services stocks. The market has been waiting for such a move for a long time. A rate cut will further support the overall market sentiment," he added.Which stocks can investors bet on? For investors looking at opportunities in the current market, consumption-related stocks could be a good bet. According to Kranthi Bathini, “Investors with a medium to long-term view should consider FMCG stocks, as these companies have been in consolidation mode for nearly a year. Given their attractive valuations, we may see buying interest in consumer discretionary and consumer staples in the coming months.” The long-term outlook for the Indian stock market remains positive, but economic growth will be a key factor. “The GDP growth is currently projected at 6.9-7%, but for stronger market performance, it should ideally be in the 7-8% range. This would act as a positive trigger for Indian markets over the long term,” Bathini added. (Disclaimer: The views, opinions, recommendations, and suggestions expressed by experts/brokerages in this article are their own and do not reflect the views of the India Today Group. It is advisable to consult a qualified broker or financial advisor before making any actual investment or trading choices.)Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 3, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Earning up to Rs 12 lakh? Here's how new marginal tax relief benefits youOne of the key highlights of Budget 2025 was that individuals earning up to Rs 12 lakh will not have to pay any income tax under the new tax regime.
Content:
Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced major income tax relief in Budget 2025, placing more money in the hands of taxpayers and bringing changes to how they calculate their dues. One of the key highlights is that individuals earning up to Rs 12 lakh will not have to pay any income tax under the new tax regime. However, this change has also led to some confusion, particularly regarding the terms 'rebate' and 'marginal relief.' With the introduction of new tax slabs, the Income Tax department has addressed concerns through explanations. While the rebate ensures that those earning up to Rs 12 lakh have no tax liability, marginal relief helps taxpayers who earn slightly above this limit so that they do not end up paying much higher taxes than those below the threshold.What is marginal tax relief? Marginal relief is a benefit given to individuals earning just over Rs 12 lakh. It ensures that the extra tax payable is not more than the additional income earned beyond the rebate limit. This prevents a situation where a small increase in income leads to a sharp jump in tax liability. For example, if a person earns Rs 12.10 lakh, their tax liability under the revised slabs would be Rs 61,500. However, with marginal relief, the individual would only need to pay Rs 10,000 as tax. This keeps their post-tax income close to that of someone earning Rs 12 lakh, who pays no tax.Who can benefit from marginal relief? Marginal relief is applicable only to individuals earning slightly above Rs 12 lakh. The maximum rebate available under the new tax regime is Rs 60,000. However, marginal relief applies only to incomes up to approximately Rs 12.75 lakh. Beyond this amount, regular tax slabs will apply, and no additional relief will be available.New tax slabs and rates Under the revised new tax regime, the updated income tax slabs are:
Rs 0-4 lakh – Nil
Rs 4-8 lakh – 5%
Rs 8-12 lakh – 10%
Rs 12-16 lakh – 15%
Rs 16-20 lakh – 20%
Rs 20-24 lakh – 25%
Above Rs 24 lakh – 30%
 While the rebate and marginal relief are aimed at benefiting salaried individuals and small business owners, they do not apply to special categories of income. Taxpayers with income from capital gains, lottery winnings, or other special-rate earnings are not eligible for this relief. The marginal relief benefit applies strictly to standard income taxed under Section 115BAC. Experts believe that these tax changes will help increase disposable income for the middle class. Manmeet Kaur, Partner at Karanjawala & Co, said, "The government aims to support the middle class by increasing the minimum tax-free slab from Rs 7 lakh to Rs 12 lakh under the new tax regime, along with a Rs 75,000 standard deduction. This move is expected to boost both consumption and savings."Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 3, 2025

Headline: Sensex tanks 700 points: Why is the stock market falling today?Stock market crash: Sensex plunged over 700 points and Nifty lost nearly 300 points in early trade.
Content:
The stock market opened in the red on Monday, with Sensex plunging over 700 points and Nifty losing nearly 300 points in early trade. The sharp decline comes despite the recent Budget announcements, as global factors and foreign investor activity continue to weigh on market sentiment. All the sectoral indices were trading in red other than Nifty consumer durables given the tax relief provided by the Finance Minister in her recent budget speech.  By 10 AM, the S&P BSE Sensex was down 707.67 points at 76,798.20, while the NSE Nifty50 fell by 242.55 points to 23,239.60. The decline in the stock market was led by heavyweight stocks like banking, financial, IT, metal, and energy sector stocks. Why is the market falling today? Several factors are putting pressure on Indian markets, including global trade tensions, foreign investor activity, and post-Budget adjustments.Global trade tensions after new US tariffs One of the biggest reasons for the market decline is the fresh round of tariffs imposed by the US on Mexico, Canada, and China over the weekend.
25% tariffs on Mexican and Canadian imports
10% tariffs on Chinese goods
 These measures have increased concerns about a possible trade war, leading to a decline in markets worldwide. Aditya Gaggar, Director of Progressive Shares, said, "The markets were expected to be in the red after the US imposed new tariffs on key trading partners, sparking fears of a trade war. Even though India is not directly affected, the global impact is being felt in our markets as well. Investors are also reacting to sectoral changes from the Budget, while focus has now shifted to the upcoming MPC (Monetary Policy Committee) meeting."Foreign investor selling puts pressure on markets Foreign portfolio investors (FPIs) have been selling Indian stocks in recent months.
FPIs sold nearly Rs 1 lakh crore worth of Indian equities in January.
After the Budget, investors are watching to see if this selling continues.
 Kranthi Bathini, Director of Equity Strategy at WealthMills Securities, said, "Foreign investors had reduced their participation before the Budget. Now, we need to see how FPIs behave today. Their activity will be crucial in determining if the markets recover or fall further. Trump’s tariff announcements have added more pressure on Indian markets in the short to medium term."Rupee hits all-time low The rupee fell to a record low of Rs 87.07 against the US dollar on Monday, as global currency markets reacted to fresh trade tensions. The decline came after US President Donald Trump imposed new tariffs on key trading partners, strengthening the US dollar and putting pressure on Asian currencies. The rupee dropped 0.5% in early trade, and traders expect further weakness throughout the day.Strengthening US dollar leads to FII outflows The US dollar index has risen above 109.6, making the American currency stronger. A stronger dollar usually leads to foreign institutional investors (FIIs) selling their holdings in emerging markets like India. Dr V K Vijayakumar, Chief Investment Strategist at Geojit Financial Services, explained, "Despite an excellent Budget, the market is under pressure due to Trump’s tariffs and rising global uncertainty. The 25% tariffs on Mexico and Canada were imposed for reasons beyond trade, and this could mean similar actions against other countries in the future. China’s response has been more measured so far, moving to the WTO instead of imposing counter-tariffs. But overall, the dollar’s strength is leading to more FII selling in India, adding to market pressure."Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 3, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Rupee hits an all-time low to go past Rs 87 against US dollar. Here's why Rupee hit an all-time low, breaching 87 per US dollar for the first time. The sharp fall was mainly triggered by three executive orders signed by Trump over the weekend.
Content: The rupee fell to a record low of Rs 87.07 against the US dollar on Monday, as global currency markets reacted to fresh trade tensions. The decline came after US President Donald Trump imposed new tariffs on key trading partners, strengthening the US dollar and putting pressure on Asian currencies. The rupee dropped 0.5% in early trade, and traders expect further weakness throughout the day.advertisementWhat caused the rupee to weaken? The sharp fall in the rupee was mainly triggered by three executive orders signed by Trump over the weekend. These orders imposed 25% tariffs on Mexican and Canadian imports and 10% tariffs on goods from China, starting Tuesday. The new trade restrictions have boosted the value of the US dollar, making it stronger against most global currencies. The US dollar’s strength has affected other Asian currencies as well. The dollar index (which measures the US dollar against six major currencies) rose 0.3% to 109.8. Meanwhile, the Chinese yuan, a key Asian currency, also weakened by 0.5% to 7.35 per US dollar. Since the yuan and rupee often move in the same direction, this decline has also put pressure on the Indian currency.Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 3, 2025

Headline: Explained: Why rupee fell past 87 against US dollar to a record lowThe Indian rupee (INR) dropped to an all-time low of Rs 87.1450 per dollar, down 0.6% from Friday. It may be noted that the rupee has fallen almost 4% since October 2024.
Content: The Indian rupee hit a record low of over 87 against the US dollar for the first time ever on Monday as a reaction to US President Donald Trump’s tariffs. Asian currencies and equities also slumped as a result of the tariffs, which have sparked fears of a trade war.The Indian rupee (INR) dropped to an all-time low of Rs 87.1450 per dollar, down 0.6% from Friday. It may be noted that the rupee has fallen almost 4% since October 2024.advertisementAnshul Chandak, head of treasury at RBL Bank, told news agency Reuters that the macros “look stacked up against the rupee”. “We expect it to stay under pressure over the next 6–8 weeks, Chandak said.WHAT TRIGGERED THE SLIDE? The Indian rupee hit a record low of over 87 against the US dollar for the first time ever on Monday as a reaction to US President Donald Trump’s tariffs. Asian currencies and equities also slumped as a result of the tariffs, which have sparked fears of a trade war. The Indian rupee (INR) dropped to an all-time low of Rs 87.1450 per dollar, down 0.6% from Friday. It may be noted that the rupee has fallen almost 4% since October 2024. Anshul Chandak, head of treasury at RBL Bank, told news agency Reuters that the macros “look stacked up against the rupee”. “We expect it to stay under pressure over the next 6–8 weeks, Chandak said.WHAT TRIGGERED THE SLIDE? The sharp fall in the rupee was mainly triggered by three executive orders signed by Trump over the weekend. These orders imposed 25% tariffs on Mexican and Canadian imports and 10% tariffs on goods from China, starting Tuesday. The new trade restrictions have boosted the value of the US dollar, making it stronger against most global currencies. The US dollar’s strength has affected other Asian currencies as well, including the Chinese yuan. And since the yuan and rupee often move in the same direction, this decline has also put pressure on the Indian currency. The dollar index (which measures the US dollar against six major currencies) also rose 0.3% to 109.8. The tariffs imposed by Donald Trump have also fuelled worries of a full-scale trade war, with global brokerage firm Morgan Stanley saying that “the risk of our worst fears materialising has risen” "Risks are skewed towards further escalation. Asia will be exposed on account of high trade orientation and seven economies run large trade surpluses with the US,” it added. Not just the rupee, but Indian stock markets also tanked as a result of the Trump tariffs, which overshadowed the positive impact of the Union Budget 2025. According to analysts, domestic stock markets could also remain under pressure as Trump’s tariffs could likely fuel more FII outflows.Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 3, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Volkswagen sues Indian authorities over $1.4 billion tax notice: ReportThe tax dispute began in September 2024, when Indian authorities issued a $1.4 billion tax notice to Volkswagen's Skoda Auto Volkswagen India unit.
Content: German carmaker Volkswagen has filed a lawsuit against Indian authorities, seeking to cancel a $1.4 billion tax demand, calling it "impossibly enormous" and contradictory to India’s import tax rules, reported news agency Reuters.  The company has warned that this dispute could impact its $1.5 billion investments in India and harm the country’s foreign investment climate, according to court documents reviewed by Reuters. The tax dispute began in September 2024, when Indian authorities issued a $1.4 billion tax notice to Volkswagen’s Skoda Auto Volkswagen India unit. Officials alleged that Volkswagen misclassified its imports to pay lower customs duties. According to the government, Volkswagen broke down imports of some VW, Skoda, and Audi cars into separate components, instead of declaring them as completely knocked down (CKD) units. CKD units attract a higher 30-35% import tax. Individual car parts are taxed at a lower 5-15% rate. Authorities claim Volkswagen imported nearly complete vehicles in an unassembled condition but used a loophole to pay less tax by classifying them as separate parts.Volkswagen’s defence: The government knew about this model Volkswagen has denied any wrongdoing and says it had been transparent about its import model. The company argues that it informed Indian authorities in 2011 about its "part-by-part import" method and had received official clarifications supporting this approach. The lawsuit, filed on January 29 in the Mumbai High Court, as quoted by Reuters, said, "The tax notice is in complete contradiction of the position held by the government ... (and) places at peril the very foundation of faith and trust that foreign investors would desire to have in the actions and assurances of the administration." Volkswagen has said it is using all legal options while continuing to cooperate with authorities to ensure compliance with local and global laws. A government source told Reuters that if Volkswagen loses the case, the total tax and penalty amount could reach $2.8 billion. For context, in 2023-24, Volkswagen India reported sales of $2.19 billion (Rs 18,100 crore) and made a net profit of just $11 million. This means the tax penalty could be far greater than Volkswagen India’s annual revenue and multiple times its profit.Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 3, 2025Must Watch

Headline: India reviewing crypto stance amid global policy shift: ReportIndians have poured money into cryptocurrencies in recent years despite the country's tough regulatory stance and steep trading taxes.
Content: India is reviewing its stance on cryptocurrencies due to shifting attitudes towards virtual asset in other countries, a senior government official told Reuters on Sunday. The review, which follows crypto-friendly policy announcements by U.S. President Donald Trump, could further delay publication of a discussion paper on cryptocurrencies that was due for release in September 2024. "More than one or two jurisdictions have changed their stance towards cryptocurrency in terms of the usage, their acceptance, where do they see the importance of crypto assets. In that stride, we are having a look at the discussion paper once again," India's Economic Affairs Secretary Ajay Seth said in an interview. Seth said that because such assets "don't believe in borders", India's stance cannot be unilateral. He did not specifically mention the United States, where Trump last week ordered the creation of a cryptocurrency working group tasked with proposing new digital asset regulations and exploring the creation of a national cryptocurrency stockpile, making good on his promise to overhaul U.S. crypto policy. Indians have poured money into cryptocurrencies in recent years despite the country's tough regulatory stance and steep trading taxes. India's Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU) issued show-cause notices to nine offshore cryptocurrency exchanges in December 2023 for non-compliance with local rules. Binance, the world's biggest crypto exchange, was hit with a fine of 188.2 million rupees ($2.25 million) in June 2024, a month after it registered with the FIU in an effort to resume operations in the country. Last year, India's market watchdog recommended that several regulators oversee trade in cryptocurrencies, in a sign that at least some authorities in the country are open to allowing the use of private virtual assets. That position stood in contrast to statements by the nation's central bank, which has maintained that private digital currencies represent a macroeconomic risk.Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 3, 2025

Headline: Earn over Rs 12.75 lakh? You can still pay zero tax under new regimeWith a standard deduction of Rs 75,000 under the new regime, salaried taxpayers earning up to Rs 12.75 lakh annually do not need to pay any tax. But what if you have a higher annual income, say Rs 13 lakh or more? You could still end up paying no tax.
Content: The new income tax regime got a major revamp in the Union Budget 2025, aimed at benefiting middle-class taxpayers. The tax-free threshold has been increased from Rs 7 lakh to Rs 12 lakh. And with a standard deduction of Rs 75,000, salaried taxpayers earning up to Rs 12.75 lakh annually do not need to pay any tax. But what if you have a higher annual income, say Rs 13 lakh or more? You can still end up paying no tax. This is because you can still opt for eligible deductions under the new income tax regime. For instance, a person can claim deductions under the new tax regime for investments in the national pension scheme (NPS). Under Section 80CCD(2), deduction of up to 14 is available on an employer's contribution to the National Pension Scheme (NPS) However, the taxpayer's NPS contribution is not deductible under the new regime and can only be claimed under the old regime. Let’s break it down with an example.  For an annual income of Rs 13.5 lakh, assuming a 50% basic salary of Rs 6.75 lakh, an NPS contribution of Rs 94,500 (at 14%), and a standard deduction of Rs 75,000, the taxable income reduces to Rs 11.8 lakh, resulting in zero tax under the new regime. Taxpayers who are opting for the new tax regime should note that an annual income of up to Rs 13.7 lakh can be free from tax if the employer contributes to NPS. However, at the moment, not many corporates have adopted the NPS benefit for employers. In fact, not many employees are also keen on signing up for NPS due to the long lock-in period and partial 60% withdrawal on maturity rule. The remaining 40% has to be invested in an annuity scheme for a steady source of income (pension) after retirement.Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 3, 2025Must Watch

He also highlighted that a salaried taxpayer earning Rs 12.75 lakh annually will not be required to pay tax due to Rs 75,000 standard deduction.

Headline: Trade war fears spook markets: Sensex, Nifty take a hit as rupee weakensThe S&P BSE Sensex tanked by 319.22 points to end at 77,186.74, while the NSE Nifty50 lost 128.85 points to close at 23,353.30.
Content: Benchmark stock market indices closed lower on Monday, as the rupee hit a record low, denting investor sentiment due to the ongoing tariff war.  The S&P BSE Sensex tanked by 319.22 points to end at 77,186.74, while the NSE Nifty50 lost 128.85 points to close at 23,353.30.  Stock market fell by nearly 1% in early trade, resulting in close to Rs 5 lakh crore loss in investor wealth, with the Sensex plunging close to 750 points. However, the indices recovered in the afternoon session to close 0.5% lower.  Vinod Nair, Head of Research, Geojit Financial Services said that the global market got unsettled amid the onset of the 'Trade War,' as tariff conflicts between the US and other nations are unlikely to yield any economic benefits. "Instead, it may cause challenges to the global economy, heightening global financial risks. International trade, which had flourished under the framework of globalisation, now faces threats from the new protectionist policies. Front and contour tariffs are expected to make the world less efficient and elevate global inflation & interest rates," he added.  Another major trigger for the market decline was the declining rupee, which hit its all-time low as foreign investors continued to sell.  VLA Ambala, Co-Founder of Stock Market Today said that the rupee has weakened further and traded at a record low against the USD at 87.17. "This depreciation has shaken foreign investors' trust in our nation’s economic stability, adding to their apprehension about India’s high stock valuation. January recorded the second-highest FII offloading in a month amounting to Rs 87,374.66 crore, after Oct 2024’s INR 114,445.89 crore, and so far in February FIIs have sold INR 1,327.09 crore and purchased stocks worth only Rs 165.26 crore. The rising global trade concerns and policy uncertainties suggest that this selling momentum could continue," she added.  Bajaj Finance topped the gainers' chart on Nifty50 with a rise of 4.47%, while Mahindra & Mahindra advanced 2.91%. IT major Wipro gained 2.84%, followed by telecom giant Bharti Airtel which added 2.03%. Two-wheeler manufacturer Eicher Motors rounded off the gainers with a 1.93% increase. On the losing front, infrastructure major Larsen & Toubro saw the steepest decline, dropping 4.68%. Oil and Natural Gas Corporation fell 4.31%, while Bharat Electronics Limited declined 3.78%. State-owned Bharat Petroleum Corporation shed 3.38%, and Hero MotoCorp slipped 3.32%. The day's trading pattern reflected investors' preference for financial and technology sectors, while banking, FMCG, metal, infrastructure and energy stocks remained under pressure. "On technical charts, Nifty formed a Bullish Pin Bar in the latest session, but the index is still away from its key support. In this situation, I suggest following a sell-on-rise approach," said Ambala. Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 3, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Explained: Why Volkswagen has sued Indian authoritiesAccording to the government, Volkswagen broke down imports of some VW, Skoda, and Audi cars into separate components, instead of declaring them as completely knocked down (CKD) units.
Content: German carmaker Volkswagen has filed a lawsuit against Indian authorities to challenge a $1.4 billion (Rs 11,125 crore) tax demand. The company has called the demand contradictory to India’s import tax rules. Volkswagen has warned that this tax dispute could affect its $1.5 billion investment in India and impact the country’s appeal as a destination for foreign investment. The case is currently being heard in the Bombay High Court. "Volkswagen AG has instituted legal proceedings against the Union of India, challenging an unprecedented and exorbitant tax demand of $1.4 billion, which the automaker contends is not only legally unsustainable but also violative of the fundamental principles of taxation jurisprudence," said Tushar Kumar, Advocate, Supreme Court of India. WHY HAS VOLKSWAGEN FILED THE LAWSUIT? Kumar explained that the crux of Volkswagen’s petition lies in the allegation that Indian tax authorities have arbitrarily and retrospectively sought to reclassify its imports of automotive components as completely knocked-down (CKD) units, thereby imposing a substantially higher duty structure of 30-35%, as opposed to the 5-15% duty applicable to component imports.  "The Income Tax Department claims that the Company has wrongfully categorised nearly complete cars as individual parts, allowing it to pay lower customs duties. As per the Indian Tax rates, Importing completely knocked-down (CKD) car kits attracts a lower 5-15% duty and Importing fully assembled cars (Completely Built Units - CBU) incurs a 30-35% duty. The claim of the Govt was that Volkswagen took undue advantage of the CKD rate and has now issued a demand to recover the difference," said Alay Razvi, Managing Partner, Accord Juris. IMPLICATIONS OF THE LAWSUIT Volkswagen denied all the allegations and claimed that the classification was done with government approval by following proper procedure and necessary clearances were obtained. However, the tax demand contradicts India’s own regulations. Volkswagen explained how the Tax Department is taking inconsistent stance.  "Volkswagen explained how it is jeopardising its reputation in the Indian market. The case stands posted to February 05, 2025. In the event the case is dismissed, Volkswagen can file an appeal before the Supreme Court," said Razvi.  The ruling against Volkswagen could impact the tax treatment of other companies operating in India. "Volkswagen will have to pay heavy tax demand which can have a major impact on the company and subsequently other companies who will end up paying the said amount. It could lead to financial crises in the automobile sector. In the event , Volkswagen  is successful, it will set a precedent on how similar cases can be handled in the future," added Razvi. Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 3, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Sensex, Nifty rebound after sharp fall after global trade concerns easeThe S&P BSE Sensex gained 522.62 points to 77,709.36, while the NSE Nifty50 rose 142.15 points to 23,503.20 as of 9:30 AM.
Content:
Benchmark stock market indices opened higher on Tuesday, gaining over half a percent in early trade after having seen a sharp fall in the previous session.  The S&P BSE Sensex gained 522.62 points to 77,709.36, while the NSE Nifty50 rose 142.15 points to 23,503.20 as of 9:30 AM.  Dr. V K Vijayakumar, Chief Investment Strategist, Geojit Financial Services said that the decision taken by Trump to temporarily freeze the tariffs on Mexico and Canada and start negotiations is a clear indication of President Trump’s strategy: "That is, impose tariffs and then negotiate and strike a deal. The same strategy is likely to be tried with China, too. It is important to understand that a full-blown trade war will be damaging for the US, too," he added. 

The decline in the dollar index to 108 is a positive development. Emboldened by the excellent Budget, investors, especially DIIs, are likely to step up investment, particularly in discretionary consumption segments. Cars, scooters, motorcycles, white goods like air conditioners and washing machines, jewellery, hotels and food delivery businesses are the segments that will benefit from the Budget and, therefore, these are the segments to focus on.Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 4, 2025

Headline: Will PF deposit interest rate go up? EPFO board to meet on February 28The Central Board of Trustees (CBT), which is led by the Union Minister for Labour and Employment, is the top decision-making body of the (Employees Provident Fund Organisation) EPFO.
Content: The Central Board of Trustees (CBT) of the Employees Provident Fund Organisation (EPFO) is set to meet on February 28 to decide the interest rate on provident fund deposits for the financial year 2024-25. This decision is expected to be one of the key discussions at the meeting. The official agenda for the meeting has not yet been shared, but media reports indicate that finalising the interest rate for the current financial year will be a priority.  An official communication confirmed that the 237th meeting of the CBT will take place on February 28. “The 237th meeting of the CBT of the EPF is scheduled to be held on February 28,” said an official document as quoted by Businesstoday.in.  The CBT, which is led by the Union Minister for Labour and Employment, is the top decision-making body of the EPFO. It includes representatives from employer associations, trade unions, and central and state government officials. For the financial year 2023-24, the EPFO had set the interest rate on provident fund deposits at 8.25%, an increase from 8.15% in 2022-23. The upcoming meeting will decide whether the interest rate will be increased further or remain unchanged. The last CBT meeting was held on November 30, 2024, where a key decision was taken regarding interest payments on PF settlements. Earlier, interest-bearing claims were not processed between the 25th and the end of each month, leading to a loss of interest for members. The new rule ensures that interest will be paid until the date of settlement, which is expected to reduce delays and improve fund management. According to the EPFO’s Annual Report for 2023-24, which was approved in the previous CBT meeting, the number of contributing establishments increased by 6.6% to 7.66 lakh from 7.18 lakh in 2022-23. The number of active EPF members also saw a rise of 7.6%, growing from 6.85 crore in 2022-23 to 7.37 crore in 2023-24. With more people contributing to the EPF and expectations of higher returns, the interest rate decision at the upcoming meeting will be closely watched as millions of employees rely on these deposits for their long-term savings. Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 4, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Sensex jumps over 700 points: 3 reasons why stock market is rising todayStock market today: At 9:53 AM, the S&P BSE Sensex was up 731.43 points at 77,918.17, while the NSE Nifty50 gained 203.30 points to trade at 23,564.35.
Content: The stock market opened in green on Tuesday, recovering from losses seen in the previous session. The Sensex jumped over 700 points, while the Nifty gained more than 200 points, both rising nearly 1% in early trade. The rupee had hit an all-time low of 87.28 against the US dollar on Monday, following tariff-related developments leading to a decline in the previous session. However, markets rebounded on positive global cues. At 9:53 AM, the S&P BSE Sensex was up 731.43 points at 77,918.17, while the NSE Nifty50 gained 203.30 points to trade at 23,564.35.WHY IS STOCK MARKET RISING TODAY?  The rally in the stock market can be attributed to three key factors: Global market recovery - After a sharp fall in equity markets worldwide on Monday, positive signs emerged on Tuesday. The US administration decided to temporarily freeze tariffs on Mexico and Canada, sparking optimism among investors. Experts believe this strategy of imposing tariffs and then negotiating could be extended to China as well, reducing concerns of a prolonged trade war. Dr V K Vijayakumar, Chief Investment Strategist at Geojit Financial Services, said, “The decline in the dollar index to 108 is a positive development. Investors, especially domestic institutional investors (DIIs), are likely to increase their investments, particularly in discretionary consumption segments such as automobiles, white goods, jewellery, hotels, and food delivery businesses.” Rupee recovery - The Indian rupee recovered by 13 paise, moving from its all-time closing low of 87.28 to 86.98 against the US dollar. The improvement in the currency’s value eased concerns among foreign investors, helping boost market sentiment. Kranthi Bathini, Director of Equity Strategy at WealthMills Securities, said, “The global cues are quite positive, and statements from the US about relaxing trade tariffs have also supported the market’s recovery. After two days of losses, buying interest from Indian investors has increased. Additionally, the services PMI index has touched a six-month high of 57, indicating a pickup in economic activity.” Rate cut expectations from RBI - Investors are anticipating a 25-basis-point rate cut in the upcoming RBI monetary policy. This expectation has added to market optimism, as lower interest rates can reduce borrowing costs and boost economic growth. Bathini added, “The market is already factoring in the possibility of an interest rate cut. If the RBI takes this step, it could further support economic recovery and corporate earnings.”Sectors leading the rally Most sectoral indices were trading in the green, with banking, financials, IT, and auto stocks showing strong gains. The FMCG sector was the only one in red, as some profit booking was seen after last week’s gains. Stocks of NBFCs like Bajaj Finance, M&M Finance, and Shriram Finance were showing strength, indicating continued positive momentum in the sector. Aditya Gaggar, Director at Progressive Shares, noted, “We continue to remain bullish on the auto sector, with a stock-specific approach. A short-term bottom seems to be in place, but further confirmation is needed. NBFCs are performing well, and we expect this trend to continue.”Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 4, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Will Budget 2025 transform agriculture and bring rural prosperity?Budget 2025 aims to modernise India's agricultural landscape and reinforces the government's commitment to sustainable agriculture and farmer empowerment.
Content:
Budget 2025 has announced several key reforms and policies for transforming the country’s agriculture sector by boosting growth and productivity, thereby building rural prosperity and resilience. One of the key announcements by the Finance Minister Nirmal Sitharaman was the introduction of 'Prime Minister Dhan-Dhaanya Krishi Yojana', which aims to enhance agricultural development, crop diversification and adoption of sustainable agricultural practices. This programme is expected to benefit 1.7 crore farmers across 100 districts with low productivity. In order to address the issue of underemployment in agriculture, the government has announced the ‘Rural Prosperity and Resilience’ programme. It aims to create job opportunities in rural areas and focusses on rural women and youth, young, marginal and small farmers, and landless families. The scheme also aims to incorporate global and domestic best practices, with financial support from multilateral development banks. Sanjay Shirodkar, Co-Founder, Wavar said, “The Union Budget 2025-26 reinforces the government’s commitment to sustainable agriculture and farmer empowerment. The introduction of the PM Dhan Dhanya Krishi Yojana and the enhanced credit support for farmers are welcome steps that will drive innovation and technology adoption in the sector.” Next, a 'National Mission on High Yielding Seeds' will be implemented to improve seed quality, ensuring high yields, pest resistance and climate resilience. Budget 2025 also introduced the ‘Mission for Cotton Productivity’, to facilitate improvements in productivity and sustainability of cotton farming. Moreover, to ease credit access, the government has announced Kisan Credit Cards (KCC) for extending short-term loans, which would benefit 7.7 crore farmers, fishermen, and dairy farmers. Rajnikant Behera, Executive Director – Finance, RSB Group has welcomed this move. “With agriculture as a key growth driver, expanded KCC credit (short-term loans of up to Rs 5 lakh), will enable farmers to invest in advanced machinery, driving demand for quality agricultural equipment,” he mentioned. Vasu Naren, Chairman & Managing Director, Sona Machinery said, “With the right policy support and effective implementation, these initiatives in the Union Budget 2025 will modernise India’s agricultural landscape, enhance value addition, and accelerate the country’s journey toward self-sufficiency in key commodities." 
Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Feb 4, 2025Tune InMust Watch

Headline: Consumption vs capex: Has the government prioritised spending over growth?Budget 2025 provided tax relief for taxpayers, but the government also maintained its fiscal deficit target at 4.4% of GDP.
Content: The key focus of Budget 2025 was income tax relief for the middle class, which was expected given the anticipation of boosting consumption amid a slowdown in the GDP.  The government also maintained its fiscal deficit target at 4.4% of GDP while focusing on improving the ease of doing business. Unlike previous Budgets, which aimed to boost capital expenditure (capex) by increasing allocations, this time the priority seems to be ensuring efficient use of funds rather than just raising spending. However, an important point to discuss is, has the government given more importance to consumption at the cost of capital expenditure? Or has it struck a balance between the two? Sunil Damania, Chief Investment Officer at MojoPMS, believes the Finance Minister has not shifted focus away from capital expenditure. "If we analyse the total capex—which includes central government spending, grants provided to state governments, and investments by central public sector enterprises—it is projected to reach Rs 20 lakh crore by FY2026. For an economy with a size nearing Rs 350 lakh crore, this level of capex is highly significant and supportive of growth," he said.  He also highlighted the Rs 1 lakh crore tax rebate announced in the Budget. Unlike a one-time stimulus, this is a recurring benefit that will improve disposable incomes over the long term, thereby boosting consumption. According to him, the government has adopted a well-balanced strategy, promoting both capex and consumption to sustain economic momentum.FOCUS ON CONSUMPTION? Some experts, however, feel that the government has moved away from aggressive capex-led growth. Harsh Madhusudan Gupta, Fund Manager at Ionic Asset, believes the government has “effectively closed the post-Covid capex mega-push chapter” and is now letting consumption and private capex lead the next phase of economic growth. He pointed out that the large income tax cuts in the new tax regime were aimed at increasing disposable income and driving consumption. “A faster-than-expected reduction in the fiscal deficit to 4.4% of GDP could help bond yields ease, especially as India enters the Bloomberg Emerging Market Bond Index this week. This also makes a rate cut by the RBI in its February 7 policy meeting more likely,” he added. Concerns were raised about Foreign Portfolio Investments (FPI) after heavy outflows in January. However, experts expect a recovery in February. Damania said that the US stock market appears overvalued and is facing uncertainties due to tariff-related policies. This could lead to increased capital flows into emerging markets like India. “As for the US tariffs, it is unclear how beneficial they will be for their economy. Markets will react to developments as they unfold,” he said.Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 4, 2025Tune InMust Watch

Headline: 5 key tax reforms for middle class introduced in Budget 2025 The new tax structure announced in the Union Budget 2025 aims to ease the financial burden of the middle class, enhancing their disposable income and giving a boost to their consumption levels.
Content:
The Union Budget 2025 presented by Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman on February 1, 2025, witnessed several key income tax reforms aimed especially at the middle class. These reforms aim to simplify the tax structure and ease the compliance burden. “The new bill will be clear and direct in text with close to half of the present law, in terms of both chapters and words. It will be simple to understand for taxpayers and tax administration, leading to tax certainty and reduced litigation,” said the FM in her budget speech. That said, let us look at the important tax-related announcements from Budget 2025.TAX-FREE INCOME UP TO RS 12 LAKH Under the new tax regime, there will be no tax payable up to income of Rs 12 lakh. With the standard deduction of Rs 75,000, the effective income limit stands at Rs 12.75 lakh for the salaried class.REVISION OF INCOME TAX SLABS The government has proposed revisions to the tax slabs under the new regime: 0-4 lakh rupees: Nil
4-8 lakh rupees: 5%
8-12 lakh rupees: 10%
12-16 lakh rupees: 15%
16-20 lakh rupees: 20%
20-24 lakh rupees: 25%
Above 24 lakh rupees: 30% This new tax structure aims to ease the financial burden of the middle class, enhancing their disposable income and giving a boost to their consumption levels.TAX RELIEF FOR SENIOR CITIZENS Budget 2025 has increased the limit for tax deduction on interest from Rs 50,000 to Rs 1,00,000 for senior citizens. This would help result in greater savings among retirees.EXTENSION IN UPDATED TAX RETURN FILING Union Budget 2025 has extended the time limit to four years from the current two years for filing the updated income tax returns, thereby allowing more time for taxpayers to voluntarily disclose their correct income.TAX EXEMPTION ON NSS WITHDRAWALS Withdrawals made from the National Pension Scheme (NPS) on or after August 29, 2024, will be exempted from tax. Nirmala Sitharaman in her budget speech mentioned, “A number of senior and very senior citizens have very old National Savings Scheme accounts. As interest is no longer payable on such accounts, I propose to exempt withdrawals made from NSS by individuals on or after the 29th of August, 2024.”Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Feb 4, 2025Tune InMust Watch

Headline: No plans to shut it down: Nirmala Sitharaman on old tax regimeFinance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman table the Union Budget 2025 on February 1, 2025.
Content: The Finance Minister said that she has no plans to scrap the old tax regime. "I don't have any proposal to shut it down," said Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman on plans for the old tax regime. In an event orgainsed by Business Today, the Finance Minister talked about the old tax regime. When being asked if she wants the entire taxpayer population to shift to the new tax regime, Sitharaman stated she wants the country’s tax structure to be simple and wants to reduce the compliance burden. She mentioned that the government wants to introduce the New Income Tax Act as the old Income Tax Act which came into being in 1961, is very exhaustive and has had several additions to it. Nirmala Sitharaman said that as long as people want to take exemptions from the old tax regime, she has no plans to scrap it. The Finance Minister, while presenting her budget speech in the Parliament on February 1, 2025, said, “The objectives of my proposals are personal income tax reforms with special focus on the middle class, rationalisation of TDS/TCS for easing difficulties, encouraging voluntary compliance, reducing compliance burden, ease of doing business, employment and investment.”Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Feb 4, 2025

Headline: Market rally: Sensex jumps 1,397 points, Nifty nears 23,750 as bulls take chargeThe S&P BSE Sensex surged by 1397.07 points to close at 78,583.81, while the NSE Nifty50 added 378.20 points to end at 23,739.25.
Content: Benchmark stock market indices witnessed a bull run on Tuesday, with Sensex and Nifty closing over 1.5% higher amid positive cues. The momentum looks set to continue, but it may face resistance at the 24,000 mark," said Aditya Gaggar Director of Progressive Shares.
