On the losing side, retail major Trent Limited witnessed heavy selling, tumbling 6.44%. Indian Hotels Company dropped 4.24%, while Britannia Industries fell 1.28%. Two-wheeler manufacturer Hero MotoCorp declined 1.09%, and Nestle India slipped 0.74%. The day's trading pattern highlighted investors' strong appetite for financial and infrastructure sectors, while consumer-focused stocks remained under pressure. "For tomorrow's session, Nifty could expect support at 23,600 and 23,700 and face resistance between 23,850 and 23,950," said VLA Ambala, Co-Founder of Stock Market Today. Headline: Why Hindenburg went after Adani group? Nathan Anderson breaks silenceHindenburg Research founder Nathan Anderson maintained that all the firm's reports, including the one on Adani Group, were accurate.
Content: Hindenburg Research founder Nathan Anderson spoke for the first time about why the US-based short-selling firm decided to investigate the Adani Group. In an interview with news agency PTI, Anderson said the decision was based on “red flags” raised by some media groups. He also defended the firm’s findings, saying he stood by all the reports published by Hindenburg.  “We initially saw media articles outlining red flags, took a closer look, and just kept following the evidence,” he said in the interview. The Hindenburg report, released in January 2023, accused the Adani Group of using offshore companies to inflate revenue and manipulate stock prices while accumulating debt. The report led to a sharp fall in the stock prices of Adani Group companies, wiping out over $150 billion from their market value. However, over time, the group managed to recover a major portion of the losses. Addressing claims that Hindenburg’s report was an attack on India’s economic growth, Anderson rejected the allegations. “We have always believed in India’s potential and view market transparency and strong corporate governance as key factors that can fuel India's growth story,” he said. Adani Group had strongly denied the allegations made in the report and called it a deliberate attempt to damage its reputation. The matter reached the Supreme Court of India, which later ruled that no further investigation was needed beyond the ongoing probe by market regulator Sebi. In January 2025, Anderson announced that he was shutting down Hindenburg Research. He clarified that the decision was not due to legal or personal threats. “As to why I retired, is all in the letter. It is not based on any threat, health issue, personal issue, or otherwise,” he said. Many questioned why Anderson did not step away and let someone else run Hindenburg. He responded by saying that the brand was too closely tied to him. “Hindenburg is basically synonymous with me. If it was a software application or a bicycle factory, you could sell the application or the factory. But when it's research driven by me, you can't really just hand that off,” he explained. However, he hinted that his former team might continue working under a different brand. “I am happy to support the team if they want to launch a new brand, which I expect they will,” he said. Despite shutting down Hindenburg, Anderson maintained that all the firm’s reports, including the one on Adani Group, were accurate. “We 100% stand by all of our research findings,” he said.Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 4, 2025Must Watch

Headline: I will think about India: Nirmala Sitharaman as Trump 2.0 goes big on cryptoFinance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman said that the government during its G20 presidency pushed for a global understanding of crypto regulations and how to tackle trading in cryptocurrencies.
Content: Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Tuesday clarified that the government is not against distributed ledger technology. But she mentioned the government’s stance on transparency in transactions, particularly the sources of funds and the individuals involved in them. At the Budget Round Table 2025 event organised by India Today and Business Today, Sitharaman did not clearly mention any policy related to cryptocurrencies or VDAs (virtual digital assets). When mentioned that 97% of the country’s crypto trading has shifted offshore, which has led to a loss of about Rs 6,000 crore in TDS revenue to the government, owing to the government’s strict stance on cryptocurrencies, the FM took note of it. When asked if President Donald Trump’s crypto-friendly stance may influence India’s approach, Sitharaman said, “We are not against distributed ledger technology.” However, the government is focused on tackling these transactions, hence it introduced TDS and TCS for cryptocurrency assets. Sitharaman mentioned that the government pushed for a global understanding of crypto regulations and how to tackle trading in cryptocurrencies during its G20 presidency. When asked about the contrasting approach of Washington DC and Delhi on cryptos, Sitharaman said, “That’s right, we are India. I will think about India.” The Union Budget 2025 did not announce any major policy regarding cryptocurrencies. The budget document mentioned, "It is proposed to bring amendment in the Act to provide for that a prescribed reporting entity in respect of a crypto-asset shall furnish information in respect of a transaction in such crypto asset, in a statement as prescribed. It is also proposed to align the definition of virtual digital asset accordingly."Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Feb 4, 2025

Headline: How to get a student credit card? Check eligibility and documents requiredWhile the credit card can be a valuable financial tool, students must be aware of its potential misuse and pitfalls.
Content: For students, getting a credit card can be an important milestone as they step into the world of personal finance. However, credit cards generally come with prerequisites like minimum credit score, monthly income, proof of employment, etc., which a student may not be able to fulfil. However, to address this gap, banks have come up with student credit cards with relaxed eligibility criteria. They may be standalone credit cards or add-on cards which are issued alongside the primary credit card being issued to a family member. That said, this article would explore eligibility, documentation and the application process for owing a student credit card.WHAT IS THE ELIGIBILITY OF STUDENT CREDIT CARD? Generally, a student credit card is issued to an applicant aged 18 years and above. The applicant should have enroled at a college or university. He/ she must be an Indian citizen.DOCUMENTS REQUIRED TO APPLY FOR A STUDENT CREDIT CARD Key documents for applying for a student credit card include an Aadhaar card, PAN card, the latest passport-sized photographs and an ID card issued by a college or university.APPLICATION PROCESS For applying for an add-on credit card, the family member who has the credit card with the bank must apply for the same. Download and complete the application form. Furnish the self-assessed photocopy of the PAN card and address proof of the applicant. While obtaining a credit card against a fixed deposit, the applicant must hold an FD account in the bank. While using a credit card, a student may enjoy benefits like emergency funds backup, and building a good credit score. However, it can have drawbacks too. At times, students fall into a debt trap as credit cards can feel like ‘free money’. Also, when compared to regular credit cards, student credit cards may have higher interest rates. That said, while the credit card can be a valuable financial tool, users must be aware of its potential misuse and pitfalls. Hence, a wise and responsible use of credit cards is the need of the hour.Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Feb 4, 2025Trending Reel

Headline: GST Council to decide on fewer, lower tax rates soon: Nirmala SitharamanFinance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman stated on Tuesday that the GST Council is close to finalising a decision on tax rate rationalisation, with the review process nearly complete. At present, the Goods and Services Tax (GST) is structured into four slabs: 5 per cent, 12 per cent, 18 per cent, and 28 per cent.
Content: Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced on Tuesday that the GST Council is nearing a decision on rationalising tax rates, as the review process is almost complete. Currently, the Goods and Services Tax (GST) follows a four-tier structure with slabs at 5 per cent, 12 per cent, 18 per cent, and 28 per cent. Luxury and demerit goods fall under the highest 28 per cent bracket, while essential items, including packed food, are taxed at the lowest 5 per cent rate. To simplify this framework, the Council-chaired by Sitharaman and comprising state finance ministers - has set up a Group of Ministers (GoM) to review and recommend changes. "The process of rationalising and simplifying GST rates began nearly three years ago. Over time, its scope expanded, and now, the work is almost complete," Sitharaman said at the India Today-Business Today Post Budget Round Table. She emphasised the need for a thorough review, particularly concerning items of daily consumption, to ensure meaningful reforms. "It was important not to miss this opportunity. The original intent was to have fewer and lower rates, and that remains our focus. I hope the GST Council will take a decision soon," she added. The finance minister's remarks come days after she presented the Union Budget 2025-26, which introduced significant income tax relief for the middle class. Addressing speculation, Sitharaman dismissed claims that the tax relief was politically motivated ahead of the Delhi Assembly elections, asserting that it reflects Prime Minister Narendra Modi's commitment to taxpayers. She also clarified that there are no plans to "shut down" the old tax regime. On capital expenditure, Sitharaman reiterated that spending has not been reduced but has, in fact, increased. The Budget has allocated Rs 11.21 lakh crore for capex in 2025-26, which is 4.3 per cent of GDP-higher than Rs 10.18 lakh crore in the revised estimates for FY25. She highlighted the steady rise in capex allocations over the years, from Rs 4.39 lakh crore in FY21 to Rs 10 lakh crore in FY24, demonstrating the government's commitment to infrastructure growth. The Budget also set a fiscal deficit target of 4.4 per cent of GDP for FY26, while revising the FY25 estimate downward by 10 basis points to 4.8 per cent. Sitharaman reaffirmed that India's economic fundamentals remain strong, dismissing concerns about a structural slowdown.Published By: Nakul AhujaPublished On: Feb 4, 2025Tune InMust Watch

Headline: Ratan Tata's millennial friend Shantanu Naidu gets top role at Tata MotorsIn 2018, Shantanu  Naidu began working as Ratan Tata's assistant, a role that brought him public attention, especially after a viral video of him singing Happy Birthday for the industrialist.
Content: Shantanu Naidu, known for his special bond with late industrialist Ratan Tata, was promoted to General Manager, Head of Strategic Initiatives, at Tata Motors after spending more than six years at Tata Sons. Announcing his new position on LinkedIn, Naidu, 32, wrote, "I'm happy to share that I'm starting a new position as General Manager, Head - Strategic Initiatives at Tata Motors! I remember when my father used to walk home from the Tata Motors plant in his white shirt and navy pants, and I would wait for him in the window. It comes full circle now," he wrote. A mechanical engineering graduate, Naidu began his professional journey as an intern at Tata Technologies before joining Tata Elxsi. It was in 2014 that he first caught Ratan Tata’s eye.   Naidu, an automobile design engineer, developed a dog collar design with a safety innovation to protect homeless dogs from speeding vehicles. Tata, a known animal lover, not only decided to invest in the project but also became his mentor. The industrialist's backing of the initiative marked the beginning of a long-standing professional and personal bond between the two. In 2018, Naidu assumed the role of Tata’s assistant, a position that brought him into the public spotlight. His close relationship with the business tycoon won hearts, especially after a video of him singing a birthday song for Tata went viral. Their mentor-mentee relationship was often likened to that of a father and son. Naidu chronicled their unique friendship in his book, I Came Upon a Lighthouse, which offered a rare glimpse into the personality of Ratan Tata beyond his business empire. Beyond his corporate endeavours, Naidu is also an entrepreneur. In 2021, he founded Goodfellows, a startup dedicated to providing companionship for senior citizens living alone. The venture, valued at Rs 5 crore, received backing from Ratan Tata, who later relinquished ownership of the company. Following Ratan Tata’s death on October 9, 2024, at the age of 86, Naidu shared an emotional tribute on LinkedIn. "The hole that this friendship has now left with me, I will spend the rest of my life trying to fill. Grief is the price to pay for love. Goodbye, my dear lighthouse," he wrote. According to reports, Naidu's MBA expenses at Cornell University were covered under Tata's willPublished By: Devika BhattacharyaPublished On: Feb 5, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Sensex, Nifty open flat as RBI policy meet kicks off; FMCG stocks fallShare Market Today: The S&P BSE Sensex was down by 14.87 points to 78,568.94, while the NSE Nifty50 added 30.40 points to 23,769.65 as of 9:28 AM.
Content: Benchmark stock market indices opened flat on Wednesday, after witnessing a rally in the previous session. The 3-day RBI MPC also begins today with market investors expecting a rate cut that could impact investor sentiment.  The S&P BSE Sensex was down by 14.87 points to 78,568.94, while the NSE Nifty50 added 30.40 points to 23,769.65 as of 9:28 AM.  Dr. V K Vijayakumar, Chief Investment Strategist, Geojit Financial Services said that short covering and actions in the derivatives market will keep the market highly volatile today. "Two factors are influencing the market trend now. One, the market perceives the Trump tariff threats as negotiating tools, which might not lead to a full blown trade war. Two, the potential beneficial impact of the game changing Budget is slowly sinking in the market. The most significant short-term positive for the market is the FIIs turning buyers (Rs 809 crores) in the cash market for the first time since January 2nd. It remains to be seen whether this will become a trend. The decline in the dollar index and the US bond yields are positive," he added. Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 5, 2025Must Watch

Headline: RBI MPC meeting starts today: Will new Governor Sanjay Malhotra cut rates?RBI MPC Meeting 2025: The repo rate has been unchanged at 6.5% since February 2023, and the last rate cut was announced during the Covid-19 pandemic in May 2020.
Content: The Reserve Bank of India’s (RBI) Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) meeting begins on Wedneday under the leadership of newly appointed Governor Sanjay Malhotra. This will be the first policy meeting of Sanjay Malhotra as RBI Governor.  Analysts are divided on whether the RBI will cut the repo rate for the first time in nearly two years or maintain the current rate to manage inflation and currency stability. The six-member committee will announce its decision on February 7, 2025.WILL RBI CUT KEY LENDING RATES? Experts believe the RBI may reduce the repo rate by 25 basis points (bps) to support economic growth, especially after the Union Budget 2025 focused on boosting demand. The repo rate has been unchanged at 6.5% since February 2023, and the last rate cut was announced during the Covid-19 pandemic in May 2020. Madan Sabnavis, Chief Economist at Bank of Baroda, believes economic conditions are suitable for a rate cut. “The budget has provided a growth stimulus, and inflation is expected to ease. However, the rupee remains under pressure due to global trade uncertainties,” he said. While some believe a rate cut is likely, others feel the RBI may wait for global economic conditions to stabilise before making any changes. Edelweiss Mutual Fund predicts a 50 bps rate cut in the first half of 2025, saying that monetary policy will have to play a key role in supporting economic growth. Rumki Majumdar, Economist at Deloitte, believes the RBI will take a cautious approach. “Balancing inflation and credit growth is tricky. While there is pressure to cut rates, the RBI may choose to keep rates unchanged but maintain an easy policy stance,” she said. Umeshkumar Mehta, CIO at SAMCO Mutual Fund, feels that global factors will influence the RBI’s decision. “Bond yields in the US are rising due to inflation concerns, putting pressure on the Indian rupee. To avoid further depreciation, the RBI may choose to keep rates unchanged,” he explained.FACTORS THAT COULD IMPACT RATE CUTS The RBI’s decision will depend on several factors: Inflation trends: Inflation has remained above 5%, but a downward trend could encourage a rate cut. Currency stability: The rupee has been under pressure due to rising US bond yields and global trade tensions. Economic growth: With the government focusing on economic expansion, a rate cut could help boost demand. Global uncertainties: Trade wars and fluctuating commodity prices could impact the RBI’s approach. The stock market and bond markets will react based on the RBI’s decision. If the central bank cuts rates, banking stocks may see gains, and borrowing costs for businesses and individuals could come down. However, if rates remain unchanged, markets may turn volatile as investors adjust their expectations.Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 5, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Bull run on Dalal Street: Will the stock market rally last? Share market today: The stock market saw a bull run in the last session with the benchmark indices, Sensex and Nifty, both closing over 1.5% higher, driven by gains in banking and financial stocks.
Content:
Dalal Street saw a strong rally on Tuesday as stock markets surged in the afternoon session, recovering from losses in the previous session. The benchmark indices, Sensex and Nifty, both closed over 1.5% higher, driven by gains in banking and financial stocks. The S&P BSE Sensex jumped 1,397.07 points to settle at 78,583.81, while the NSE Nifty50 climbed 378.20 points to close at 23,739.25. According to market experts, the next target range for Nifty stands at 23,900–24,200. The banking sector played a major role in Tuesday’s recovery, and analysts believe that the market’s momentum will depend on how the banking index moves beyond the 50,200 level. Ajit Mishra, SVP-Research at Religare Broking Limited, said, “Given the current market conditions, we continue to focus on selective stock picking, with a preference for large-cap and large mid-cap stocks.” Rajesh Bhosale, Technical Analyst at Angel One Ltd., suggested that a buy-on-dips strategy remains ideal, as it has been successful in recent sessions. He added, “The Budget Day high of 23,630 now acts as immediate support, while the bullish gap near 23,400 is a key demand zone.” However, he warned that geopolitical tensions and ongoing trade wars could lead to volatility in the markets. Domestic factors such as the RBI’s Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) meeting and the Delhi state elections will also influence investor sentiment. Banking stocks have been rising ahead of the RBI policy meeting, where analysts expect a rate cut. This will be the first policy meeting under the new RBI governor, making it a key event for investors. Vinod Nair, Head of Research at Geojit Financial Services, said, “While overall market sentiment remains positive, large-cap stocks are the preferred choice. Meanwhile, banking stocks are rallying in anticipation of a rate cut in this week’s RBI policy.”STOCKS TO WATCH TODAY Several stocks will be in focus in today’s trade due to earnings announcements and key business developments.
Swiggy, Reliance Power, and Info Edge will be in focus as they are set to announce their quarterly results today.
Titan reported a 0.6% drop in net profit for the third quarter, at Rs 1,047 crore. However, its total income grew 25% year-on-year to Rs 17,723 crore.
Tata Power posted an 8% rise in consolidated net profit for the December quarter, reaching Rs 1,031 crore, compared to Rs 953 crore in the same period last year.
Hero MotoCorp, Bandhan Bank, and Tata Power are also expected to be in focus due to various corporate updates.
DEFENCE STOCKS IN FOCUS Defence stocks have been showing signs of recovery, driven by strong order books and rising exports. Kranthi Bathini, Director of Equity Strategy at WealthMills Securities, said, “The defence sector still has strong earnings visibility. The defence budget has been increased to Rs 11 lakh crore, marking a 10% rise from the previous year.” He highlighted that Indian defence companies exported more than Rs 21,000 crore (about $2 billion) worth of goods last year. “Despite high valuations, these companies have a clear earnings outlook. After a 20-30% correction from their peak, defence stocks now look attractive for long-term investors,” he said. (Disclaimer: The views, opinions, recommendations, and suggestions expressed by experts/brokerages in this article are their own and do not reflect the views of the India Today Group. It is advisable to consult a qualified broker or financial advisor before making any actual investment or trading choices.)Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 5, 2025Must Watch

Headline: ITC Hotels to be dropped from Sensex, BSE indices today. Here's why ITC Hotels shares opened at Rs 188 per share on the BSE and Rs 180 per share on the NSE at a discount of over 30% compared to the discovered price of Rs 260 on the NSE and Rs 270 on the BSE.
Content: ITC Hotels will be removed from 22 BSE indices before trading begins on Wednesday, February 5. The company, which was spun off from ITC, was temporarily included in the Sensex and other indices to help passive funds adjust their portfolios. ITC Hotels began trading separately on January 29 after it was demerged from ITC. Initially, it was included in stock indices for a short period to allow index funds and investors to rebalance their holdings. ITC Hotels shares debuted at Rs 188 per share on the BSE and Rs 180 per share on the NSE. This marked a listing at a discount of over 30% compared to the discovered price of Rs 260 on the NSE and Rs 270 on the BSE. In a notice, BSE confirmed this move, and said that since ITC Hotels did not hit the lower circuit till the cut-off time, the company will be dropped from all BSE indices before trading begins on Wednesday. “As ITCHOTELS did not hit the lower circuit till the cut-off time, the company will be dropped from all the BSE Indices effective prior to the open of trading on Wednesday, February 5, 2025,” said a notice on BSE.  The company’s shares closed at Rs 165 in the last session, falling by 4.16%. At the time of its listing, ITC Hotels had a market valuation of Rs 39,126.02 crore, which has now fallen to Rs 34,266.48 crore. The removal from Sensex led to selling pressure, with index funds selling shares worth over Rs 400 crore. An additional Rs 700 crore worth of selling is expected when the stock is removed from NSE Nifty. The demerger process saw ITC Ltd retaining a 40% stake in ITC Hotels, while the remaining 60% was distributed to ITC shareholders in a 10:1 ratio. According to ITC, the total acquisition cost for 100 shares of ITC Hotels stands at Rs 54,040. Despite the short-term volatility, ITC Hotels has reported strong operational performance. The Average Room Rate (ARR) has increased from Rs 7,900 in FY19 to Rs 12,000 in FY24, marking a 51.9% rise, with a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 8.7%. Revenue Per Available Room (RevPAR) has also grown from Rs 5,200 to Rs 8,200 in the same period, a rise of 57.7%, with a CAGR of 9.5%. In FY24, room sales contributed 52% to total revenue, while food and beverage accounted for 40%.Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 5, 2025

Headline: Explained: Is China playing it safe in latest trade war with US? US-China trade war: China's countermeasures appear more restrained compared to its approach during the previous trade war. This has raised a key question: Is China playing it safe in the latest trade standoff with the US?
Content: China has hit back after US President Donald Trump announced new 10% tariffs on Chinese goods. Beijing's response included duties on about 80 American products, an investigation into Google, tighter controls on critical minerals, and the blacklisting of two US companies. However, this time, China’s countermeasures appear more restrained compared to its approach during the previous trade war. This has raised a key question: Is China treading cautiously in the latest trade standoff with the US? The answer lies in Beijing’s current economic challenges and the large trade gap it has with America. Rather than matching Trump’s move entirely, China imposed tariffs on a smaller set of US goods worth around $14 billion, according to Bloomberg News. The careful response marks a shift from its earlier strategy, when it would retaliate with equal measures against US tariffs. Instead of matching Trump's move completely, China only put tariffs on a small portion of US goods worth $14 billion, reported Bloomberg News. This careful approach is in stark contrast to how China acted during Trump's first term, when they would match US tariffs dollar for dollar.WHY CHINA HAS MORE TO LOSE The change in China’s strategy seems to be due to ongoing economic challenges. The country is dealing with falling prices and trying to fix problems in its property market. Right now, China heavily depends on selling goods overseas to keep its economy growing. The math makes China's position even more difficult. China sells more than three times as much stuff to the US as it buys from them. This means China has fewer American products it can put tariffs on if it wants to fight back. As Larry Hu from Macquarie Group told Bloomberg, China is being restrained because it "has more to lose" due to this huge trade imbalance with the US. Therefore, instead of getting into a full-blow tariff war, China might focus more on supporting its own economy through internal measures. Experts suggest China might try to make peace by promising to buy more American oil and gas, keeping its currency stable, or fulfilling previous trade promises. Both sides seem interested in making a deal. Trump has said he wants to talk with Chinese leader Xi Jinping, though he's in no rush. There are other issues on the table too, like Trump wanting China's help to stop the war in Ukraine and demanding changes to TikTok's ownership. For now, China is trying to look strong without making things worse. Josef Gregory Mahoney from Shanghai's East China Normal University told Bloomberg that it's like "two giants sizing each up and testing each other's resolve while also playing to their domestic audiences before shaking hands." But if things escalate, China's heavy reliance on exports to the US means it might have the most to lose in a full-blown trade war.Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 5, 2025Tune InMust Watch

Headline: Arbitrator may decide who controls Ratan Tata's fortune: ReportRatan Tata had set up two entities in 2022 to manage his personal wealth for charitable purposes—the RTEF under Section 8 of the Companies Act 2013 and the Ratan Tata Endowment Trust.
Content: Tata stakeholders may seek to appoint an arbitrator to decide who will be the trustees of the Ratan Tata Endowment Foundation (RTEF), as there are no clear written instructions from the late Ratan Tata regarding the process, reported The Economic Times. The arbitrator is likely to be a retired Chief Justice of the Supreme Court as per the report. The main issue is whether the right to appoint trustees belongs to the executors of Ratan Tata’s will, the Tata family, or the members of the Tata Trusts. Ratan Tata had set up two entities in 2022 to manage his personal wealth for charitable purposes—the RTEF under Section 8 of the Companies Act 2013 and the Ratan Tata Endowment Trust. The RTEF also holds minor stakes in Tata Digital and Tata Technologies. Ratan Tata held a 0.83% direct stake in Tata Sons, the holding company of the Tata Group, and had a net worth of Rs 7,900 crore, as per the Hurun India Rich List published in August 2024. However, sources estimate his total wealth to be above Rs 15,000 crore. According to people familiar with the matter, Ratan Tata was clear that the RTEF should remain independent of Tata Trusts, which currently controls Tata Sons with a 66% stake. During his lifetime, Ratan Tata expressed a desire to use a major portion of his fortune for charitable and community purposes. Most of his wealth will be managed by the foundation, while the remaining assets will be handled by the trust. There is also a possibility that his collection of luxury cars, which includes a Ferrari and a Maserati, may be auctioned, with the proceeds going to the foundation. Before his passing, Ratan Tata had named RR Shastri and Burjis Taraporewala as holding trustees of the RTEF and had appointed Jamsheed Poncha as the CEO as per the report. He had also expressed his preference for Tata Sons Chairman N Chandrasekaran to be the managing trustee. However, there is no clarity on who holds the authority to appoint trustees after his passing. Ratan Tata had chosen Darius Khambata, Mehli Mistry, and his half-sisters, Shireen and Deanna Jejeebhoy, as the executors of his will. Khambata, a senior counsel, is one of the executors, but sources suggest that since he is already involved, a legal expert senior to him may be needed for guidance. Mistry, a close associate of Ratan Tata, is also a board trustee of the Sir Dorabji Tata Trust and the Sir Ratan Tata Trust, two of the main Tata charities. The four executors have not commented on the matter. Once the probate is completed, the foundation is expected to receive a large influx of funds from Ratan Tata’s stake in Tata Sons and other group companies. Ratan Tata, who passed away in October 2024 at the age of 86, wanted the RTEF to focus on areas of philanthropy that were new, relevant, and under-represented. He also aimed for the foundation to promote research into future technologies that could help modern India and support long-term projects with a significant positive impact on society. The RTEF is currently a board-managed entity and follows the guidelines outlined for charitable organisations. Legal experts believe that in cases where there are no specific instructions in a will, the responsibility of administering the estate lies with the executors, who must follow the wishes of the deceased. Ajay Khatlawala, managing partner at Little & Co, told ET that since RTEF is registered under Section 8 of the Companies Act 2013, it will be governed by its Memorandum of Association, Articles of Association, and the provisions of the Companies Act. The rules for appointing trustees or directors will be determined by the Articles of Association of RTEF. Khatlawala also said that this situation could set a precedent for how legacy foundations are managed in India. He said it highlights the importance of having clear written instructions in a will to prevent disputes and confusion among stakeholders after the passing of the founder.Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 5, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Services sector growth slows to more than 2-year low in JanuaryDemand for services rose at the slowest pace in 14 months but remained sturdy. It was supported by international demand that was the strongest in five months.
Content: Growth in India's dominant services sector was the slowest in over two years in January amid cooling demand but remained historically strong and led to a substantial rate of hiring, a business survey showed on Wednesday. Asia's third-largest economy has been struggling with slackening consumption. To try and boost spending, the government gave some tax relief to the middle class at its annual budget on February 1 but shied away from announcing big reforms which are much needed to prop up growth. The HSBC final India Services Purchasing Managers' Index INPMIS=ECI, compiled by S&P Global, fell to 56.5 in January from 59.3 in December, a tad lower than a preliminary estimate of 56.8 but comfortably ahead of the 50-mark separating contraction from growth. "The business activity and new business PMI indices eased to their lowest levels since November 2022 and November 2023 respectively," said Pranjul Bhandari, chief India economist at HSBC. "That said, new export business partly countered the downtrend and continued to rebound from a dip in late-2024, in line with official data." Demand for services rose at the slowest pace in 14 months but remained sturdy. It was supported by international demand that was the strongest in five months. The future activity sub-index moderated to a three-month low but the fall was insignificant and firms hired new staff at one of the fastest paces since the inception of the survey in December 2005. Inflationary pressures picked up, as both input costs and prices charged rose at a strong pace. But India's retail inflation eased to a four-month low in December, increasing the chances of easier monetary policy. The Reserve Bank of India is widely expected to cut its key repo rate on Feb. 7, a Reuters poll taken last week showed. Slower services growth overshadowed a six-month high pace of expansion in the manufacturing sector INPMI=ECI and dragged the overall Composite PMI down to 57.7 last month from 59.2 in December.Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 5, 2025Must Watch

Headline: OpenAI's Sam Altman meets with IT minister to discuss India's AI roadmapIn a post on X, Ashwini Vaishnaw said he had a "super cool discussion" with Altman on India's "strategy of creating the entire AI stack - GPUs, model, and apps" and that OpenAI was willing to collaborate on all three.
Content: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman met with Union Minister for Railways and Electronics and IT Ashwini Vaishnaw on Wednesday to discuss India’s vision for a cost-effective artificial intelligence (AI) ecosystem. Altman’s discussion with Vaishnaw mostly revolved around India’s efforts to create a complete AI ecosystem. In a post on X, Vaishnaw said he had a "super cool discussion" with Altman on India's "strategy of creating the entire AI stack - GPUs, model, and apps" and that OpenAI was willing to collaborate on all three. A week ago, Viashnaw praised Chinese startup DeepSeek for its affordable AI solutions, and said, India also has plans to build a localised AI model. “Our country sent a mission to the moon at a friction of the cost that many other countries did right, why can't we do a model that will be a fraction of the cost that many others do?” Vaishnaw said. It may be noted that this is Sam Altman’s first visit to India since 2023 and comes amid regulatory scrutiny in the country. His visit also comes at a time when India is stepping up efforts to develop homegrown AI solutions. Altman, who had previously dismissed India’s ability to develop large-scale AI models, has said that the country should play a leading role in AI. He also highlighted India's growing role in AI and revealed that it is OpenAI’s second-largest market globally.Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 5, 2025Trending Reel

Headline: Will Rs 12 lakh income qualify for zero tax even with capital gains?The biggest announcement was that individuals earning up to Rs 12 lakh would not have to pay any tax. But does this still apply if you have additional income from capital gains? Here is all you need to know.
Content:
Income tax relief for the middle class was at the highlight of Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman’s budget presentation. She introduced major changes to rates and slabs under the new tax regime.The biggest announcement was that individuals earning up to Rs 12 lakh would not have to pay any tax. But does this still apply if you have additional income from capital gains? Not quite.In her budget speech, Nirmala Sitharaman made it clear that “special rate income” such as capital gains will be taxed separately from salaried income.advertisement“To taxpayers, up to Rs 12 lakh of normal income (other than special rate income such as capital gains) tax rebate is being provided in addition to the benefit due to slab rate reduction in such a manner that there is no tax payable by them,” Sitharaman said.To put it simply, while salaried income up to Rs 12 lakh will be tax-free, you will be taxed for long-term capital gains (LTCG) and short-term capital gains (STCG) and they are not eligible for rebate.“Your salary up to Rs 12 lakh is effectively tax-free only if your normal income (i.e. excluding incomes chargeable at special rates, example capital gains etc.) does not exceed Rs 12 lakh for the accounting year. In case your salary has short-term capital gains, you shall have to pay tax on that part of the income at special prescribed rates,” said Ritika Nayyar, Partner, Singhania & Co.advertisementSumeet Agarwal, Associate Partner at Economic Laws Practice, explained that under the new tax regime, no rebate is available if “total income” exceeds Rs 12 lakh.“Therefore, income from salary of Rs. 12 lakh will not be tax-free if there is additional STCG income over and above the salary of Rs. 12 lakh,” he said.“Further, where the total income does not exceed Rs 12 lakh (including capital gains income taxable at special rates), such capital gains shall remain subject to tax while the balance income would be tax-free on account of rebate under the new tax regime,” he explained.For instance, if a person earns Rs 12 lakh from salary and an additional Rs 2 lakh as STCG from equity investments, the total income would be Rs 14 lakh. Since the total income exceeds the Rs 12 lakh rebate threshold, the person will not be eligible for the Section 87A rebate.The Rs 12 lakh salary component will be taxed as per the slab rates, while the Rs 2 lakh STCG will be taxed at 15%. However, if the person’s total income, including capital gains, remains within Rs 12 lakh, then only the capital gains portion will be taxed separately, while the rest of the income will remain tax-free due to the rebate.Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 5, 2025Tune InMust Watch

In case your salary has short-term capital gains, you shall have to pay tax on that part of the income at special prescribed rates,” said Ritika Nayyar, Partner, Singhania & Co.advertisementSumeet Agarwal, Associate Partner at Economic Laws Practice, explained that under the new tax regime, no rebate is available if “total income” exceeds Rs 12 lakh.“Therefore, income from salary of Rs. 12 lakh will not be tax-free if there is additional STCG income over and above the salary of Rs. 12 lakh,” he said. The biggest announcement was that individuals earning up to Rs 12 lakh would not have to pay any tax. But does this still apply if you have additional income from capital gains? Not quite.In her budget speech, Nirmala Sitharaman made it clear that “special rate income” such as capital gains will be taxed separately from salaried income.advertisement“To taxpayers, up to Rs 12 lakh of normal income (other than special rate income such as capital gains) tax rebate is being provided in addition to the benefit due to slab rate reduction in such a manner that there is no tax payable by them,” Sitharaman said.To put it simply, while salaried income up to Rs 12 lakh will be tax-free, you will be taxed for long-term capital gains (LTCG) and short-term capital gains (STCG) and they are not eligible for rebate. In her budget speech, Nirmala Sitharaman made it clear that “special rate income” such as capital gains will be taxed separately from salaried income. “To taxpayers, up to Rs 12 lakh of normal income (other than special rate income such as capital gains) tax rebate is being provided in addition to the benefit due to slab rate reduction in such a manner that there is no tax payable by them,” Sitharaman said. To put it simply, while salaried income up to Rs 12 lakh will be tax-free, you will be taxed for long-term capital gains (LTCG) and short-term capital gains (STCG) and they are not eligible for rebate. “Your salary up to Rs 12 lakh is effectively tax-free only if your normal income (i.e. excluding incomes chargeable at special rates, example capital gains etc.) does not exceed Rs 12 lakh for the accounting year. In case your salary has short-term capital gains, you shall have to pay tax on that part of the income at special prescribed rates,” said Ritika Nayyar, Partner, Singhania & Co. Sumeet Agarwal, Associate Partner at Economic Laws Practice, explained that under the new tax regime, no rebate is available if “total income” exceeds Rs 12 lakh. “Therefore, income from salary of Rs. 12 lakh will not be tax-free if there is additional STCG income over and above the salary of Rs. 12 lakh,” he said. “Further, where the total income does not exceed Rs 12 lakh (including capital gains income taxable at special rates), such capital gains shall remain subject to tax while the balance income would be tax-free on account of rebate under the new tax regime,” he explained. For instance, if a person earns Rs 12 lakh from salary and an additional Rs 2 lakh as STCG from equity investments, the total income would be Rs 14 lakh. Since the total income exceeds the Rs 12 lakh rebate threshold, the person will not be eligible for the Section 87A rebate. The Rs 12 lakh salary component will be taxed as per the slab rates, while the Rs 2 lakh STCG will be taxed at 15%. However, if the person’s total income, including capital gains, remains within Rs 12 lakh, then only the capital gains portion will be taxed separately, while the rest of the income will remain tax-free due to the rebate.Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 5, 2025Tune InMust Watch

Headline: Zepto delivering cars now? Skoda's new teaser sparks buzzQuick commerce platforms like Blinkit, BigBasket and Zepto started delivering iPhone 16 in a few minutes, challenging traditional e-commerce giants Amazon and Flipkart, last year in September.
Content:
First, it was groceries and last-minute essentials. Then came gadgets like iPhones and PlayStations. And now, it looks like cars might be the next big thing in the quick commerce industry. Skoda India’s latest teaser suggests something that would have been hard to believe until now—ordering a brand-new car on Zepto and having it delivered just like any other online purchase. An online video, made in collaboration with Skoda India, shows a Zepto delivery executive walking into a Skoda showroom and announcing that he is there to pick up an order. A showroom staff member then leads him to his "order," which appears to be a Skoda Kylaq, the company’s new sub-compact SUV. The video ends with the words "Skoda x Zepto: Coming soon," and the caption hints at a launch date of February 8.

 



Skoda collaboration with Zepto (Source: Twitter) 
 While the teaser does not confirm the exact details, it suggests that Skoda cars could soon be available for purchase through Zepto. However, it remains unclear how this system will work. The ad does not specify whether Zepto will offer deliveries in just a few minutes, as it does with groceries, or if the process will take longer due to the paperwork and logistics involved in selling a car. More details are expected to be revealed soon. Zepto entering this space may seem surprising, but it aligns with the rapid growth of quick commerce in India. Initially, platforms like Zepto, Blinkit, and Swiggy Instamart focused on small, everyday purchases. However, consumer demand has evolved, and these platforms now offer high-value products like smartphones, gaming consoles, and other expensive electronics. If Zepto successfully launches car deliveries, it could change the way vehicles are sold in India. Traditionally, buying a car involves multiple steps, including visiting a showroom, test-driving the vehicle, completing paperwork, and securing financing. If quick commerce companies can simplify this process, it could appeal to tech-savvy consumers who prefer convenience over traditional dealership experiences.Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 5, 2025Trending Reel

Headline: Government accuses Kia of tax evasion in VW-like dispute: ReportKia competes with Hyundai and Maruti Suzuki in the world's third-largest auto market, where it has a share of 6% of roughly 4 million units a year, and its Kia Seltos and Sonet SUVs are among the top sellers.
Content: India has accused South Korea's Kia of evading taxes of $155 million by misclassifying component imports, but the carmaker has denied wrongdoing, the latest fight by a foreign automaker with New Delhi over tariffs, according to a document and two sources. Kia competes with Hyundai and Maruti Suzuki in the world's third-largest auto market, where it has a share of 6% of roughly 4 million units a year, and its Kia Seltos and Sonet SUVs are among the top sellers. Foreign companies in India face headaches from high taxes and long-drawn-out investigations. For example, Tesla has publicly complained about high taxes on imported EVs and Volkswagen last week sued over a demand for a record $1.4 billion in back taxes that it called "impossibly enormous". Tax officers sent a confidential notice to Kia's Indian unit in April 2024, flagging alleged tax evasion of 13.5 billion rupees, according to a government notice Reuters is reporting for the first time. The offence centered on incorrect declaration of imports of components for the assembly of the carmaker's luxury Carnival minivan, the notice showed. In a statement to Reuters, Kia India said it made "a detailed response, supported by comprehensive evidence and documentation to substantiate" its stand and the authorities were still reviewing the matter. Kia India is committed to complying with all regulations and has "consistently cooperated with" authorities, it added. India's finance ministry and customs officials did not respond to Reuters queries. In its 432-page notice, the government said tax authorities found Kia's Carnival "car model was being imported in parts or components in separate lots" via different ports, with the "intent to discharge lesser customs duty". Kia devised the strategy to ensure the imports "could not (be) detected by customs," it added in the notice, issued by a customs commissioner in the southern city of Chennai. Two sources said Kia's case was similar to that of Volkswagen, accused of evading a higher tax of 30% to 35% applicable on parts imported in "completely knocked down" or CKD form in a single shipment, instead shipping separate parts over days, making them eligible for a tax rate of just 10% to 15%. During the investigation, Kia's website showed the Carnival model sold in India as being in "CKD" form, with retail sales of 9,887 units between 2020 and 2022, the tax notice said. The Volkswagen investigation spanned 14 car models from the Skoda Kodiaq to the Audi A3 and the Volkswagen Tiguan. In contrast, Kia's case concerns only the Carnival model, a seven-seater priced around $73,500, which is among its most expensive cars in India.KIA COULD FACE $310 MILLION PAYOUT Indian tax rules could require Kia to pay up to $310 million if it loses the dispute, or roughly double the amount evaded, due to penalty and interest. The latest available corporate filings in India show Kia's domestic annual sales of $4.45 billion in fiscal 2022/23 were its highest ever, up 53% on the year, for net profit of $243 million. Last week, India slashed import duties on fully-built high-end motorcycles to 30%, in a move widely seen as looking to placate U.S. President Donald Trump, who has in the past called India a "tariff king". But fully-assembled imported cars still attract a levy of more than 100%. Kia has deposited 2.78 billion rupees ($32 million) "under protest" as it continues to fight the Indian tax notice, which is still proceeding, said a government source who declined to be named as the matter is private. In 2022, authorities searched Kia offices and a factory in the southern state of Andhra Pradesh and took statements from India executives, some of whom the document identifies as Chief Procurement Officer Lee Sang Hwa, and Chief Finance Officer Kiho Yoo. During the investigation, Kia executives "changed their stance and have made efforts to mislead," the tax notice stated, referring to statements on imports, manufacturing and taxation. Kia was accused of importing more than 90% of the parts for Carnival, constituting a car in CKD form, which attracts higher tax, it added. India's head of indirect taxes, Sanjay Kumar Agarwal, told Reuters the law was clear and some automakers were flouting it by not paying applicable CKD duties. "If they are on the wrong side, then the department will have to issue a notice," he said in an interview on Tuesday.Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 5, 2025

Headline: Sensex, Nifty end lower as consumer stocks weigh; rupee dropsShare Market: The S&P BSE Sensex was down 312.53 points to 78,271.28 at the closing bell, while the NSE Nifty50 settled 42.95 points lower at 23,696.30.
Content: The benchmark stock market indices ended the trading session in red as the decline in consumer stocks overpowered gains in energy stocks.  The S&P BSE Sensex was down 312.53 points to 78,271.28 at the closing bell, while the NSE Nifty50 settled 42.95 points lower at 23,696.30.  While energy stocks provided some support, they were not enough to offset the broader market weakness.  Some of the top losers on the Nifty50 were Asian Paints, Nestle India, Britannia, Tata Consumer Products and HUL. On the other hand, the top gainers were Hindalco, ITC Hotels, ONGC, Apollo Hospitals and BPCL. Vinod Nair, Head of Research, Geojit Financial Services, said, "The domestic market traded within a narrow range in negative terrain. Investors are weighing the improved domestic outlook, buoyed by a favourable budget, against lingering global uncertainties stemming from the tariff war." Meanwhile, the rupee also faced pressure, dropping 0.4% against the US dollar to 87.4650. The decline was triggered by a sharp fall in the afternoon, which triggered stop losses amid prevailing bearish sentiment. "While declining US bond yields and lower crude oil prices have supported market sentiment, the rupee's depreciation could offset these gains. Rate-sensitive sectors are attracting attention ahead of a potential RBI rate cut. Meanwhile, large-cap stocks are well-positioned, benefiting from moderation in valuations," Vijayakumar added. Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 5, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Sensex, Nifty fall after flat opening as investors await RBI rate decisionShare Market Today: The S&P BSE Sensex was down 151.58 points to 78,119.70 at 10:12 am, while the NSE Nifty50 traded 42.95 points lower at 23,696.30.
Content: Benchmark stock market indices fell after opening flat on Thursday as investors wait for the Reserve Bank of India’s rate decision on Friday. The S&P BSE Sensex was down 151.58 points to 78,119.70 at 10:12 am, while the NSE Nifty50 traded 42.95 points lower at 23,696.30. Most of the other broader market indices were also trading flat or in the red as volatility gained momentum. Some pharma and IT stocks were among the gainers, but bank and financial services stocks were down. The top five gainers on the Nifty50 were BPCL, ITC Hotels, Cipla, Dr Reddy’s and Power Grid. On the other hand, the top losers were Trent, Titan, Ultratech Cement, M&M and Eicher Motors. While the mood on Dalal Street remains volatile, there are wide expectations that the RBI will cut interest rates for the first time in nearly 5 years. A 25 bps rate cut is expected. Dr VK Vijayakumar, Chief Investment Strategist, Geojit Financial Services, said "The market is moving into a consolidation phase on expectations of a pickup in growth in the coming quarters. In the near-term the market is likely to get a mild boost from a possible 25 bp rate cut by the MPC tomorrow.” If the RBI’s Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) does cut rates, it will be another boost to consumption after Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced fresh income tax benefits in Budget 2025. “Even though steadily depreciating INR doesn’t provide a favourable macro backdrop for a rate cut, the MPC is likely to go for a 25 bp cut tomorrow to keep the optimistic momentum provided by the Budget going,” he added. Prashanth Tapse, Senior VP (Research), Mehta Equities Ltd, said, “All eyes are on Friday’s RBI MPC decision, with hopes for a rate cut to boost consumption.” Tapse also said that key corporate earnings from companies such as Bharti Airtel, SBI and ITC will also determine the mood of investors on Dalal Street.  Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 6, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Will RBI cut key rates for 1st time in 5 years? 4 things you need to knowRBI MPC: There are expectations that the central bank's MPC will decide on cutting the key rates for the first time in 5 years by 25 basis points (BPS).
Content: The Reserve Bank of India’s (RBI) Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) is set to announce its policy decision on Friday, under the leadership of newly appointed Governor Sanjay Malhotra. There are expectations that the central bank’s MPC will decide on cutting the key rates for the first time in 5 years by 25 basis points (BPS). The last time the MPC announced a rate cut was way back in May 2020. While analysts have mixed views on whether the RBI will cut the repo rate, a positive announcement could provide another boost to consumption after the recent tax cuts in the Union Budget 2025. So, will the RBI’s MPC cut rates tomorrow or stay focused on keeping inflation under control? Here are 4 things you need to know:25 BPS RATE CUT LIKELY A 25 basis points (bps) rate cut is widely anticipated, marking the first reduction since the Covid-19 pandemic in May 2020. The repo rate has remained steady at 6.5% since February 2023, following a cumulative 250 bps hike between May 2022 and February 2023. Dr. VK Vijayakumar, Chief Investment Strategist at Geojit Financial Services, believes that a cut is likely despite concerns over the depreciating rupee. “The market is moving into a consolidation phase on expectations of a pickup in growth in the coming quarters. In the near term, the market is likely to get a mild boost from a possible 25 bps rate cut by the MPC tomorrow. Even though steadily depreciating INR doesn’t provide a favourable macro backdrop for a rate cut, the MPC is likely to go for a 25 bps cut tomorrow to keep the optimistic momentum provided by the Budget going,” he said. Madan Sabnavis, Chief Economist at Bank of Baroda, also supports the likelihood of a rate cut. “The budget has provided growth stimulus, and inflation is expected to ease. However, the rupee remains under pressure due to global trade uncertainties,” he noted. On the other hand, Rumki Majumdar, economist at Deloitte, expects the RBI to maintain a cautious approach. “Balancing inflation and credit growth is tricky. While there is pressure to cut rates, the RBI may choose to keep rates unchanged but maintain an easy policy stance,” she said. Umeshkumar Mehta, CIO at SAMCO Mutual Fund, highlighted global factors influencing the RBI’s decision. “Bond yields in the US are rising due to inflation concerns, putting pressure on the Indian rupee. To avoid further depreciation, the RBI may choose to keep rates unchanged,” he said.NEUTRAL STANCE TO CONTINUE The government’s fiscal approach in the Union Budget 2025 has provided room for a potential rate cut to stimulate growth. India’s GDP growth slowed to a seven-quarter low of 5.4% in Q2 FY25, adding pressure on the central bank to support economic expansion. According to Bajaj Broking Research, the MPC is expected to maintain its neutral stance, allowing flexibility in future policy decisions. The brokerage also noted that RBI’s recent liquidity measures aim to stabilize the financial system, reinforcing expectations of monetary easing. Edelweiss Mutual Fund predicts a total rate cut of 50 bps in the first half of 2025, emphasizing the need for monetary policy to complement fiscal measures in boosting demand.INFLATION AND RUPEE PROBLEM Inflation remains a key factor in the RBI’s decision-making. Consumer Price Index (CPI) inflation for FY26 is projected at 4%, with January inflation expected to be below 4.5%. December inflation stood at 5.22%, marking four consecutive months above 5%, while food inflation eased to 8.4% from 9% in November. Despite easing inflation, concerns over currency stability persist.  The rupee has been under pressure due to rising US bond yields and global trade tensions. A rate cut could further weaken the currency, prompting the RBI to adopt a wait-and-watch approach.POSSIBLE IMPACT ON STOCK AND BOND MARKETS The stock and bond markets are expected to react sharply to the RBI’s decision. A rate cut could benefit banking stocks and lower borrowing costs for businesses and individuals, boosting consumption. However, if rates remain unchanged, volatility may rise as investors recalibrate their expectations. Prashanth Tapse, Senior VP (Research) at Mehta Equities Ltd, highlighted the dual factors influencing market sentiment. “All eyes are on Friday’s RBI MPC decision, with hopes for a rate cut to boost consumption,” he said.Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 6, 2025

Headline: Explained: Why Swiggy shares hit record low todaySwiggy shares dropped over 7% to hit a new 52-week low of Rs 387 on the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) in early trade. At around 11:37 am, Swiggy shares were down 4.16% lower at Rs 400.70.
Content: Shares of online food delivery company Swiggy fell sharply during Thursday’s trading session following its Q3 FY25 results. In early trade, Swiggy shares dropped over 7% to hit a new 52-week low of Rs 387 on the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE). At around 11:37 am, Swiggy shares were down 4.16% lower at Rs 400.70.WHY SWIGGY SHARES ARE FALLING? Swiggy’s stock price fell after the company reported a consolidated loss of Rs 799 crore in the third quarter of FY25, compared to Rs 574 crore in the same period last year. The company’s loss also increased on a sequential basis in Q3FY25. Revenue from operations in Q3FY25 increased 31% year-on-year (yoy) to Rs 3,993 crore. On a sequential basis, the revenue grew 11% from Rs 3,601 crore. It may be noted that Swiggy’s increased losses can  be attributed to a 32% yoy increase in Q3FY25 expenses, which rose to Rs 4,898 crore from Rs 3,700 crore in the same period a year ago.WHAT DO BROKERAGES SAY? Brokerages shared mixed views about Swiggy’s Q3FY25 results. While UBS maintained a ‘Buy’ rating with a target price of Rs 515, Macquarie kept its ‘Underperform’ rating on Swiggy with a target price of Rs 325. Explaining its bullish stance on Swiggy, UBS said the company’s management has reiterated its group-level breakeven targets, but highlighted that margin pressure is expected to persist in coming quarters. It also noted that Swiggy does not have any plans for dark store expansion like Zomato, indicating that this could be a negative going forward. Macquarie noted that Swiggy’s quick commerce economics faces challenges, with the segment reporting a wider-than-expected loss. It said network expansion and rising competitive intensity have hurt margins of Swiggy, adding that the period of hyper-competition is expected to continue for a few more quarters. The brokerage also said it prefers Zomato over Swiggy. Meanwhile, Nuvama noted that Swiggy’s food delivery segment remains stable, but added that competitive intensity continues to pressurise margins. (Disclaimer: The views, opinions, recommendations, and suggestions expressed by experts/brokerages in this article are their own and do not reflect the views of the India Today Group. It is advisable to consult a qualified broker or financial advisor before making any actual investment or trading choices.)Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 6, 2025

Headline: India bets on pro-business policies in Budget 2025. Here are the key takeawaysOne of the most significant initiatives announced is the establishment of a High-Level Committee for transformative reforms across sector regulations.
Content: With a series of transformative measures aimed at bolstering exports, enhancing infrastructure, revitalising agriculture, and implementing tax reforms to further improve the ease of doing business, the Union Budget 2025 reflects the Government's unwavering commitment to fostering a business-friendly environment, aligning with global standards and promoting sustainable economic growth. Over the past decade, India has demonstrated a steadfast dedication to enhancing ease of doing business through both financial and non-financial reforms. This year’s Budget builds upon this foundation, introducing a mature trust-based regulatory framework that can modernise outdated regulations, reduce bureaucratic hurdles, streamline compliance requirements, and promote investment. One of the most significant initiatives announced is the establishment of a High-Level Committee for transformative reforms across sector regulations. This Committee will be tasked with conducting a comprehensive review of all non-financial sector regulations, certifications, licenses, and permissions with the objective of strengthening trust-based governance. The recommendations of this Committee are expected to pave the way for smooth and efficient regulatory practices, particularly in the inspections and compliance processes.  In the financial sector, the government plans to establish a mechanism under the Financial Stability and Development Council (FSDC), to evaluate the impact of current financial regulations and guidelines. This mechanism will also develop a framework to improve the adaptability and expansion of the financial sector, ensuring that regulations support innovation and economic growth while upholding financial stability.  Building upon the Jan Vishwas Act of 2023, which decriminalised over 180 legal provisions, the Government will introduce the Jan Vishwas Bill 2.0 to decriminalise more than 100 additional provisions across various laws. By reducing the criminalisation of minor offenses, the Bill seeks to encourage self-governance and reduce the compliance burden on individuals and businesses. This will foster an environment where businesses can operate with greater flexibility and confidence, without fear of undue legal repercussions. To streamline the Know Your Customer (KYC) process, the Government will roll out a revamped Central KYC Registry. This includes implementing a streamlined system for periodic updates, making it easier for businesses and individuals to comply with KYC requirements. The enhanced system aims to reduce redundancy and improve efficiency in the verification process. A simplified and standardised KYC framework will help financial institutions and businesses seamlessly onboard customers while ensuring security and compliance. A system with an automated requirement for updates at regular intervals can also strengthen the enforcement mechanism and achieve the underlying objectives of the KYC requirement. Steps to simplify and expedite the approval process for company mergers have also been proposed. The scope for fast-track mergers will be widened, and the process simplified, facilitating smoother corporate restructuring and consolidation. This is expected to enhance operational efficiency and competitiveness among Indian businesses. By reducing bureaucratic hurdles, companies will be better positioned to swiftly adapt to evolving market conditions and implement growth strategies with increased agility. In the spirit of ‘First Develop India’ and to attract more foreign investment, the Government will raise the Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) limit in the insurance sector from 74% to 100%. This enhanced limit will be available to companies that invest the entire premium in India. Additionally, the proposal to review and simplify the existing guardrails and conditionalities in relation to foreign investment will make the sector more attractive to global investors. This can spur considerable capital inflows, strengthening the insurance industry and increasing consumer access to a broader range of financial products.  Additionally, the Government intends to overhaul the existing model Bilateral Investment Treaty (BIT) to enhance its appeal to foreign investors. This move comes in the wake of BIT agreements signed with two countries in 2024, including the India-UAE BIT, underscoring India's dedication to fostering a welcoming environment for international investors. A well-designed BIT framework will offer increased predictability and legal security for investors, further solidifying India’s standing as an attractive investment destination. All in all, the Budget introduces a comprehensive set of reforms and initiatives designed to propel India's economic growth, enhance the ease of doing business, and attract foreign investment. By modernising regulatory frameworks, simplifying compliance procedures, and fostering an environment of trust-based governance, the Government aims to create a dynamic and resilient economy. These reflect a forward-looking approach, signalling that India is poised to navigate the complexities, challenges and opportunities of the global economic landscape. However, the success of these proposals will depend on their implementation and the response from industry stakeholders. (Moin Ladha is a Partner and Priyal Sanghvi is Associate at Khaitan & Co. The views expressed are personal.)Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 6, 2025

Headline: How will senior citizens benefit from increased TDS limits?The tax reforms announced in Budget 2025 aim at lowering the compliance burden for elderly taxpayers, and giving them enhanced financial flexibility and security in their retirement years.
Content: The Union Budget 2025 presented on February 1, has brought some relief to senior citizens. The government announced key financial reforms aimed at lowering the tax burden and allowing better financial security for them. Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman introduced a raise in the tax deducted at source (TDS) threshold on interest for senior citizens. Previously, the limit was Rs 50,000 a year. But now, the limit is increased to Rs 1,00,000 from the financial year 2025-26, thereby leaving more money in the hands of senior citizens. Sneha Pai, Senior Director, Direct Tax, Nexdigm, welcomed this move by the government. “The majority source of income for a senior citizen is interests on deposits. The government has doubled the interest limit attracting tax withholding from Rs 50000 currently to Rs 100,000. The increase in limit leaves higher disposable amount in the hands of the senior citizen,” she said. “It also aligns with the fact that senior citizens have lower tax liabilities and are unnecessarily subjected to tax withholding on interest incomes,” Pai added. Also, the TDS limit for rent payments has been increased from Rs 2.40 lakh to Rs 6 lakh a year, thus lowering the compliance burden for elderly taxpayers, and giving them enhanced financial flexibility and security in their retirement years. Sakchi Jain, CA and Financial Educator said relief on rental income provides much-needed financial security for senior citizens. “Budget 2025 brings significant financial relief for senior citizens, ensuring better income security and tax benefits. The TDS exemption on interest income has been doubled from Rs 50,000 to Rs 1 lakh, allowing seniors to earn more from Fixed Deposits (FDs), Recurring Deposits (RDs), and savings accounts without tax deductions,” Jain said. “These measures collectively enhance disposable income, reduce tax liabilities, and provide greater financial security for senior citizens,” she added.Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Feb 6, 2025Tune InMust Watch

Headline: New Income Tax Bill likely to be approved by Cabinet tomorrow. Check key details The new legislation, often referred to as the Direct Tax Code, is aimed at overhauling the existing tax structure, making it more streamlined and transparent.
Content: The Union Cabinet may approve the new Income Tax Bill on Friday, paving the way for its introduction in the Lok Sabha as early as Monday, sources said. The bill is part of a broader push to reform the taxation system. The new legislation, which is often referred to as the Direct Tax Code, is aimed at overhauling the existing tax structure, making it more streamlined and transparent. While presenting the Union Budget 2025, Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced the government’s intent to bring a new Direct Tax Code. The bill is likely to be referred to the Standing Committee for further discussion and refinement of its provisions.WHAT WILL IT FOCUS ON? The government has already made it clear that the bill will not introduce any new taxes and just focus on simplifying tax laws, removing ambiguities, and ensuring ease of compliance for taxpayers. In addition, several amendments are expected to be introduced to the existing law, with a focus on reducing litigation. One of the provisions could include a reduction in penalties for certain offences, making the tax framework less punitive and more taxpayer-friendly. A crucial aspect of the new bill will be the simplification of legal language, ensuring that even ordinary taxpayers can easily understand tax provisions and their implications.advertisementPublished By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 6, 2025

Headline: Old vs New tax regime: Which one should you choose for income above Rs 12.75 lakh?Old vs New tax regime: What if you earn more than Rs 12.75 lakh? Should you pick the new tax regime for lower rates or stick to the old one for deductions?
Content:
The Union Budget 2025 introduced some major changes to the new income tax regime, aimed at providing relief to middle-class taxpayers. Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman proposed an increase in the basic exemption limit to Rs 4 lakh and raised the income threshold for rebate under Section 87A to Rs 12 lakh. With this, people earning an income of Rs 12 lakh from salary won't have to pay any tax. In fact, with a standard deduction of Rs 75,000, people with an annual income of Rs 12.75 lakh won't have to pay tax. This has made the choice simple for millions of taxpayers with income less than Rs 12.75 lakh. But what if you earn more than Rs 12.75 lakh? Should you still opt for the sweetened new income tax regime or the deduction-heavy old income tax regime? In this article, we will help you determine whether the old or new tax regime suits you better. WHEN SHOULD YOU OPT FOR THE NEW TAX REGIME? The new tax regime is ideal for taxpayers who: 1) Have an income of Rs 12 lakh or below, as they qualify for a full rebate under Section 87A. 2) Do not have deductions under Section 80C (such as Provident Fund, PPF, life insurance, or housing loan principal repayment) or Section 80D (medical insurance premium). 3) Prefer a simplified tax filing process with minimal compliance requirements. If you do not claim substantial deductions and want a hassle-free tax filing process, the new tax regime can be beneficial as it offers lower tax rates without the need for detailed documentation.WHEN SHOULD YOU OPT FOR THE OLD TAX REGIME? The old tax regime is more suitable for individuals who can claim high deductions, including: 1) Section 80C: Contributions to PF, PPF, life insurance premiums, repayment of the housing loan principal, etc. 2) Section 80D: Medical insurance premiums for self and family. 3) House Rent Allowance (HRA) and Leave Travel Allowance (LTA). $) Home loan interest deductions. The old tax regime allows taxpayers to reduce their taxable income significantly if they maximise these deductions. But for it to be more beneficial than the new tax regime, the total deductions must be higher than the break-even threshold for their income level.Below is a break-even analysis by CA Dr. Suresh Surana for annual income up to Rs 10 crore:  The table below provides a comparative analysis of the tax liability under both regimes and the minimum deductions needed to make the old tax regime more beneficial:

 



Break-even analysis by CA Dr. Suresh Surana.
KEY TAKEAWAYS If your total taxable income is Rs 12 lakh or below, the new tax regime is the obvious choice, as no tax is payable due to the rebate. If your deductions exceed the minimum break-even amount for your income slab (as shown in the last column of the table), then the old tax regime is preferable. If you have minimal deductions, opting for the new tax regime will result in lower tax liability and a simpler filing process.WHICH TAX REGIME SHOULD YOU CHOOSE?       High deduction claimers (especially above Rs 8.5 lakh in deductions) should stick with the old tax regime. Individuals with lower deductions should switch to the new tax regime to benefit from lower tax rates and reduced paperwork. Salaried individuals should also consider the standard deduction of Rs 75,000, which is available only under the new tax regime. Lastly, the choice between the old and new tax regime should ideally be made based on individual financial situations and tax-saving strategies. A tax consultant or CA can help evaluate the best option based on your income, deductions, and financial goals.Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 6, 2025

Headline: New Income Tax Bill: What is it and how will it help taxpayers?In order to make the Income Tax Act 1961 more concise and simpler, the government is introducing a new income tax bill.
Content: Finance Minister Nirmla Sitharaman in her budget speech revealed about the new income tax bill, which is likely to be presented in the Parliament on February 7, 2025. She said, “Over the past 10 years, our government has implemented several reforms for the convenience of taxpayers, such as faceless assessment, taxpayers charter, faster returns, almost 99 per cent returns being on self assessment, and Vivad se Vishwas scheme. Continuing these efforts, I reaffirm the commitment of the tax department to “trust first, scrutinise later”. I also propose to introduce the new income-tax bill next week.”advertisementWHY IS THERE A NEED FOR A NEW INCOME TAX BILL?The Income Tax Act 1961 has been in existence over the past six decades and has 298 sections and 23 chapters. Over the years, with the introduction of new amendments and revisions in almost every Union Budget, the present income tax bill has become very complex. The Income Tax Act 1961 has been in existence over the past six decades and has 298 sections and 23 chapters. Over the years, with the introduction of new amendments and revisions in almost every Union Budget, the present income tax bill has become very complex. Hence, in order to make the income tax bill more concise, the government is introducing a new income tax bill. The new bill is said to simplify tax compliance, lower disputes and offer greater clarity on taxes.WHAT TO EXPECT FROM THE NEW BILL? Sitharaman in her budget speech stated, “I am happy to inform the country that the new income-tax bill will carry forward the same spirit of “Nyaya”. The new bill will be clear and direct in text with close to half of the present law, in terms of both chapters and words. It will be simple to understand for taxpayers and tax administration, leading to tax certainty and reduced litigation." The new bill will be concise with simplified language, making it easier for taxpayers to understand and comply. Also, it aims to reduce legal ambiguities with streamlined tax laws and has been drafted in such a manner that it meets international standards.Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Feb 6, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Sensex, Nifty fall sharply as D-Street remains edgy ahead of RBI's rate decisionThe S&P BSE Sensex closed 213.12 points lower at 78,058.16 and the NSE Nifty50 settled 92.95 points lower at 23,603.35.
Content:
Benchmark stock market indices ended the trading session on a weak note as volatility gripped Dalal Street ahead of the Reserve Bank of India’s crucial rate decision.There are expectations that the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) of the RBI will cut the repo rate by 25 bps and maintain a neutral stance.At the same time, there is also uncertainty due to factors like the falling rupee and inflation.The S&P BSE Sensex closed 213.12 points lower at 78,058.16 and the NSE Nifty50 settled 92.95 points lower at 23,603.35.Most of the other broader market indices also fell during the volatile session, in which the Nifty FMCG and Nifty Realty indices were worst hit.The top five gainers on the Nifty50 were ITC Hotels, Cipla, Adani Ports, HDFC Life and Dr Reddy's. On the other hand, the top losers were Trent, BEL, Bharti Airtel, Titan and ONGC.advertisementPrashanth Tapse, Senior VP (Research), Mehta Equities Ltd, said, "Despite logging sharp gains in the first few minutes of opening trades, markets slipped into the red and moved in a narrow range with a negative bias for most part of the trading session.""Investors booked profits in rate-sensitives like realty, banking, and auto shares ahead of tomorrow's monetary policy announcement. If there is any surprise rate cut, we may see short-term optimism," he added.Vinod Nair, Head of Research, Geojit Financial Services, said, "The benchmark indices experienced a moderate decline as investors awaited the RBI's decision on a potential rate cut amidst the ongoing trade war.""The broader market remained cautious, in a consolidation phase, despite the government's focus on boosting consumption to cushion lower growth. Meanwhile, the IT and Pharma sectors advanced supported by lower treasury yields after moderating US PMI data, encouraging the Fed to reduce interest rates," he added.Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 6, 2025Must Watch
