Headline: Sensex tanks over 600 points: 3 reasons why stock market is falling todayThe BSE Sensex lost over 600 points, while the NSE Nifty dropped close to 200 points in early trade. The Sensex fell to the day's low of 77,189.04 after closing at 77,860.19 in the previous session.
Content: Stock markets fell sharply in early trade on Monday, despite the Reserve Bank of India's (RBI) rate cut and the Bharatiya Janata Party's (BJP) victory in the Delhi elections. The benchmark indices opened lower and continued to decline as selling pressure intensified. The BSE Sensex lost over 600 points, while the NSE Nifty dropped close to 200 points in early trade. The Sensex fell to the day's low of 77,189.04 after closing at 77,860.19 in the previous session. As of 10:30 AM, the Sensex was down by 579.15 points to 77,281.04, while the Nifty50 declined by 177.90 points to 23,382.05. Market experts pointed to multiple factors driving the selloff. Kranthi Bathini, Director of Equity Strategy at WealthMills Securities, said that foreign investors continue to sell their holdings, which is adding pressure on the market. "Indian markets are witnessing selling pressure from foreign portfolio investors. After the rate cut and also, the recent budget, it's not able to enthuse the foreign portfolio investors. They continued to be the sellers. One thing is the earning traction, okay, that has been missing in the markets in the medium to short term. That's creating pressure on Indian markets. As long as Nifty is about 23,000, the medium to short term direction is in a positive direction," said Bathini. RUPEE HITS ALL-TIME LOW The rupee weakened to a record low on Monday as concerns over potential U.S. trade tariffs led to losses in regional currencies. Traders told Reuters that the RBI may step in to stabilise the currency if needed. In early trade, the rupee slipped to 87.95 per U.S. dollar, breaching its previous record low of 87.58 from last week. As of the latest update, it was trading at 87.93, down 0.6% for the day. A weaker rupee increases the cost of imports, particularly crude oil, and affects foreign investment sentiment. Analysts believe that if the trend continues, the RBI may have to take further steps to stabilise the currency.METAL STOCK DRAG MARKET LOWER Metal stocks were among the worst performers as US President Donald Trump announced new tariffs on steel and aluminium imports. Speaking to reporters on Air Force One, Trump said that the new 25% tariffs would be imposed on all steel and aluminium imports, in addition to existing duties. He mentioned that the official announcement would be made on Monday, with tariffs coming into effect almost immediately. The news led to a sharp selloff in metal stocks in India. The Nifty Metal index dropped 2.94%, with major companies witnessing steep declines. Vedanta Limited fell 4.61%, while Steel Authority of India (SAIL) lost 4.16%. Tata Steel declined 3.48%, and JSW Steel was down 3.04%. National Aluminium Company dropped 2.90%, NMDC lost 2.88%, and Jindal Steel & Power fell 2.35%. The broad decline in metal stocks reflected fears of lower demand and pricing pressure due to the new tariffs.WHAT'S AHEAD?  The recent Delhi election results were expected to bring some stability to market sentiment, but global concerns and foreign investor activity have overshadowed the impact. Analysts at Motilal Oswal Financial Services (MOFSL) noted that the BJP’s victory in Delhi should be a positive sign for markets, as it eases concerns about political stability at the Centre. The BJP secured 48 out of 70 seats in the Delhi Assembly elections, ending a 27-year gap in its rule in the state. MOFSL attributed the win to the party's campaign focus on "double-engine" governance, Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s leadership, and a strong anti-incumbency factor against the Aam Aadmi Party (AAP). While this result is expected to boost confidence, MOFSL believes that market attention will now return to corporate earnings, company guidance, and global economic trends. Uncertainty over U.S. trade policies and foreign investor selling could continue to impact the market in the coming days.Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 10, 2025

Headline: 5 common UPI-related frauds and tips to prevent them  Fraudsters often at times impersonate banks or organisations and trick victims to reveal sensitive information like UPI account, OTP and PIN details.
Content: With the rise in digitalisation, UPI transactions are also increasing. In January 2025, the UPI processed 16.99 billion transactions in a month worth Rs 23.48 lakh crore, as per the National Payments Corporation of India (NPCI) data. However, this has also led to a surge in UPI-related frauds and scams. In FY 2023-24, banking sector-related fraud cases surged by nearly 300%, reaching 36,075 cases, while fraud cases jumped by 27% Y-O-Y to 18,461 cases in the first half of FY 2024-25, reveals RBI data. Let us look at some of the common UPI-related frauds.PHISHING Here, fraudsters send fake UPI links which look similar to the original URL of the merchant. On clicking the link, users are directed to malicious apps where auto-debit happens, thereby causing victims to lose their money.SENDING FAKE REFUND MESSAGES  Some fraudsters send requests urging users to send back the money which was mistakenly transferred to them. While the initial credit and messages are fake, the payment made by the victim is real.SIM CLONING Here fraudsters create a duplicate sim of the victim’s mobile number. They then use this SIM card to access the victim’s UPI account and transfer the amount without the victim’s knowledge.IMPERSONATION Fraudsters often at times impersonate banks or organisations and trick victims to reveal sensitive information like UPI account, OTP and PIN details.THROUGH ANY DESK  Sometimes fraudsters trick gullible victims, impersonating bank employees or customer care representatives and convince them to download screen-sharing apps like Any Desk. They then access the victim’s computer or mobile phone, and carry out fraudulent transactions. Below are a few tips to prevent UPI fraud. Never share your UPI PIN with strangers or any person you don’t trust, do not click on any online link irrespective of how tempting it might seem to click, and always be cautious of dubious applications and never download apps from untrusted sources.Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Feb 10, 2025

Headline: New income tax regime: Check revised tax rates, slabs, and will you benefit? Will the new tax regime put more money in your pocket, or should you stick with the old regime? Here is all you need to know.
Content: The new income tax regime is set to become the preferred option for the majority of taxpayers in the upcoming financial year, following the proposals in the Union Budget 2025. Taxpayers couldn’t have asked for more from Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman. Income tax rates have been slashed, and tax slabs have been rationalised further.  The basic exemption, or income free from taxation, has been increased to Rs 4 lakh. Those earning up to Rs 12 lakh do not have to pay any tax under the new regime due to the increased tax rebate under Section 87A. In fact, salaried individuals with an annual income of Rs 12.75 lakh won't have to pay any tax, given the standard deduction of Rs 75,000 under the new regime.  High-income earners (above Rs 24 lakh per annum) will also benefit under the new regime, and are likely to save Rs 1.1 lakh in tax annually.WHO BENEFITS?  The changes in the new tax regime will provide substantial relief to middle-class taxpayers, particularly those who previously relied on deductions and exemptions to reduce their tax liability. With wider tax slabs, many will find that even without these benefits, their overall tax outgo is lower. Take the case of Rajeev Sharma, a Mumbai-based IT professional earning Rs 20 lakh annually. Under the old regime, he used deductions under Sections 80C, 80D, and HRA to bring his taxable income down, but this required a lot of financial planning. However, under the new regime, with a higher basic exemption and revised slabs, his tax burden will reduce by Rs 30,000 without the need to optimise exemptions. The new income tax regime is also a clear winner for those in the Rs 12-24 lakh income bracket. For instance, Ritu Arora, a marketing executive in Bengaluru, used to pay Rs 3.2 lakh in taxes on her Rs 22 lakh salary under the old tax regime after deductions. But under the new tax regime, her tax liability will now drop by nearly Rs 50,000.FOR INCOME BETWEEN RS 24-50 LAKH While middle-income taxpayers benefit, the reforms also extend to high-income groups. Individuals earning between Rs 24 lakh and Rs 50 lakh will now save Rs 1.1 lakh annually. Consider Akash Mehta, a business consultant in Delhi with a salary of Rs 35 lakh. Previously, he relied on deductions for home loan interest, NPS, and insurance premiums to manage his tax liability. The new regime’s rationalised slabs, however, mean he will save on tax without any additional investment planning. While he will miss out on exemptions, his tax savings will still amount to Rs 85,000 per year.OLD VS NEW REGIME: WHICH WORKS BEST FOR YOU? Despite the advantages, not everyone will benefit from switching. Those with substantial deductions, such as high home loan interest payments and corporate NPS contributions, may find the old regime more advantageous. Take Meghna Sinha, a senior banking executive earning Rs 60 lakh annually. Her deductions and exemptions total Rs 8.5 lakh, thanks to investments, home loan interest, and tax-saving schemes. Even with the new slabs, her tax outgo is around Rs 84,000 lower under the old regime. Simply put, the new tax regime offers better benefits than before, but taxpayers should assess their finances before making the switch. According to tax experts, those with minimal deductions are likely to benefit the most, while individuals with high exemptions and a high annual income might still prefer the old system.Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 10, 2025

Headline: When will your home, auto loans EMIs get cheaper after RBI rate cut?Experts say that borrowers with repo rate-linked loans will see an immediate or near-term reduction, while those with MCLR-linked loans may have to wait longer.
Content: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) recently cut the key repo rate by 25 basis points for the first time in nearly five years, offering relief to home and auto loan borrowers. However, the timing of lower loan rates depends on the type of loan one has. Experts say that borrowers with repo rate-linked loans will see an immediate or near-term reduction, while those with MCLR-linked loans may have to wait longer.advertisementWHY THE DELAY FOR MCLR LOANS?Following the rate cut, RBI Deputy Governor Swaminathan J, said, "We will see an immediate impact on loans linked to external benchmarks. In loans linked to MCLR, it will take two quarters for the effect to play out.” Following the rate cut, RBI Deputy Governor Swaminathan J, said, "We will see an immediate impact on loans linked to external benchmarks. In loans linked to MCLR, it will take two quarters for the effect to play out.” “The existing deposits will be carried on the contracted rate; only the new deposits will see changes. So, monetary policy transmission to deposit rates will also take about two quarters,” he added. Shivaji Thapliyal, Head of Research at Yes Securities, also said, “Banks will reprice repo rate-linked loans lower by 25 bps immediately or in the near term. However, they will manage net interest margins through various levers, including MCLR repricing.” Loans tied to MCLR (Marginal Cost of Funds-Based Lending Rate) take longer to reflect rate cuts because they are influenced by factors like a bank’s cost of funds, deposit rates, and operating expenses. With high competition for deposits, a liquidity deficit, and elevated funding costs, banks are unlikely to pass on the full benefit quickly. An expert told The Economic Times that sustained transmission of rate cuts would require a surplus liquidity environment, which is currently lacking. Without additional liquidity measures, banks could face a deficit of up to Rs 2.5 lakh crore by March-end, further pressuring rate transmission.HOW LONG WILL IT TAKE? For borrowers with MCLR-linked loans, the impact of the rate cut could take at least two quarters to materialise. These loans typically have a six-month reset period, meaning the revised rates may only take effect next year. On the other hand, external benchmark-linked loans, such as those tied to the repo rate, will see faster transmission. Since these loans are directly linked to the RBI’s policy rate, banks are required to pass on rate changes almost immediately, usually within a month. As a result, borrowers with repo rate-linked loans should expect their EMIs to reduce sooner compared to those under MCLR.Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 10, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Edelweiss MF CEO Radhika Gupta on SIPs: 'Don't fall for fear-mongering'Radhika Gupta reiterated that patience and a long-term approach are essential for SIP investors.
Content: Edelweiss Mutual Fund CEO Radhika Gupta has urged investors to stay patient and ignore the fear-mongering over mid-cap and small-cap Systematic Investment Plans (SIPs). In a post on social media platform X, Gupta also highlighted the importance of long-term investments. "The SIP was meant to be a simple savings-investment instrument for the common person. A fill it, shut it, forget it one because most people struggle with markets, market caps, and SIPs," she said. She explained that balanced allocation is essential when investing in these segments. "Everything, including mid and small, is good in balance. Even an average flexi-cap fund has 30% allocation to this category," she noted. Addressing concerns about volatility, Gupta pointed out that returns can appear unattractive when measured from peak to trough periods. "If you look at the returns of anything from the top of the cycle to the bottom (e.g., 2006 to 2013), they will not look pleasant," she said. Liquidity, according to her, remains a crucial factor. "Liquidity is very important and can be managed. We have disclosed liquidity numbers in our funds well before regulators asked and maintain this liquidity, without taking cash calls or holding a lot of large-cap," she added. Gupta reiterated that patience and a long-term approach are essential for SIP investors. "The critical thing that no one can disagree about is that the key to making money is to hold on to SIPs for a long time. 10 years. More," she said. Citing the performance of Edelweiss Mutual Fund’s midcap fund, which was launched in 2007, she said, "Here are the rolling 10-year lump sum returns, the minimum return is 10%. The minimum SIP return is 8%. Regular plan. Nothing can convince me these are bad numbers. And by the way, no negative returns in 10 years." She advised investors not to be swayed by short-term concerns or market noise. "Don't fall for fear-mongering or 10-day debates. Focus on finding a good manager and holding for 10 years, in a sensible balanced way," she added. (Disclaimer: The views, opinions, recommendations, and suggestions expressed by experts/brokerages in this article are their own and do not reflect the views of the India Today Group. It is advisable to consult a qualified broker or financial advisor before making any actual investment or trading choices.)Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 10, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Markets bleed as investors lose Rs 6 lakh crore: Will the fall continue? The fall in the stock market led to a loss of Rs 6 lakh crore in investor wealth as market bulls took control of the Dalal Street.
Content: The stock markets faced a sharp decline on Monday, with both the Sensex and Nifty falling by nearly 1%. The drop came amid concerns over global trade after US President Donald Trump warned of new tariffs and rupee hitting its all-time low didn't help the Dalal Street either. The fall in the stock market led to a loss of Rs 6 lakh crore in investor wealth as market bulls took control of the Dalal Street. The BSE Sensex was trading 704.40 points, or 0.90%, lower at 77,155.79, while the NSE Nifty50 was down 226.90 points, or 0.96%, at 23,333.05 around 2:20 PM. Kranthi Bathini, Director of Equity Strategy at WealthMills Securities, said that foreign investors continue to sell their holdings despite the recent rate cut from RBI and tax saving measures in the Union Budget. The rupee weakened to its lowest level ever on Monday due to concerns over U.S. trade policies. In early trade, the rupee slipped to 87.95 per U.S. dollar, breaking its previous low of 87.58 from last week. It was last trading at 87.93, down 0.6% for the day. Metal stocks saw heavy selling after U.S. President Donald Trump announced plans to impose new 25% tariffs on all steel and aluminium imports. Trump said the announcement would be made on Monday, and the tariffs would take effect almost immediately.WILL D-STREET SEE MORE DECLINE?  Market analysts believe that the sharp fall may not be over yet, as multiple factors continue to affect investor sentiment. Dr. VK Vijayakumar, Chief Investment Strategist at Geojit Financial Services, said that despite the BJP’s strong performance in the Delhi elections, the market is unlikely to see a sustained rally. He said that with the U.S. dollar index above 108 and the 10-year U.S. bond yield above 4.4%, foreign investors are likely to continue selling. This will limit any major gains in the stock market. The recent depreciation of the rupee has also raised concerns. The rupee fell 49 paise on Monday to hit 87.92 against the U.S. dollar. The decline was driven by losses in Asian currencies following Trump’s tariff announcement. The RBI’s latest policy decision to cut the repo rate by 25 basis points (bps) was expected due to the economic slowdown. However, the central bank has not shifted to an accommodative stance due to global uncertainty. Analysts at Nuvama Institutional Equities said that the RBI is likely to cut rates further in the coming year, but it will move cautiously due to global economic risks. They expect economic growth to remain slow in the near term and believe that aggressive rate cuts by the U.S. Federal Reserve or an improvement in exports could help the Indian economy recover. Dr. Vijayakumar said that valuations in the Indian stock market are still high, especially in midcap and smallcap stocks. He said the market needs strong triggers such as better GDP growth and corporate earnings to see a sustained recovery. Until then, he believes the market is likely to remain within a specific range, with no major uptrend. He advised investors to focus on high-quality largecap stocks that are fairly valued, as they are expected to be more stable in the current market conditions. The Sensex and Nifty have already corrected by 10-11% from their all-time highs, while the BSE midcap and smallcap indices have fallen 15% each from their 52-week highs. Some stocks have lost as much as 50% from their peak values. Despite concerns, analysts at Motilal Oswal Financial Services (MOFSL) believe the BJP’s win in Delhi will boost confidence in the market. They said that with the Union Budget behind and the RBI taking steps to ease liquidity, market sentiment may improve slightly. However, they warned that global factors, such as Trump’s trade policies and foreign investor selling, could continue to create uncertainty. They recommend investors to focus more on largecap stocks rather than midcap and smallcap stocks due to valuation differences.Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 10, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Bears rampage Dalal Street as Sensex, Nifty close lower on US tariff fearsThe BSE Sensex dropped 548.79 points to close at 77,311.80, while the NSE Nifty50 lost 178.35 points to end at 23,381.60.
Content: Benchmark stock market indices closed after shedding 1% on Monday on cue from global markets, with both Sensex and Nifty ending in the red. The decline came as investors reacted to US President Donald Trump's latest threat to impose new tariffs on steel and aluminium imports. The BSE Sensex dropped 548.79 points to close at 77,311.80, while the NSE Nifty50 lost 178.35 points to end at 23,381.60. This marked the fourth straight session of losses for the benchmark indices, with Sensex and Nifty falling by 1.5% during this period. The rupee fell to an all-time low, adding to market worries. A weaker rupee increases import costs and affects companies with high foreign debt, making investors more cautious. Vinod Nair, Head of Research, Geojit Financial Services, said, "The US tariff threats continued to impact the market sentiment. Domestic yield is inching higher as investors stay cautious on riskier assets and navigate their investments to safe haven assets like gold. On the earnings front, the companies are facing downgrades in estimates due to a weak demand environment, margin pressure, and a cautious near-term outlook." The metal sector saw heavy losses as concerns grew over the impact of U.S. tariffs. The Nifty Metal index was one of the worst-performing sectors, tumbling 2.6%. Tata Steel dropped 3.1%, making it one of the top Nifty 50 losers. Other major metal stocks such as JSW Steel, Hindalco Industries, and Vedanta also declined. Analysts said Trump's tariff announcement could lead to an oversupply of metals in other markets, which may reduce base metal prices. This added pressure on metal stocks, which are already facing challenges due to margin concerns. The broader market also witnessed selling pressure. Midcap and smallcap stocks fell sharply, with both the Nifty Midcap 100 and Smallcap 100 indices declining by 2.1% each. HDFC Bank and Reliance Industries, two of the biggest stocks in Sensex and Nifty, dropped 1% each. Experts believe that the selling in mid and smallcap stocks is due to high valuations and concerns over earnings growth. All 13 major sectors ended in the red. Banking stocks faced profit booking, with HDFC Bank and ICICI Bank slipping by 1% each. FMCG stocks traded weak as concerns over rural demand continued to weigh on investor sentiment. IT stocks remained under pressure due to global uncertainty and currency volatility. VLA Ambala, Co-Founder of Stock Market Today said that as an economy, we could remain in a bear phase, further affected by slower GDP growth, depreciating rupee, continuous tariff threats, weak domestic demand, costlier imports, and a widening trade deficit. "Collectively, these factors hint at a prolonged bear phase. Besides these, Nifty and Sensex have already corrected by 12% this quarter and are likely to slump further, as current market conditions could leave a lasting impact on company earnings and GDP growth. Considering these aspects, the index could gain support between 23,200 and 23,050 and face resistance between 23,410 and 23,480 in the next session," she added. Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 10, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Opt for new income tax regime, but don't stop investing. Here's why Tax-savings incentives like the Public Provident Fund (PPF), National Savings Certificate (NSC) and Equity-Linked Savings Scheme (ELSS) not only helped individuals lower their taxes but also induced disciplined savings habits, particularly among young people in developing financial prudence early in their careers.
Content: Several tax-incentives were introduced in Budget 2025 under the new tax regime. While these tax reliefs are aimed at reducing taxes and easing compliance, many people are wondering if it would impact their savings habits. The old income tax regime offered several tax-savings incentives under Section 80C, like the Public Provident Fund (PPF), National Savings Certificate (NSC) and Equity-Linked Savings Scheme (ELSS), and life insurance premiums. The interest being offered under these schemes ranges from 7.9% to 15%. It helps taxpayers to choose from a variety of options that best suit their financial goals and preferences. Moreover, Section 80C served a dual purpose. It not only helped in reducing taxable income, but also developed disciplined savings habits. Taxpayers, particularly young people, begin investing in them, thereby developing financial prudence early in their careers. The mandatory lock-in period in most of the tax-saving instruments under Section 80C, instils long-term financial discipline and encourages goal-based financial planning. Further, investing regularly helps build wealth over a period of time, allowing money to work and generating returns which simple savings can not. In an era with changing family structures, regular investments help create a corpus for children’s higher education, buying a house, going for a holiday, and setting aside funds for retirement and contingencies. With increasing life expectancy, retirement planning and setting aside funds for contingencies has become essential. Hence, investment in pension schemes, or mutual funds ensures steady returns even after retirement. On the other hand, the government has announced reduced tax slabs under the new tax regime, to make it more attractive for taxpayers. It has done away with most of the deductions and exemptions. Some people might say that it may lead to reduced savings, as people would lack any motivation to invest in tax-saving investments and become spendthrifts. In fact, investments are not just about deductions, they help build funds and derive the benefit of compounding over a period of time and ensure financial independence in later years. Also, experts say that the annual rush to make tax-saving investments helped people develop the habit of saving. In other words, one should not get discouraged in the absence of tax-savings deductions. As we move towards a simplified tax regime, people should think of new ways that motivate them to make prudent financial choices and investment decisions.Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Feb 10, 2025Tune InMust Watch

Headline: Own more than 1 property? Why you don't need to worry about additional taxThe reform announced in Budget 2025 regarding two self-occupied properties would encourage investment across the country's real-estate segment and would also enhance affordability for homebuyers.
Content: The Union Budget 2025 has provided the much-needed relief for home buyers. Now, house owners can claim nil annual value for up to two self-occupied houses. This implies that one does not have to pay taxes on the second house if it's not rented out. Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman in her speech said, “Presently taxpayers can claim the annual value of self-occupied properties as nil only on the fulfilment of certain conditions. Considering the difficulties faced by taxpayers, it is proposed to allow the benefit of two such self-occupied properties without any condition.” This move has been welcomed by taxpayers as it reduces their financial burden and brings ease in tax compliance. Sakchi Jain, CA and Financial Educator, said that the move has made homeownership more affordable.  "Budget 2025 introduces key reforms aimed at tax relief, financial inclusion, and economic stability. Homebuyers now benefit from tax relief on two self-occupied properties, making homeownership more accessible," she said. "One major change is in house property taxation. Previously, tax relief was available only for one self-occupied house. Now, if you own two houses and live in both, you can claim tax benefits on both properties, making homeownership more affordable," Jain mentioned. Kaushal Agarwal, Co-Founder & Director of The Guardians Real Estate Advisory said that the tax exemption of two self-occupied houses has eased the financial burden and simplified compliance. “The Union Budget 2025 brings significant relief for homeowners by allowing tax benefits on two self-occupied properties instead of just one. Earlier, individuals had to pay tax on the notional rental income of a second home, adding to their financial burden. This change simplifies tax compliance and recognises the need for housing flexibility, especially for families with homes in different cities for work, investment, or personal reasons,” he said. Chandresh Vithalani, Partner at Palladian Partners Ltd said that the tax benefits on two self-occupied houses will give a boost to the real-estate market. “The Union Budget 2025 delivers a strong push for the real estate sector through a well-rounded approach that balances affordability, investment incentives, and project completion. By increasing the income tax exemption limit, homebuyers now have greater purchasing power, enhancing demand for residential properties,” he said. “The move to allow tax benefits on two self-occupied properties instead of just one encourages multiple homeownership, making real estate a more attractive long-term investment avenue,” Vithalani added. In other words, the reform would encourage investment across the country’s real-estate segment, enhance affordability for homebuyers, thereby strengthening market confidence.Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Feb 10, 2025Tune InMust Watch

Headline: Sensex falls nearly 200 points, Nifty struggles in early tradeThe S&P BSE Sensex was down 197.45 points to 77,114.35 at 9:29 am, while the NSE Nifty50 fell 62.90 points to trade at 23,318.70. All the other broader market indices were also trading in negative territory.
Content: Benchmark stock market indices opened the trading session on a negatively, continuing their weak run as foreign institutional investors (FIIs) continue to dump their holdings. The S&P BSE Sensex was down 197.45 points to 77,114.35 at 9:29 am, while the NSE Nifty50 fell 62.90 points to trade at 23,318.70. All the other broader market indices were also trading in negative territory. Major sectoral indices such as Nifty Bank and Nifty Financial Services were trading weaker; Nifty IT was the only index that was trading in the green, but only marginally. The top 5 gainers on the Nifty50 were Adani Enterprises, Grasim, Hindalco, Infosys and Tata Consumer Products. On the other hand, the top losers were Eicher Motors, Apollo Hospitals, Power Grid, Coal India and BPCL. Dr. V K Vijayakumar, Chief Investment Strategist, Geojit Financial Services, said, “The significant trend in the ongoing bearish phase of the market is the outperformance of largecaps over the broader market. While the Nifty Midcap and Smallcap indices are down 8.6% and 11.3% respectively YTD, the Nifty is down only 1.52%. This outperformance is likely to continue, going forward.” “The relentless selling by FIIs in largecaps has made their valuations fair while the valuations of mid and smallcaps continue to be excessive. FIIs will certainly turn buyers in India; but that will happen only when the dollar index turns weak. We know that it will happen, but don’t know when. What investors have to do now is to buy quality largecaps in banking, IT, autos, pharma and capital goods and wait patiently,” he added. “When FIIs turn buyers in India, which is inevitable, they will be buying the largecaps which they are selling now. For patient investors, this is a good opportunity.”Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 11, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Nokia picks Intel's AI and data centre leader Justin Hotard as new CEOJustin Hotard, who will take up the position on April 1, is currently the executive vice president and general manager of Data Center & AI Group at Intel, according to the chipmaker's website.
Content: Finnish telecoms company Nokia on Monday said Pekka Lundmark would step down as CEO, and that it has appointed Justin Hotard to take over his role. Hotard, who will take up the position on April 1, is currently the executive vice president and general manager of Data Center & AI Group at Intel, according to the chipmaker's website. Telecom gear makers, struggling with lower sales of 5G equipment, have been looking for ways to diversify their markets and break into growing areas such as artificial intelligence. "He has a strong track record of accelerating growth in technology companies along with vast expertise in AI and data centre markets, which are critical areas for Nokia's future growth," Nokia's Chair Sari Baldauf said in a statement. Shares were up 1.6% at 4.7 euros by 0854 GMT on Helsinki's stock exchange, which was up just 0.45%. JPMorgan analysts called the CEO transition a surprise as they said Lundmark had been successful at "steadying the ship". "Given that a new CEO has already been appointed, it looks like this transition was in the works for some time. With the Datacentre and AI background of the new CEO, it is clear which areas Nokia wants to focus on," they said in a note. This view was echoed by analysts at Inderes, who see the change as a strategic shift towards Nokia's Network Infrastructure unit, where data centres and AI investments are fostering new growth opportunities. Last year, Nokia made a move to buy US optical networking gear maker Infinera in a $2.3 billion deal to gain from the billions of dollars in investment pouring into data centres to cater to the rise of artificial intelligence. Lundmark, who was appointed as Nokia's CEO in 2020, will stay on as an advisor to Hotard until the end of the year, the company said. In September, Nokia declined media reports saying the company was looking for a new chief executive. "The planning for this leadership transition was initiated when Pekka indicated to the Board that he would like to consider moving on from executive roles when the repositioning of the business was in a more advanced stage, and when the right successor had been identified," Baldauf said. Nokia shares are up 27.85% over the past year, but are down more than 90% since peaking in June 2000. Its infrastructure business, increasingly integrating AI technologies, focuses on building and maintaining communication systems, including data centres, servers, and routers. Its mobile networks unit concentrates on technologies and services enabling mobile communication, including the development and management of cell towers and 5G technologies.Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 11, 2025

Headline: Stock market sell-off hurting your portfolio? Here's what you can doThe ongoing stock market sell-off has hit retail investors hard, dragging portfolios deep into the red.
Content:
Retail investors have been under pressure due to the ongoing volatility in the stock market, primarily set off by the relentless sell-off by foreign institutional investors (FIIs). To make matters worse, US President Donald Trump’s tariff action has further deteriorated the mood on Dalal Street, leading to high volatility. Even the tax cuts in the Union Budget 2025 and the RBI’s 25 bps rate cut have not been able to reduce the market anxiety, and experts have indicated that the benchmark indices could remain under pressure for a prolonged period. The market selloff has hit retail investors hard, dragging portfolios deep into the red. But what should one do to avoid further losses amid the ongoing market correction? According to experts, being patient and investing in large-cap stocks could be an ideal option. Dr. VK Vijayakumar, Chief Investment Strategist at Geojit Financial Services, suggested that the ongoing market weakness presents an opportunity, especially in large-cap stocks.WHERE TO INVEST AND WHERE NOT TO? While mid-cap and small-cap stocks have faced steeper declines, Vijayakumar pointed out that large-caps have held up better.He also said that on a year-to-date (YTD) basis, the Nifty Mid-cap and Small-cap indices have fallen 8.6% and 11.3%, respectively, whereas the Nifty50 has only lost 1.52%. He suggested that this trend is likely to persist. While mid-cap and small-cap stocks have faced steeper declines, Vijayakumar pointed out that large-caps have held up better. He also said that on a year-to-date (YTD) basis, the Nifty Mid-cap and Small-cap indices have fallen 8.6% and 11.3%, respectively, whereas the Nifty50 has only lost 1.52%. He suggested that this trend is likely to persist. “The relentless selling by FIIs in large-caps has made their valuations fair, while mid- and small-caps remain overvalued,” Vijayakumar said. Retail investors, who often follow market trends rather than fundamentals, should take advantage of this phase rather than panic-sell.WHAT SECTORS SHOULD BE ON YOUR RADAR? Vijayakumar said investors looking to navigate the ongoing market volatility should focus on quality large-cap stocks in banking, IT, automobiles, pharmaceuticals, and capital goods.These sectors have strong fundamentals and could attract fresh FII inflows once global conditions turn favourable.“When FIIs turn buyers in India, which is inevitable, they will be buying the large-caps caps that they are selling now. For patient investors, this is a good opportunity,” he said.For investors facing losses in their portfolios, the message is clear: instead of panic-selling, consider accumulating fundamentally strong large-cap stocks that are now available at fair valuations.(Disclaimer: The views, opinions, recommendations, and suggestions expressed by experts/brokerages in this article are their own and do not reflect the views of the India Today Group. Headline: Explained: Why Zomato share price plunged over 5% todayZomato stock price: Shares of the company have been under pressure ever since global brokerage firm Jefferies raised concerns over rising competition in the quick commerce space.
Content: Shares of food delivery giant Zomato fell over 5% in early trade on Tuesday, continuing its poor run. Zomato shares were down 5.24% to Rs 215.25 on the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) at 11:01 am. The stock is down nearly 9% in the past five trading sessions. Shares of the company have been under pressure ever since global brokerage firm Jefferies raised concerns over rising competition in the quick commerce space. Jefferies analysts quoted in a CNBC-TV18 report raised concerns over profitability due to the rising competition and discounting pressures affecting profitability. While 2024 was a breakout year for Zomato’s stock in terms of valuation growth, Jefferies analysts indicated that trend of high growth is unlikely in 2025 due to the intense competition in the Q-com sector. Jefferies has downgraded Zomato’s stock to ‘hold’ from ‘buy’ and slashed the target price to Rs 275 from Rs 335. The brokerage firm, however, indicated that Zomato’s valuation is not “excessively expensive”, citing the company’s strong execution and opportunity in the quick commerce space. Jefferies fears that the intense competition in the sector, with aggressive strategies by existing players and entry of new competitors, could lead to higher discount offers that could hurt Zomato’s medium-term profitability. Considering these factors, Jefferies has sharply reduced Blinkit's EBITDA forecast for FY26-27 and halved its target multiple to 6x. For Zomato, the brokerage cut EBITDA estimates by 12% for FY26 and 15% for FY25, while lowering profitability projections by 17% for FY26 and 18% for FY27. EPS estimates were also slashed by 20% for FY26 and 21% for FY27. (Disclaimer: The views, opinions, recommendations, and suggestions expressed by experts/brokerages in this article are their own and do not reflect the views of the India Today Group. It is advisable to consult a qualified broker or financial advisor before making any actual investment or trading choices.)Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 11, 2025

Headline: India 1st G20 country to achieve Paris Agreement goals, says PM Narendra ModiPrime Minister Narendra Modi also outlined various other green energy targets to achieve by the year 2030, calling them ambitious yet possible given the excellent track record in the past 10 years.
Content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Tuesday virtually inaugurated India Energy Week 2025, and said that the nation wants to add 500 Gw of renewable energy capacity. The Prime Minister also outlined various other green energy targets to achieve by the year 2030, calling them ambitious yet possible given the excellent track record in the past 10 years.  In the past 10 years, we have become the 5th largest economy and increased our solar capacity by 32 times. India is the 3rd largest solar power generating nation in the world," said PM Modi while addressing the summit.  He further said that India is the 1st country to achieve the target laid down in the Paris Agreement among the G20 nations. Paris Agreement is a legally binding international treaty on climate change.  It was adopted by 196 parties at the UN Climate Change Conference (COP21) in Paris, France, on 12 December 2015. It entered into force on 4 November 2016.  "We are on our way to achieving the 20% ethanol mandate. During India's G20 presidency, the global biofuel alliance was formed and has been expanding ever since. 28 nations and 12 international organisations are now a part of it. It has been converting waste into wealth," said PM Modi.  He also talked about the increasing use of natural gas in the nation due to robust infrastructure and said that the sector also offers great investment opportunities.  The India Energy Week 2025 is taking place from February 11–14, 2025 in New Delhi, India, at the Yashobhoomi. Published By: Sonu VivekPublished On: Feb 11, 2025

Headline: Why Eicher Motors shares dropped 7% despite record Royal Enfield sales in Q3Eicher Motors stock price fell nearly 7% in early trade despite reporting a 18% year-on-year rise in consolidated net profit.
Content:
Shares of Eicher Motors fell nearly 7% in early trade on Tuesday despite reporting positive figures in its Q3FY25 results. The stock tumbled as much as 6.8% to hit an intraday low of Rs 4,966.15 after brokerage firm Goldman Sachs downgraded its target price.Eicher Motors reported an 18% year-on-year (YoY) rise in consolidated net profit to Rs 1,171 crore, while the company's revenue from operations rose 19% to Rs 4,973 crore. Its EBITDA increased 10% YoY to Rs 1,201 crore.GOLDMAN SACHS CUTS TARGET PRICEWhile Eicher Motors put up a good show in the third quarter, the foreign brokerage cut its FY25-27 earnings per share (EPS) by 5.4%, citing higher expenses. While Goldman Sachs did maintain its 'Buy' rating, it has lowered its target price on the stock to Rs 5,900 from Rs 6,000.Despite a strong financial performance, Goldman Sachs cut its FY25-27 EPS estimates by 5.4%, citing higher marketing expenses. The brokerage maintained a ‘Buy’ rating but lowered the stock's target price from Rs 6,000 to Rs 5,900.It may be noted that Eicher Motors' commercial vehicle arm, VE Commercial Vehicles (VECV), recorded a 6% YoY rise in revenue to Rs 5,801 corer and its EBITDA climbed 16% to Rs 509 crore. Profit after tax surged 44% to Rs 301 crore. VECV recorded its highest-ever quarterly sales volume at 21,012 units, outperforming the industry despite a sluggish commercial vehicle market.In addition, the company's flagship Royal Enfield motorcycle also delivered its best-ever quarter, selling 269,039 motorcycles—up 17% YoY—driven by strong global demand. CEO B Govindarajan credited strategic groundwork and festive season sales for the record-breaking performance.advertisement"Our performance in the last quarter is a result of the groundwork we put in through the year—preparing for key launches and optimising operations to ensure we were ready to deliver at this scale, especially during the festive season in India," said Govindarajan, CEO of Royal Enfield.Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Feb 11, 2025
